PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McCelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Mart Niklus
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Mr Mart Niklus
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That we are deeply concerned for the well-being of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist who is in ill health and imprisoned in solitary confinement in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36 in Siberia.
(2) That Mr Mart Niklus has been imprisoned as a 'prisoner of conscience' for the non-violent exercise of his beliefs and is denied visiting and communications rights.

(3) That the Australian Government give its support to any initiatives in this case by Amnesty International which has adopted Mr Mart Niklus. Amnesty International believes he has committed no real crime and has never used or advocated the use of violence.
(4) That we urge the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly release Mr Mart Niklus and grant him a passport exit visa.
(5) That in its representation to the Government of the Soviet Union advise that the Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 13 citizens), Harradine (from 127 citizens), Townley (from 221 citizens), Walters (from 336 citizens) and Watson ( from 153 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Service
PETITION.PARA: The humble petition of residents of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth:
(1) that temporary salaried and full-time sessional teachers working for Adult Migrant Education Services are disadvantaged in status and security by lack of permanency and
(2) that this disadvantage is reflected in its effect on and implications for multicutural education.
(3) Victoria is particulary disadvantaged as with 30 per cent of national Adult Migrant Education program it has only one permanent member of staff.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) This imbalance be redressed by providing realistic funding for permanency.
(2) Funding should be used to balance the present inequity of permanent positions throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Program 'The Winners'
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That Australian Rules Football followers in the Northern Territory are deprived of their ability to view their National Sport (Australian Rules) by the Australian Broadcasting Commission's decision to withdraw the Television Program 'The Winners' from Territory and other viewers.
We therefore protest the Australian Broadcasting Commission's action.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate will request the Australian Broadcasting Commission to reinstate this program 'The Winners' as a matter of urgency
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: 1932-33 Famine in the Ukraine
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Ukrainian nation has suffered a genocidal act at the hands of the Kremlin when 7 million Ukrainians perished of starvation in 1932-33 in a deliberately planned famine.
Ukrainian Australian deplore the fact that the Kremlin has never been called upon by the free world to give a public account of this tragic event.

Russian Great Power Chauvinism which caused this Famine survives to this day. The Ukrainian Helsinki Monitoring Group, in the forefront of the opposition to the Russification and Ukrainian cultural destruction has been ruthlessly eliminated and protests by the West on its behalf ignored.

As the only founding member of the United Nations with no western diplomatic presence, Ukraine's political isolation allows Moscow to move unimpeded towards its goal of the complete elimination of the Ukrainian nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. The Australian Government denounce the Famine of 1932-33 in Ukraine as a genocidal act by the Kremlin against the Ukrainian nation.
2. The tragic events of the Ukrainian Famine Holocaust be highlighted during a day set aside by the Australian Government to honour victims of genocidal acts and imperialistic aggression.

3. The Australian Government immediately implement the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs and Defence to convene a Standing Committee to monitor the adherence to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights of all signatories, in particular, the U.S.S.R.
4. The Australian Government immediately take steps to expand official government representation to include all member states of the United Nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We urge the Government to declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;
We urge the Government to repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor Government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium;
We urge the Government to not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium mining pursuant to agreements entered into contrary to ALP policy; and
We urge the Government to discontinue the Roxby uranium mine development.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray for peace, disarmament and a nuclear free future.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 503 citizens), Giles (from 118 citizens), Hamer (from 795 citizens), Harradine (from 72 citizens) and Walters (from 241 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions which will be detrimental to women's golf in that-
A There will be interference with the rights of men and women to conduct separate competitions.
B Associate (women) golfers are handicapped differently to men golfers and use different tees and participation in the same competition under the same conditions would be detrimental to women.
C Associates now enjoy a lower membership fee and many would be unable to play golf if they had to pay the higher men's fee.
Your petitioners therefore pray that there will be no intervention in the existing arrangements for women's golf.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition from 129 citizens of Australia which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned, support Senator Chipp's Notice of Motion to establish a Senate Select Committee ''to enquire into and report upon the question of animal welfare in Australia'' and urge you as a member of the Senate to support this motion on behalf of concerned people throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition from 74 associate members of The North West Tasmanian Ladies' Golf District which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders:

SPEECH.PARA: Having been given the declared intention of the Federal Government to legislate on, ''Sex Discrimination Act'', it is the opinion of the following Associate Members of the North West Tasmanian Ladies' Golf District, that this legislation should be opposed, as, in its present form, it would be detrimental to all facets of the game of golf.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) is leaving Australia today to attend the General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation in Paris from 24 to 28 October and to hold discussions in other European capitals on education and youth policy issues. Senator Ryan will return to Australia on 6 November, and in her absence I will act as Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) condemns the Queensland Government's policy of secrecy in relation to the blatant sellout of 3.6m hectares of prime rural land to alien interests in that State by refusing to establish a register of foreign-owned land;
(b) notes with concern that more than 10 per cent of available agricultural and pastoral land there is already foreign-owned and foreign-controlled;

(c) calls on the Queensland Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, to publicly disclose any personal financial involvement in Japanese and South Korean companies that are being given such favourable treatment in tendering and investment opportunities to the detriment of competing Queensland companies; and

(d) demands that the Queensland Premier explain to the electors of that State precisely how and where the standard of living of ordinary Queenslanders has improved as a result of alleged progress, growth and development when 60 per cent of resource industries alone are foreign-owned and their profits are pouring out of the country faster than you can say 'multinational'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) congratulates the Queensland Government on its positive job creation policies which enabled it to decrease jobless numbers and go against the national trend of increased unemployment rates;
(b) acknowledges that this is a direct result of strong confidence in Queensland's economy and the implementation of wage pause program money-more than any other State;
(c) points out, that in Queensland young people have better opportunity of finding a job than in any other State; and

(d) notices that the unrelenting attack on the Queensland economy by certain Federal Government parliamentarians and the Queensland Branch of the Australian Labor Party has been to no avail in view of the upswing in employed persons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) recognises that the Queensland Government is the lowest taxed State;
(b) deplores the introduction of increased State taxes and charges in Western Australia despite election promises by the Western Australian Labor Party that there would be no immediate rises;
(c) regrets that the increased taxes and charges will cost $4 for every man, woman and child in Western Australia; and
(d) points that the new direction of Labor Parties in all mainland States has led to higher State taxes and charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) Congratulates the Queensland Government on its public sector building approvals which, according to the latest ABS figures, are the highest of any State, standing at 25.3 per cent of the national average compared to the New South Wales figure of 23.2 per cent;
(b) Notices that public sector building approvals in terms of value are above the national average;

(c) Observes that the total public and private sector approvals exceed the per capita ratio of any other State-Queensland, with 16 per cent of the nation's population, accounted for 21 per cent of all dwellings approved in August, whereas New South Wales, with 35 per cent had 28 per cent of dwellings approved; and
(d) Condemns Federal Labor Ministers and the Queensland branch of the Labor Party for unwarranted and mischievous attacks on Queensland's building industry.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
REPATRIATION LEGISLATIONAMENDMENT BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 18 October 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I suggest that it would be appropriate that this Bill be debated cognately with the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1983?
—Is that course of action agreed to? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night just before dinner I was addressing my remarks on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill to issues relating to the assets test and in particular to the questionnaire that was produced some three months ago by the Government in regard to the income test. This questionnaire was sent out to those persons over 70 who, by the Government's decision, would be made subject to the income test. I drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that a statement at the foot of the questionnaire required that an authorisation be given by the pensioner concerned in order that details of that pensioner's financial affairs be made available to the Government by banks, building societies and other institutions of that kind for the purposes of assessing eligibility for the pension. I was making the point that I could not see the need for that authority to be given in light of the general legislative authority which the Government has which enables it to seek out information of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to draw that matter to the Government's attention, because it has been mentioned in the community as a significant and major source of discontent with the Government's actions in regard to the imposition of the income test on the over 70s. People cannot see the need for it. Certainly if there are deficiencies in the Government's legal authority in this regard it ought to amend the law and do it properly rather than take the kind of action which it has in this respect. I refer to the matter of having people authorise the Government to inquire into their financial affairs in the way in which it sought to do.

I make that point because the questionnaire, while it was allegedly designed to obtain information about the income of people over 70 for the purposes of assessment for the income test, looked very much as though it was designed to obtain other information. We all now know that is true. The required information related to people's assets. As a result, no doubt the Government was preparing the way for the introduction of the assets test, which was subsequently announced in the Budget of August of this year. I believe that it was really something of a deception on the part of the Government to seek to have people authorise, if you like, the Government to obtain information of a very private kind about their financial affairs under the guise of seeking information for the purposes of assessment for the income test, while in reality it was seeking information about assets and at the same time denying that it was contemplating introducing any assets test. I think that that point needs to be drawn to the attention of the Government as being one of very significant concern among the community and one which has been mentioned very extensively by my contacts around the place.

One or two other matters in regard to the legislation which I think are worthy of note are the moves by the Government apparently in regard to the McLeay report on accommodation and home care for the aged. This does seem to indicate that the Government is moving towards the introduction, again in a piecemeal way , of part of the recommendations of that report. The Opposition does not deny that there are many very significant advantages in some of the recommendations of that report. We support generally the thrust of the Government's intentions in that regard in this legislation. There are other issues which the Government has acknowledged need to be examined in this regard and, no doubt, it is undertaking a very comprehensive review of those points at present.

I return very briefly to the major point of the Opposition's position in regard to this legislation-that is, in connection with the payment of unemployment benefit to workers who have been stood down as a result of industrial action outside the work place in which they are engaged. I reiterate the Opposition's position. We will oppose the relevant clauses in the Committee stage of this debate. I understand from public statements this morning that the Australian Democrats intend to support that position also. No doubt the Government has a view as to whether it is prepared to accept that, but we believe that the reasons we will be taking that line of action are cogent. They are rational in terms of the policies of the former Government with regard to industrial relations.

I refer in particular to the industrial law amendments which were undertaken by the Fraser Government in October 1979. They sought to introduce more individual responsibility into union affairs so as to ensure that industrial action was a collective responsibility of all union members rather than that of only a section. For that reason, we have opposed the Government's action in this regard in limiting the responsibility of a union in regard to strike action to only a limited number of people so that that greater number of people can be exempt from the effects of their actions. If people are members of trade unions, they should bear equally and collectively the responsibility of their actions. That remains the fundamental principle to which we adhere and it is the reason why we will oppose that clause. During the latter stages of the debate and in the Committee stage, I will be speaking at greater length on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill implements most of the Budget's initiatives in the area of social security and reflects the high priority given to social welfare, using that term in its broadest sense, in the Labor Party's election policy and campaign. During that campaign I found widespread concern that more be done for those in the community disadvantaged by age, illness or economic circumstances, often exacerbated by the policies of the previous Government. After six months in Parliament I can understand how honourable senators tend to become isolated from the realities of life for large numbers of Australians who are living in poverty or in other forms of need. We need consciously to fight against that isolation and keep in touch with the real world in which many people spend much of their lives without the security of an adequate income and the things which that income can buy.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators talk, for example, about freedom to choose a school or a doctor. Large numbers of Australians cannot afford that choice. This Bill aims to make life more bearable for some of the most disadvantaged of those people. I refer to some of the provisions of the Bill which reduce disadvantage and remove discrimination. Firstly, I refer to clause 13 of the Bill which deals with the spouse carer's pension. This clause removes previously existing discrimination. A wife caring for an aged or disabled husband could receive additional pension for his care, but a husband caring for his wife could not. The criteria are now the same for both sexes. The person being cared for must be severely handicapped , an aged or invalid pensioner or a recipient of a rehabilitation allowance who was previously an invalid pensioner and must be cared for under constant care at home. It surprises me that this anomaly persisted until 1983. I am glad that it has now been removed, giving community recognition to the fact that men as well as women can be responsible for the care of others.

Part III of the Bill refers in part to hostel care. An anomaly has existed whereby the Government has provided a substantial subsidy for patients in nursing homes but this subsidy has not been available to those in hostel accommodation, many of whom through age or disablement need personal care, for example, help with dressing and bathing. This Bill introduces a subsidy of $10 a week for each person requiring hostel care and an additional $40 a week for each person needing personal care. Apart from the obvious direct benefit of this change, it may relieve the pressure on nursing homes which presently accommodate some patients who might be more appropriately accommodated in hostels.

This Bill makes a number of provisions relating to the unemployment benefit. It was a significant acknowledgement of the high priority given to reducing unemployment and its attendant hardships that the first Bill passed by this Senate increased the rate of unemployment benefit for single adults. This was in line with our commitment to reduce progressively the difference between the unemployment benefit and the standard pension rate. The next step in this progression is the provision in this Bill of a further increase, bringing the single rate to $73.60-half the married rate plus $2. This Bill also provides a much needed increase in the unemployment benefit for those aged 16 to 18 years. It has seemed to me that the decision makers on these matters have been out of touch with the real situation of many of the young people who are expected to live on a much lower income than someone a year or even a few months older.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I draw your attention to the same standing order that you invoked last night, that is, standing order 406. The honourable senator seems to be reading her speech without even any attempt to use it as copious notes.

—Order! I point out that I did not invoke any standing order last night; I was not in the chair. I have been watching Senator Zakharov very closely and she is referring to notes. I invite her to continue.
—She has to make a pretence of not reading it.
— Order!

—Would the honourable senator like to see my notes? She would see that they are in my handwriting and, as I do not have good handwriting, I have to concentrate on them. Some members of the Opposition have said that they believe 16-year-olds to 18-year-olds should still be supported by their families . The fact is that, for various reasons, many young people of that age are on their own and need an income to survive. Sixteen-year-olds eat as much as 18- year-olds; many parents would say they eat more. A 16-year-old has the same fares, clothing and shelter needs as an 18-year-old. At the same time, 16-year- olds are less likely to have adequate support systems in the community. They do not normally have friends, for example, who have accommodation of their own to offer in an emergency, and older people are more likely to know how to seek help from community organisations. We cannot ignore the poverty of young people and at the same time piously deplore the petty thieving and juvenile prostitution which are its corollaries. In this Bill the benefit for 16-year-olds to 18-year- olds has been increased by $5 a week, and I hope we will be able to increase the unemployment benefit for that age group to a realistic level during this term of Parliament while concurrently seeking an alternative range of services and income support schemes for young people.

SPEECH.PARA: I share Senator Messner's disquiet about the gap between the unemployment benefit and the tertiary education assistance scheme. I assure him that the Government has not forgotten its commitment to people dependent on TEAS but it is a matter of priorities. I remind him that this Government has done more for students in relation to both the level of the TEAS allowance and its means test than the previous Government did in recent years.

I refer now to a couple of matters which do not affect many people but which are very important to the people whom they do affect. Under the amendment to section 6B of the Act, the family allowance will now be payable for the six weeks after students leave school and before they become eligible for the unemployment benefit. This removes the anomaly whereby school leavers cannot claim the benefit and are thus still dependent on their parents but on the other hand their parents are no longer able to receive the family allowance.

Clause 9 redefines income to overcome the anomaly which received a lot of prominence earlier this year whereby the receipt of other forms of assistance, such as emergency relief after a bushfire or flood or insurance payments and compensation for loss of property, was regarded as income for the purpose of determining eligibility for benefits. Those sorts of payments will no longer be regarded as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Last night , you took a point of order because someone was reading a speech. I think the honourable senator is making no attempt not to read her speech. Indeed, she is holding it up in front of her and very obviously reading it. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you took a similar point of order last night, I would imagine that you would view this action with a bit of concern.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to take into account that what we are seeing here is a deliberate attempt to obstruct the honourable senator from making a speech. This is a omnibus Bill which contains many clauses referring to different parts of the legislation. The honourable senator has obviously prepared her speech carefully, which is more than one can say for the honourable senator who took the point of order. In fact, Senator Zakharov is reading from notes she prepared herself. I think it ill becomes a senator like Senator Collard, who reads speeches prepared by mining companies, and Senator Walters, who would not make a speech without referring to the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Ltd to see what she could say, to try to obstruct another senator making a speech.
—I take a point of order.
—I will make a ruling at this stage.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Giles

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been waiting for the opportunity to say this for a very long time. Standing order 406, to which we are referring, states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall read his speech.
I submit that this rule has no relevance whatsoever to the women who now grace this chamber and I ask you to rule accordingly, Mr Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I also make some statements?

—No. I intend to make a ruling on Senator Giles' point of order first. In view of the equality of senators in this place, there is no point of order in respect of the application of the standing order to women. I have already ruled on a similar point of order to that of Senator Walters. I have been watching Senator Zakharov carefully. She has copious notes to which she is referring. I rule that she is not reading a speech. If Senator Walters had been here last night she would have heard what the President said when I raised a similar point of order. I invite her to read his comments if she has not already done so. I call Senator Zakharov.
—Perhaps in answer to the point of order I might make a personal point.
—I ask the honourable senator to continue.

—This Bill also provides assistance for staff salaries, meals and accommodation for homeless persons. This is an area of urgent need because traditionally the homeless person has usually been in the elderly category. Now there are large numbers of young people who are also homeless and needing help. Clause 35 of the Bill allows for the payment of pension directly into a bank account, a credit union or a building society. This will lessen the opportunity for fraud or theft. A few years ago a student of mine aged then about 13 years, but looking much younger, managed to cash four pension cheques that she found in letterboxes on her way home from school. If shops apparently without question can cash cheques presented by a child it must be very easy for adults to cash other people's cheques. Payment to accounts would remove this possibility, thus saving government money, but more importantly obviating the delay and difficulty for the lawful recipient of the cheque who now has to get a replacement.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to the rule introduced by the previous Government which denies unemployment benefit to a trade unionist stood down because of a strike of members of his or her union in another place of employment. We had a situation in Victoria a few years ago in which large numbers of unionists were unable to work because of a strike at a power-station complex. Thanks to the provisions of that discriminatory rule, every relief organisation in Melbourne was drained to provide for the families of unionists whose only reason for disqualification from benefit was that they belonged to a union whose members were on strike in another part of the State.

Since I know that many non-unionists are ignorant of what happens during a strike, it needs to be noted that the unionists themselves will receive neither wages nor unemployment benefit. Their families will be supported in the traditional way in which unionists have always supported their mates. But members of unions not on strike at the same place of work and those stood down in other places will be entitled to the unemployment benefit. Therefore, I am strongly opposed to Senator Messner's proposed amendment.

I can understand the Opposition coalition parties opposing this clause. They have a long history of union bashing and opposition to the organisation of workers, because it threatens the interests of the people they represent, or those who are the basis of their support, but I am genuinely surprised that it is reported that the Australian Democrats also are reported to oppose the clause , because the existing rules go against what I understood the Democrats to hold dear. The rules introduced by the Fraser Government are undemocratic and unjust, discriminating against whole families because one of their members has exercised his or her democratic right-I would say duty-to belong to a trade union.

I referred a moment ago to a particular dispute in Victoria, where the operation of this disqualification caused a great deal of hardship. At that time even Liberal supporters in my work place donated money to help those in need. Surely, the Democrats do not wish to see children suffer because their father or mother belongs to an organisation whose members in another place altogether are on strike. Do the minders really mind what happens to innocent people? This Bill provides real assistance to many of those in greatest need. I hope, as economic circumstances allow, that our Government can move further in the direction of a co-ordinated equitable policy of income support and other services for all those who have much less than a fair share of this country's wealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. During the discussion which we had in the last few minutes, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) mentioned that I had come into the Senate with prepared speeches by mining companies. I take exception to that. I think Hansard would probably wish that my speeches were better prepared or prepared by somebody other than me. I think the last time I could claim to have had a prepared speech was for my maiden speech, for which I was given the indulgence of this House, the same as everbody else is. I completely reject the allegations by Senator Grimes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Acting Deputy President--
—Stop reading.

—Senator Grimes can never pull that one on me. The Opposition does not oppose the majority of the various provisions that the Government has brought down. Indeed, the Opposition applauds many of the aspects of the Government's omnibus Bill, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) rightly calls it. It is indeed an omnibus Bill. It is consistent with the piecemeal approach of this Government. I believe the Government should rethink the whole of the social security area. It has gone into areas where angels fear to tread and taken off certain aspects of social welfare-I will come to them later-and added others. It has thereby created tremendous anomalies in social welfare. The Government does not have an original thought in its mind; it has absolutely no innovative thoughts at all. The Government which preceded the Labor Government, the Liberal Party Government, brought in a family allowance. We automatically tied the level of age pensions to the consumer price index. Original thought had been given to those areas. But the present Government cannot do more than take off, put on and touch up around the edges. This creates tremendous anomalies, as I have said already.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with some of those anomalies. Let us look at what the Government has done to the over-70s. Even though this legislation does not include matters relating to the over-70s, it certainly reflects the tenor of the Government's social security legislation. The over-70s have certainly taken a bashing. The Government introduced an assets test that was discriminatory from the very beginning. It allows people who have invested their money in certain areas to get away with those large amounts of investment. But it has created problems for the person who has not invested large sums of money in areas such as art, jewellery and other comforts like yachts, homes and caravans. There really are grave anomalies in this legislation. It has attacked the under-70s who have just bought their own homes and perhaps a small holiday home. It is these people whom the Government has said are not entitled to these meagre things. Of course, the Government has not come to any firm decision about the assets test. The over-70s have lost their non-income test related benefits. Altogether the assets test is creating tremendous problems for the elderly. As I said before, I have gone around units and spoken to people in their 80s. They said they will now have to change their accommodation arrangements because the Government has taken away the paltry amount that they were receiving free of the incomes test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paltry?

—Senator Crowley does not understand the situation when she says 'paltry?'. The amount was very small. It was just over $50 a week, but it was important to those people who had arranged their finances for the rest of their lives. They had arranged their finances for accommodation and had arranged to spend that small amount of money on food. Now that has been taken away from them they will have to move from their accommodation into lesser forms of accommodation. That is a very traumatic experience to be forced on those people at 80 years of age.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition applauds the Government for some measures in this legislation. I was delighted to see the unemployment benefit increased for both the under-18s and the over-18s. We have to look, of course, at what the Government has done about the tertiary education assistance scheme. The gap between it and the unemployment benefit is widening considerably. It is creating great hardship for students who receive TEAS.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I believe that the honourable senator is digressing from the subject matter of the Bills before the chamber and ought to be called to relevance.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that this is a cognate debate. I do not see that what Senator Walters is debating at present is out of the range of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill. There is no point of order. I call Senator Walters. (Quorum formed)

INTERJECT.PARA: Before I call Senator Walters, may I say that I recognise that Senator Walters is one of the best debaters in the chamber and well able to care for herself in exchanges across the floor. Nevertheless, the Senate must be orderly and she is entitled to the protection of the Chair. I call Senator Walters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. I appreciate those remarks. As I have rather flimsy notes, I am not quite sure where I was up to before the quorum was called. Perhaps I will just go back to the assets test and the fact that those people who are in the later years of life are to be disadvantaged. I think I have covered that aspect fairly well but it is a situation where the Government has a general philosophy of not treating all people equally. It seems to me that many people in their eighties who have paid their taxes all their lives-
—All of your friends.

—Well, they certainly have. All my friends who have paid their taxes all their lives have decided now that they should be entitled, as I said earlier, to that small amount that the Government was giving them, but the continuity of that payment has been destroyed by the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The tertiary education assistance scheme is again an area in which there is great discrimination because we now have a situation where people who are over 18 years of age and who are single and with no dependants at all receive $73.50 unemployment benefit each week. I do not think that that is too large an amount by any manner of means; but, if we compare that to the TEAS allowance, we will see where the anomalies exist. The area with which the Opposition has the greatest concern is section 107 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill that amends the principal Act. I will read it because it deals with unemployment benefits for those who are on strike or associated in some way with a striking union. Proposed new section 107 (4A) states:

Sub-section (4) does not, by reason of paragraph (4) (b), disqualify a person from receiving unemployment benefit in respect of a period if the Director- General is satisfied that the place or places at which the relevant industrial action occurred was not or were not a place or places at which the person, if he had not been unemployed-
(a) would, throughout or for a substantial part of that period, have carried on his employment or work; or
(b) would, throughout that period, have regularly attended for the purpose of being organized in his employment or work.

All that means-as mentioned in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) who delivered that speech on behalf of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes)-is that direct participants in a strike will indeed not qualify for the unemployment benefit. Members of a striking union at the establishment at which a strike takes place will also not qualify. So, if a person is working in an area in which the rest of the trade unionists are on strike, that person, if he were stood down, would not be entitled to the unemployment benefit. However as the law stands now, if that person's union is on strike, if he is perhaps employed in the industry, in the company next door, and if he has voted for the strike and is stood down because there is no work available because some of his members are on strike, he can collect unemployment benefit. This will change under the Government's amendment. People who are stood down through lack of work and who are not members of the union at the establishment at which the strike takes place and who are not themselves on strike will qualify for unemployment benefit.

This is an area that is of great concern to the Opposition. Indeed, if we go back a few years, we will find that it was also of great concern to the Australia Labor Party. Indeed, Mr Chifley-and I doubt whether the people opposite me today would be critical of that leader; he was a respected Labor Leader of the time and he certainly was not a pro-Moscow leader-when he was in government in 1947 said that a person who was a direct participant in a strike was not paid unemployment benefit. If he was not a direct participant but was a member of a participating union, and employed at the place of industrial action he was not entitled to receive unemployment benefit. If he was a member of the participating union he was not paid unemployment benefit even though he was not directly participating and was not employed at the place of the industrial strikes. The law at that stage was far stricter than the law is at the moment. It said that if a person was a member of a non-participating union which did not disown the strike, in other words, if he was a member of another union, that union had to disown the strike. If it did not do so, then he, too, was not entitled to unemployment benefit.

So the law as it stands now is far less strict than the law which applied in 1947. I believe that this points very clearly to the road that this Government is taking. It started off by saying that it would govern with union accord. It told the Australian people that it would legislate in the area of the economy of this country only after the unionist had agreed exactly with it, but it will not agree to do anything that the unions do not agree to. Consequently we had, at the earliest opportunity, the downgrading of this legislation that now insists upon the taxpayer coming to the party where industrial action takes place. It seems to me to be an incredible situation that if a union, for one reason or another, wants to go on strike, the taxpayer has to foot the bill for the unemployment benefit for which those people can apply.

I believe that the sophistication of the present method of strikes makes this legislation quite a farce. We have areas in which very few people are taken out on strike but which cause considerable disruption all over the country. A small group of people will go on strike and other people can be stood down because there is no work available for them. Under this new amendment they will be entitled to unemployment benefit. There will be no need for them to pressure their union or their mates into going back to work so that their families can be looked after. Their wives can collect unemployment benefit if their husbands are on strike. The husbands who are stood down, of course, can also get unemployment benefit. The Opposition is concerned about the Government's decision in this area. Senator Messner has already said that the Opposition proposes to move an amendment. We will discuss the amendment at the Committee stage. I am delighted to know that the Australian Democrats are considering supporting the Opposition' s amendment. I will talk further about it at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I will be setting a precedent in this debate by paying some attention in the first few moments of my speech to the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1983. We have been conducting, allegedly, a cognate debate on this Bill and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 but, as far as I am aware, very few comments have been made about the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill. The Australian Democrats congratulate the Government on fulfilling a significant range of election promises which were made to repatriation benefit recipients in this country. In particular, income limits for fringe benefits eligibility are to be indexed and, in periods of high inflation, of course, that is something devoutly to be wished . The other major amendment is the ending of an anomaly in that women have been able to qualify for a service pension if they have been providing constant care and attention to a severely handicapped male service pensioner but the reverse has not been the case. This legislation now corrects that anomaly, and I am pleased to see it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters seemed to spend most of her time debating a piece of legislation which not only has not been introduced into this place but also, if the signs are an accurate indication, may never be introduced into this place. I am referring to the Government's proposed incomes and asset test legislation. I am not quite sure whether Senator Walters did that because she did not have a great deal to say about the omnibus Bill which is before us today or because she had prepared a speech for distribution in Tasmania and was trying to hide the fact that the Liberal Opposition has indicated that it intends to support the income and assets test legislation if and when it is introduced into this place. Anybody who believes that the Opposition will repeal it, if and when it ever gets into government, will believe anything. I also point out that people over 70 years of age, who used to be able to benefit from the frozen means test, are suffering simply because the Liberal Opposition supported the Government's legislation in May and June of this year, and without the excuse, I might add, that it was a Budget Bill. Anyone concerned about the problems that are facing the people over 70 because of a means test on their pension can blame the Liberal Opposition as much as they blame the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you vote against it?
—I spoke against it very strongly, Senator Messner. I remind you that whenever we call a division on something in which you are in cahoots with the Government--
—Order! I ask Senator Haines to direct her remarks through the Chair.

—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President. I point out to you, sir, that whenever the Australian Democrats call a division on something in which the Liberal Opposition is in cahoots with the Labor Government, as it was with regard to the over-70 means test, the Opposition accuses us of grandstanding. It cannot have it both ways.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular legislation is also predominantely aimed at increasing assistance to the needy and the disadvantaged. It does it in two major ways. The first is by increasing levels of payment. For example, the rate of benefit to unemployed single adults with no dependants has been increased by $4.95 a week, bringing it to $73.60, which is just slightly over half the married rate. I, of course, agree with everything Senator Messner said yesterday with regard to people having to be given adequate levels of financial support when they are needy, disadvantaged, unemployed or elderly, but I wonder why he and his party did not take this point of view during the seven years they were in government. We could, of course, argue forever about what the levels should be. These levels are at least an improvement on what they have been and are an acknowledgement by this Government that we have a responsibility adequately to support those people who are affected by economic and other problems in Australia.

The second way in which this legislation aims to provide additional assistance to those in need is by extending a range of benefits. These include the introduction of a zone allowance, which I point out has been a part of Australian Democrat policy for a long time. The legislation extends the mother's and guardian's allowance to a married pensioner with a child or with children in the case where the spouse of the person lives apart because of illness or infirmity. Again, this is a long overdue removal of an unnecessary anomally. This brings me to that section of the legislation for which I have no support, that is, sub-clauses (2) and (3) of clause 30. According to the second reading speech:

This Bill also provides for the modification of the existing rule that disqualifies a trade unionist who is not himself on strike from receiving unemployment benefit if his unemployment is due to other members of his trade union being on strike.
The second reading speech goes on to say:
With the introduction of this amendment, the rules governing qualification for unemployment benefit in strike situations will be as follows-
(1) direct participants in a strike will not be qualified for benefit-
I add that, of course, neither should they be-
(2) members of a striking union at the establishment at which a strike takes place will not be qualified for benefit-
again, neither should they be-
(3) members of other unions at the establishment at which a strike takes place who are not themselves on strike will be qualified for benefit-
That is acceptable enough since, presumably, members of other unions can have no control over what a separate union or its members do. The second reading speech continues:
(4) persons stood down at other establishments as a result of a strike will be qualified for benefit, irrespective of their union membership.

It is about that section that I have considerable misgivings. It seems to me that in allowing a member of the union who is stood down at a particular plant or site, because of action taken by his union at another plant or site, to receive the unemployment benefit or to be subsidised in some way by the taxpayer is removing the last remaining restraint on some unionists to force them to act with some sort of social responsibility. These people do have some say in what the members of their union do or they should have some say in what they do. Therefore, any action which their fellow union members take which affects them is as much their responsibility as their brother unionists' responsibility. They must accept responsibility for that and any problems that arise from such action .

Senator Zakharov made the point that if members of a union are out on strike ' their mates' come in and help them with some form of donation. If they are concerned in that way, they can extend that action to members of their union who are stood down at other sites. I point out, of course, that legislation still exists in this country which says that the wife of a striker is entitled to make a claim for unemployment benefits. That legislation still stands. It applies in this case. If the spouse is working, of course, the unionist who is on strike or who is stood down will not be able to qualify for unemployment benefits. So in effect the removal of this clause will have an impact almost entirely on single unionists. Even if it did not, I would hold to the original principle that I stated: All members of a union must be held responsible and must be prepared to accept the responsibility for actions of other members of that union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even from different States?

—If they are members of the same union, they must, I reiterate, accept responsibility for the behaviour of their fellow unionists. If they are not members of the same union, they do not have to do so.
—That is not quite how the real world is.

—Then perhaps they ought to think a little before they act irresponsibly and anti-socially. The Minister says that this is a case of discrimination against trade unionists. I suggest that it is perhaps retribution against trade unionists who choose to act irresponsibly and with no real thought for the results of their actions either on society generally or on other members of their union at different sites. That remains true whether they are within the same State or within the same city. I cannot see a great deal of point in worrying about distance. It is, therefore, the intention of the Australian Democrats to support the amendment to delete clauses 30 (2) and 30 (3), lines 30 to 43. Unlike other senators on this side of the House, I do not feel moved to repeat at the Committee stage what I have said in my second reading speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a significant amount of money as far as the Budget is concerned. Probably about 30 per cent of the Budget is devoted to social welfare and related matters. First, I should like to refer to the repatriation part of this cognate debate and to indicate my interest in the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. It is currently being conducted into the possible effects of agent orange on the health of Vietnam veterans and their families. I am interested in this matter because the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment made an inquiry into exactly the same subject and I presented that report to the Senate last year. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs at the time, Senator Messner, showed great interest in that report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believed that we went into the matter in great detail. Significant witnesses came before us, including people of the calibre of Dr McBride, the physician who became world famous for his work on thalidomide and the mutogenic effects it had with respect to deformity of the foetus. Several representatives of the Vietnam Veterans Association and their scientific advisers gave evidence. We thought that we came up with quite sensible conclusions based on scientific fact. For example, we said that there was no possibility that the wife of a Vietnam veteran who had been exposed possibly to agent orange in Vietnam 15 years ago could produce a deformed child because of such exposure, simply because in order to produce a deformed child as a result of exposure to a toxic chemical of that type the female has to be exposed to it during the first 12 weeks or so of pregnancy. So we tried to alleviate the concern of the wives of Vietnam veterans in that way.

However, in that report we said that we had concern about the possible carcinogenic effects of anti-malarial drugs. We said that we had concern about the use of pesticides for the removal of mosquitoes and the prevention of malaria, and so on. We said that more work needed to be done on those matters to satisfy us that the health of Vietnam veterans and their families had not suffered as a result of such things. We also pointed to the fact that we could not make a conclusive report simply because two scientific studies were being conducted-they are still being conducted-one of them dealing with the mortality rate amongst Vietnam veterans. Of course, one has to look at this matter having regard to the epidemiological evidence throughout the community as a whole. One must look at the age group of soldiers who did not go to Vietnam and at citizens throughout the community in a similar age group to form some sort of statistical pattern, and see whether evidence presented could indicate that perhaps Vietnam veterans are suffering more or are dying earlier than other people in the community of a similar age group.

We were also anxiously awaiting the production of a report on morbidity. I understand that that has been changed to a psychiatric study. Both of these reports will not be available until about the end of next year, to the best of my knowledge, so that the Royal Commission will inevitably come to the same conclusions. It will be looking at the same people and the same evidence. The Opposition of the day seemed to claim that royal commissions had some great overriding powers and authority way above those which existed for the Senate committee. That is a lot of nonsense, because at least a Senate committee has an opportunity to present a report and then follow it up by asking the Govenrment what has been done about that report. A royal commission presents a report, but quite frequently such reports are shelved and gather dust over the years, without any action at all being taken.

What concerns me is that the current Royal Commission with respect to Vietnam veterans' health is costing this year $3.7m. If it drags on for a year or two in order to examine the reports to which I have referred, which are not due to be presented until next year, it will cost another $3m or $4m. That is the sort of cockeyed approach of the Government today. That $7m or $8m, or whatever it costs , could well be employed in providing a little more financial benefit to Vietnam veterans and others through the Repatriation Act. It is interesting to observe that the inquiry conducted by the Senate committee cost about $100,000 to $150, 000. So here is this Government, uncertain of many aspects of its responsibilities, handing matters over to royal commissions willy-nilly to give it some sort of breathing space, and at tremendous cost to the taxpayers of Australia. I am anxiously awaiting the report of that royal commission. I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) will ask his colleague to accelerate the process so that we can examine the royal commissioner's report and compare it with the report of the Senate Standing Committee. I suggest that there will not be much difference.

The then Minister, Senator Messner, recognising what we had to say about Vietnam veterans, took action as a result of some of our recommendations. He anticipated some of the things that we were going to say because of the evidence presented to us. I commend him for that. He extended the counselling facilities available to Vietnam veterans. He made changes to the Act to assist them more than they had been assisted before. I compliment him on recognising the value of the Committee report by taking those steps.

I would like to talk a little about the Opposition's concern with respect to the payment of unemployment benefits to unionists who are not involved in a strike. As Senator Grimes mentioned in his second reading speech:

This Bill also provides for the modification of the existing rule that disqualifies a trade unionist who is not himself on strike from receiving unemployment benefit if his unemployment is due to other members of his trade union being on strike. The existing rule was introduced in October 1979 and has the effect of discriminating against trade unionists. Under the proposed amendment, a trade unionist will not be disqualified for the purposes of unemployment benefit if the industrial action did not occur at the place where he was employed.

I am very worried about that because, in my opinion and in the opinion of many others in the community, this country has to do all it can to prevent strikes. I think this measure will encourage strikes. I will be very concerned if we pay unemployment benefits to people who are not directly involved in a strike. What will happen, for example, if the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its drive for a 38-hour week perhaps goes to the extreme of creating a national strike? That would mean that all the trade unionists throughout Australia would have to be paid an unemployment benefit at a tremendous cost to the community. What we ought to do, of course, is strengthen our industrial relations laws so that we can discourage strikes, if that is possible.

I have raised the question of demarcation disputes in previous debates. What do demarcation disputes really have to do with the Government? I think a demarcation dispute should be argued before a disputes council of the ACTU. Its members are the experts. They can judge whether a seaman's work has to be carried out in this way or that way or whether a member of the Merchant Service Guild of Australia has to do certain types of work. I think that decisions on the question of demarcation in those areas should be and ought to be the responsibility of the ACTU. It disturbs me that because of those sorts of disputes the goods of Australia have been held up on the waterfronts, for up to three months in many instances, to the detriment of our overseas trading credibility. I believe that the ACTU happens to be the authority to deal with those sorts of disputes. If that could be done strikes would become fewer and fewer and our credibility as a trading partner overseas would be restored.

I refer again to the matter of an unemployed person who went to Adelaide recently to demonstrate against the development of uranium. The Government is paying an unemployed benefit to that person who came from Sydney. He was over there trying to prevent uranium development at Olympic Dam, which would provide about 10,000 jobs for people in South Australia and in other parts of Australia who want to work if that project goes ahead. Let me comment on that matter. During the last election campaign I was in Port Augusta introducing a Liberal Party Senate team colleague to the people in the business area. I was walking along Commercial Road and I came upon two young men; one was very casually, but neatly dressed. He came over to me and said: 'Senator Jessop, what will you do for me on Saturday at the election?' I said: 'What do you want me to do?' He said: 'I want a job'. He said that he was anxious that mining in that part of South Australia should commence because that was the sort of work he wanted to do. His friend sauntered over to me and said: 'I'm going to vote Labor because Labor will increase the dole. It will give me more dole'. Those were the attitudes of two young men. One wanted to work; the other was quite satisfied to receive an additional dole payment in order to remain unemployed. I was so impressed with the first young man that I succeeded in getting him an interview with a company in that area and opened up the possibility of a job opportunity for him. That story illustrates the attitude amongst some people in Australia. Some people anxiously want to work and I believe that they represent the majority of those who are unemployed at the moment. There are others who simply just do not want to work at all.

In my opinion the amendment which will be brought up in the Committee stage and which has been laid on the table now by Senator Messner is worthy of support because it removes an incentive for people to go on strike. I think it is bad to pay people when they go on strike. By accepting this amendment I think we will go part of the way to encourage responsible trade unionists to attend their meetings in order to speak against unreasonable strikes. If they did that there would be a lot less trouble in the community. We would have a lot fewer strikes and a lot less disruption to the workers not involved directly in any strike which is contemplated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to mention two matters in relation to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. First of all, I am pleased to see that the Government has brought in a zone allowance increase for pensioners- all those who are in receipt of a pension benefit or sheltered employment or rehabilitation allowances. For a single person that will mean an increase of $7 a week, for a couple $12 a week and for a child $3.50 a week. That is something which I suggested very long ago when I first came to this House and I am glad to see that some action has been taken in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area relating to pensions on which I wish to speak is along the same lines. The other day I read an article-I think its title was 'Solar Energy, the Energy of the Rich?'-and the point brought out in that article was that it costs a considerable amount of money to heat houses in many of the areas of this country. The article also said that some people could not afford to heat their houses to the degree that they should be heated. I believe that the houses in which pensioners live often fall into that category. Many pensioners cannot afford to place in the ceilings and walls of their premises the insulation they need for efficient heating of a house. I would like to suggest that at some stage the Government look at considering a way of adding an increment, something along the line of the increment that has been added for expensive living zones, towards the cost of a pensioner's heating. Obviously somebody who lives in Cairns does not need to pay as much towards heating a house, whether it be by way of wood, oil or electricity, as somebody who lives in Canberra or in other colder areas of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hobart?
—I will not mention Tasmania because I must repeat here and now that Tasmania is not nearly as cold as many people think. It is certainly not as cold during the winter as this city is.

SPEECH.PARA: If we accept that living is more expensive in some areas of the country and that we need to add to the pensioner zone allowance, I think that the Government , when the country can afford it, should look at some way of adding a heating allowance to pensions. I have mentioned this matter also on other occasions with regard to pensions.

I turn now to the union situation. Senator Zakharov said that the Liberal Party and the coalition had a long history of union bashing; I think those were her words. I do not think that is true. Many people who vote for the Liberal Party are unionists. I know very many of them who are in the Liberal Party organisation. It would not be to the coalition's advantage to take a line of union bashing. A major aspect of this legislation that concerns the Opposition is the provision for the payment of unemployment benefit to people who are out of work because of strike action. I think that most people in this country would say: 'Why on earth should the taxpayer be expected to help finance a strike?'. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) stated:

This Bill also provides for the modification of the existing rule that disqualifies a trade unionist who is not himself on strike from receiving unemployment benefit if his unemployment is due to other members of his trade union being on strike. The existing rule was introduced in October 1979 and has the effect of discriminating against trade unionists. Under the proposed amendment, a trade unionist will not be disqualified for the purposes of unemployment benefit if the industrial action did not occur at the place where he was employed.
In that second reading speech, he continued:
With the introduction of this amendment, the rules governing qualification for unemployment benefit in strike situations will be as follows-
(1) direct participants in a strike will not be qualified for benefit
I think that rule is quite reasonable. He continued:
(2) members of a striking union at the establishment at which a strike takes place will not be qualified for benefit
(3) members of other unions at the establishment at which a strike takes place who are not themselves on strike will be qualified for benefit
The Opposition takes exception to the final rule, which is:
(4) persons stood down at other establishments as a result of a strike will be qualified for benefit, irrespective of their union membership.

Currently, a trade unionist who is stood down or loses his job permanently because of industrial action by members of his union, no matter where, is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit. The effect of the Government's amendment will be that a trade unionist will not be disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit if the industrial action did not occur at the place where he was employed. The current rule was inserted by the previous Government in October 1979 on the grounds that responsibility for sponsorship or support of a strike by a trade union must be accepted equally by all members of that union. I do not think that many people in the country would take exception to that rule. The essential point is that this was an industrial relations measure and not a social welfare one. The purpose was to enforce a sense of responsibility on militant unions and to make them more aware of the effects of their actions. In addition, the displeasure of fellow trade unionists stood down and denied unemployment benefit provided a useful tool for moderate union leaders seeking to bring a branch that is out of line back into line.

It is likely that, in enforcing this rule, innocent trade union members and their families might be penalised, but the action of their fellow union members is the reason for their being disadvantaged, not the social security system. If the prime purpose of section 107 is to impose responsibility on trade unions and provide a further means of settling industrial disputes, I believe that the Government's proposed amendment should be opposed for all the reasons that have been given here today, including those given a moment ago by Senator Jessop.

I believe there is a need to ensure responsibility and accountability of unionists to the community. They have to acknowledge collective responsibility. I do not think that unemployment benefit should be used to finance union actions . When the Fraser Government brought in the legislation of 1979, it sought to formally encapsulate in the Social Security Act principles which had first been enunciated and laid down by the Chifley Labor Government. These principles were laid down a fair while ago, I admit, but let me tell honourable senators what was said in a letter from T. H. Kewley in Australian Social Security Today. In quoting a letter from Senator McKenna, who was Minister for Social Services, to the Director-General of his Department, he said:
All unions represented at the conference with me in Sydney on 23 April accepted the principle that the Commonwealth could not permit unemployment benefit to be used for financing strikes.
For the life of me, I cannot see why that principle is now being changed. In Queensland, on 25 February 1948, Prime Minister Chifley said:

In connection with the payment of unemployment benefit to persons involved in or affected by the present Queensland industrial dispute, the Social Services Consolidation Act provides that benefit is not payable to an applicant whose unemployment is due to him being a direct participant in a strike.

In relation to other persons involved in or affected by an industrial dispute, the Minister for Social Services has issued instructions which are being observed by the Department of Social Services in Queensland at present and throughout the Commonwealth. These instructions are the outcome of a full consideration of the relevant parts of the Act of a Cabinet sub-committee in early 1947.

In brief, the instructions embody the following principles: In respect of unions on strike and unions sponsoring a strike of its members in key positions, members of these unions whether directly participating in the strike, or unemployed as a direct or indirect consequence of the strike are not to be regarded as eligible to receive unemployment benefits.
In respect of unions not on strike, or apparently having no members on strike members of these unions are to be regarded as eligible to receive unemployment benefits.
Finally, he said:
A person is not to be disqualified for unemployment benefit by reason only of his refusal to undertake work available through a strike or lockout.
I do not think those principles have been disputed by Federal Labor Governments until now. I think it was in 1979 that Senator Grimes then in opposition said:
I am not in favour of paying unemployment benefits to people who are on strike.
At the same time, Senator Cavanagh stated:
The Opposition has never supported the payment of unemployment benefits to strikers . . .

We are getting to that stage. My philosophy is that strikes should not be financed directly or indirectly by money allotted for social security benefits. We have to remember that it is taxpayers' money. If we have any money to spare, let it go to the truly needy, not those who choose to make themselves needy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak but briefly on some aspects of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. From the outset, I acknowledge that certain parts of the Bill are commendable, but I think it is the role of the Opposition to point out to the Government and to the people at large those features which raise community problems. It is on those areas that I propose to address my remarks. Before doing so, I wish to correct a number of inaccuracies in the remarks of a previous speaker, a member of the Australian Democrats. As late as yesterday, the Canberra Times reported remarks by the Leader of the Opposition, Andrew Peacock, when opening the campaign for the Liberal Party in relation to the by-election for the Queensland seat of Moreton.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite Senator Haines's assertion, Mr Peacock is reported as having quite categorically said:
A Federal Liberal Government would reverse the Labor Government's decisions to increase tax on superannuation lump-sum payouts and-
here are the important words-
to impose an asset test on pensions . . .
I think that completely refutes Senator Haines's assertion; we would overturn those two measures on return to government.

My problems in relation to this Bill arise from the amendments to section 107 of the Social Security Act. These relate to the payment of the unemployment benefit to certain categories of people who are on strike and who have been affected by strikes. I think the silent majority in the community needs to be satisfied by the answer to this question: Are we creating a situation which will tend to enable strikes to take place a lot easier, with the consequence to the community where a lot of people financially get hurt?

Unfortunately, it is often those other people in the community who are mainly disadvantaged by strike action. In other words, I believe that some union leaders lead their members into strike action for sometimes trivial and unjustifiable causes. Traditionally the strike has been regarded as a weapon of last resort. Unfortunately, a minority of union leaders tend to use their powers and responsibilities recklessly, at great cost to the community. Given this environment in 1979 the Fraser Government introduced a legislation package designed to deal with what we regarded as a growing sophistication, with some sections of the trade union movement arranging strikes and work bans tending to bring about a maximum disruption with minimum of pay loss. I think the emphasis must be on the minimum pay loss. So often the community at large could see little justification in relation to the action by some of these reckless trade union leaders. Quite often that action was contrary to the tenor or consensus of a union's own members, but the members felt obliged to go along with a philosphy of 'follow the leader'.

The community must have a measure of protection; it must have mechanisms which reduce the capacity to strike, particularly for unjustifiable reasons. What the Government is seeking to do now is to reduce the pressure that can be applied by members of other unions who would be affected within that same establishment and by the same members of the striking union in other establishments. I think we do require mechanisms for applying pressure to minimise strike action because the community can no longer afford the cost of problems associated with strikes. The cost to the community is very great. One of the great problems that Australia is facing at this moment is the problem of competition from overseas. We are becoming less competitive than our neighbours. One could well ask what economic activity will sustain the wealth of this community in the future, maintain our high standard of living, if we allow cost increases to permeate throughout the community.

We all know, through the system of centralised wage fixing in Australia, that what is achieved by one group of militant unionists spreads across the community into other industries. We all acknowledge that not all industries have the same ability to pay. Regrettably, what is happening is that the disparity between the industries that have that ability to pay and those that do not is growing at an alarming rate, with the result that there is growing unemployment. It is growing at such a rate because the industries affected are the labour intensive industries and small business. Every cost increase disproportionately harms the small business more than it does the large business, unless that large business is a labour intensive one.
