Therefore, I repeat: We do need these sorts of mechanisms so that strikers within the same establishment or strikers in the same union but outside that establishment can exert pressure, particularly when they feel that the strike is unjustifiable, to try to bring reason to bear in such circumstances.

I mentioned earlier that our whole standard of living is at peril. We have to have the maximum number in the work force to be able to support a growing standard of living. If we are not careful we will see Asian standards rising and in the not too distant future we will see a decline in the standard of living that we have come to enjoy and expect. We have to be concerned about cost competitiveness; we have to be concerned about keeping maximum numbers in employment. I believe that action such as that proposed by the insertion of this provision in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill must ultimately work to the general disadvantage of the community at large. True, some people would have been disadvantaged by the previous legislation but that group has a responsibility to the community at large, and I must say to themselves so far as their future continuity of employment is concerned because we have to recognise that wage increases can be sustained only by increased productivity. Unfortunately, over the years we have tended to lose sight of this important guideline.

Despite the fact that there is hardship, we have to recognise that wives can still receive social security assistance. The overriding point is that the unemployment benefit must not be used to finance union action or to subsidise certainly unjustifiable strike action. My colleague, Senator Townley, quoted members of the Australian Labor Party. When the Labor Party was in opposition, a highly recognised former senator of this place, Senator Cavanagh, said:
The Opposition has never supported the payment of unemployment benefits to strikers . . .
Our colleague across the way, Senator Grimes, said in the same debate:
I am not in favour of paying unemployment benefits to people who are on strike.

So there has been a change in philosophy by some members of the Labor Party. I believe that this change is a retrograde step and the amendments will bring about changes in employment and loss of competitiveness which will be detrimental to the Australian community at a time when it can least afford these changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators from both sides of the Senate who have taken part in this debate. I am pleased that, in the main, they support this social security legislation. The Budget was put together in very difficult economic circumstances and in a time of very great economic restraint. The Government applied to itself disciplines as to the amount of expenditure that could be taken into account in budgetary considerations. Of course, Social Security, being the largest individual expenditure department, had to accept severe restrictions on what we as a party and what we as a government would have liked to do. I therefore think it is of some compliment to us that in fact most people who spoke in this debate did not speak about the legislation at all-I presume because they agree with most of it-but spent inordinate amounts of time talking about matters which are not dealt with in this legislation. For instance, I suppose the best example of that is Senator Walters, who spent most of her time talking about the assets test, which has not been finalised, which has not been introduced into this Parliament yet and which has not been passed by this Parliament. She also spoke about the over-70s income test which was introduced and passed in the May and June session of Parliament, as Senator Haines said, without opposition from the Liberal-National party coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain matters were raised and it is important that we deal with them. In particular it is important that I deal with the matter concerning unemployment benefits paid to unionists, and I will do that shortly. But as I have said, this omnibus legislation deals with many changes which the Government thought were important. It does not go as far as we would have liked to go. But, as I said, we were acting under considerable constraint. In particular, we are pleased with those sections of the legislation which make a start, but only a start, towards restoring justice to those who are unemployed through no fault of their own. I was interested to hear so many Opposition speakers mention this, and mention it in a way that makes one presume that they have just discovered, now that they are in opposition, that there are large numbers of unemployed in this country who-and this applies particularly to single people-have in fact been treated unfairly in the past.

I would like to remind the Senate that the present Opposition, when in government, cut off regular benefit increases to the single unemployed, who compose between 70 per cent and 75 per cent of the jobless in the community. During its term in office the single unemployment benefit in fact dropped from nearly 25 per cent of average weekly earnings after the 1978 changes to the legislation to as low as 17.4 per cent of average weekly earnings just a year ago. One of the first actions of this Government was to increase this benefit in May. In this legislation we are resuming cost of living increases to single unemployed for the first time in five and a half years. We are giving another $2 now and another $2 in May so that the unemployment benefit will reach at least just over 20 per cent of average weekly earnings. We will not allow the value of this benefit to erode. We will in fact continue to increase the benefit until we restore equality again. We, of course, would have liked to restore equity in one hit but in the economic situations which face us such a sudden increase in government expenditure is not possible, nor is it desirable.

Similarly, we have increased the allowances to the children of pensioners, which have remained unchanged for two years despite inflation and despite the numerous reports that pensioner and beneficiary families with children are the most likely to be in poverty. We have made changes in this area. We would have liked to make greater changes, but this is the start of an increased restoration of justice to this group of people.

The introduction of a spouse carer's allowance has been advocated by people on both sides of this Parliament who, as members of parliament, have had to face the unfortunate situation of men who are affected in this way. I have certainly raised this matter in the past and I have been supported in this regard by others. I was pleased to be the Minister who was able to introduce this change. Senator Townley mentioned the remote area allowance. Again, one would have liked to include people whose place of residence is in income tax zone B, and that will be the ultimate aim of this Government. However, we had to take into account the restraints about which I spoke. We have to face the fact that all the reports in the past have shown the increased burden of costs which has to be borne particularly by people in zone A. We thought it was important to make a start. I am sure we have done so to the satisfaction of those people who live in the outlying and difficult areas of Australia.

In general, the payment to single parents needs to be increased. We, like the previous Government, knew that single parents in receipt of unemployment benefits were in deeper poverty even than supporting parents. But nothing was done. We have at least moved to give these people the $8 guardian's allowance, which represents an additional $400 a year. We are amending the legislation to allow adopting single parents to receive the supporting parent's benefit and to give the supporting parent's benefit to a parent who is in institutional care.

I do not wish to go into the arguments about the assets test. That is for debate at another time in this place. I certainly point out to Senator Walters that the introduction of the over-70s income test still leaves that group with a considerably more generous income test than that which applies to other age pensioners. I believe that the hyperbole and rhetoric we heard from Senator Walters about people having to leave their units and accommodation is just not true and is typical of the sort of exaggeration in which she indulges.

The thing that seems to have exercised the minds of those opposite more than anything else is the amendment in clause 30 to section 107 of the parent legislation which in fact seeks to reverse the situation which has arisen since the changes which were made by the previous Government in 1979 and which in fact were resisted by the then Opposition. Senator Watson suggested that what we are seeing is in fact a change in philosophy on this side of the House. In support of that, he quoted what Senator Cavanagh and I said at the time that those changes were made. I point out that our speeches at that time were made in opposition to the changes that were introduced in 1979. Our philosophy has not changed at all. We do not believe that those taking part in industrial action should directly get unemployment benefits. We said that then and we say that now . I point out that at times even that arrangement can be of some considerable difficulty and hardship for people on our side of the House. Senator Watson talked about justifiable and unjustifiable disputes. However, the legislation, if amended, would still exclude those groups which are taking part in industrial disputes whether that industrial action is justified or not.

Clause 30 of this legislation seeks to modify the rule introduced in October 1979 which affects those on unemployment benefits. I repeat that benefits will still not be payable to workers who are on strike; they will still not be payable to workers in the same union who are laid off in the work place because of industrial action by that union in that work place. That was the situation before 1979; it is the situation we wish to reintroduce. This legislation proposes to change the iniquitous situation whereby workers who are indirectly laid off at a factory or a plant as a result of an industrial dispute in another plant which, I might point out, may be miles away or in another State, and who may have no knowledge of the dispute, let alone the cause of it, are refused unemployment benefit. I remind honourable senators that that was only part of the way that the previous Government wanted to go. It also wanted to deprive the wives and children of those who were taking part in industrial disputes of the unemployment benefit or special benefit, for which they would otherwise qualify. The then Government was prevented from doing so by the combined action of the Opposition parties in this place at that time. It is no good Senator Watson getting up and saying: 'Well, their wives will still be able to get unemployment benefits'. Senator Watson was part of a party which tried to deprive those wives of unemployment benefits.

At present members of one union laid off are not paid during an industrial dispute. It may be that the primary dispute is in Sydney and, for Senator Watson 's benefit, the effects of that dispute may be felt in Launceston or in Perth, where the people laid off do not know anything about it; they do not even know that the dispute is on.

They will not be paid; whereas their neighbours who are members of another union will be paid. In particular-this is what it is all about-those who are not in a union at all will be paid. It is this latter situation which is the nub of the whole problem. The provision in the Act is, in fact, a penalty for trade union membership. It turns trade union membership into a personal liability. As such it may be in keeping with the philosophy of those opposite, but it is certainly not in keeping with the philosophy of people on this side of the House . I point out that those who come into this place, as they have done in the past , and with crocodile tears heap praise on those brave and courageous members of the Polish union, Solidarity, and in doing so make pious speeches about the rights of workers to organise being an essential part of our democratic process will, by way of the legislation which they introduced in 1979, penalise those people who are members of trade unions for no other reason than that they are, in fact, members of trade unions. That is not a fair situation; it is not an equitable situation. What is more, it is a misuse of the Social Security Act.

Senator Jessop in his speech correctly pointed out that what we need to do in this country is improve our system of industrial relations; what we need to do is improve industrial relations law. He said that we need to improve the situation so that we have fewer disputes in this community. I put it to the Senate, as I put it in 1979, 1981 and 1982 when we were dealing with legislation such as this, that the wrong way to go about that is to use the social security legislation, which is meant to assist people who are in need, through no fault of their own, as a blunt weapon in industrial relations policy. It is not a sensible use of that legislation. Not only members of the Government have said that in the past in situations in which the application of this Act has arisen.

This situation largely arose out of the disputes which occurred in the Latrobe Valley in, I think, September and October 1977. As a result of a dispute there, a large number of unionists, including members of the unions involved in the Latrobe Valley and in a wide area outside the Latrobe Valley, were thrown out of work. It was at that stage that this sort of application of legislation was mooted. The Government at the time suggested that the unemployment benefit should be denied to all those people outside that area who were affected. I wish to read to honourable senators some of the comments of some of the people who were concerned at that time about the proposed action of the then Government. The first one to speak up was the then Victorian State Minister for Social Welfare, Mr Dixon. As honourable senators know, Mr Dixon was a Liberal member of parliament. He said:
It's stupid to use unemployment benefits as a possible lever in an industrial dispute and such a move would be ill-advised and ill-considered.

At the time the Age reported that Mr Peter Falconer, the then chairman of the former Federal Government's back bench industrial relations committee, had urged the Government to reconsider such proposals because they would affect a large number of rank and file members who would find their benefits cut. The same report stated that the honourable member for Boothby, Mr Steele Hall, had said that the Government was making the innocent do its dirty work for it and that the proposal was unjust. Those remarks were made by Liberal and conservative member of the Government at the time. The Melbourne Herald said:

. . . it would be outrageous to deny sustenance to stood-down unionists and their families not involved in the dispute. The Government should take care that no substance exists for such stories in future.
The Age said:
Unemployment benefits should be regarded as a right for people jobless through no fault of their own. They are not a privilege and they most certainly are not a plaything for politicians.
The Canberra Times called it:
. . . a threat to the right of freedom of opinion, a denial of justice to taxpayers, and a perversion of the conventional definition of what constitutes unemployment.

So it was not only the Opposition at the time, the Labor movement, which was concerned about this situation. Also the conservative members of the Government and supporters of the Government at the time were concerned. It must be remembered that at that time and shortly afterwards there was an unusual industrial situation, certainly in the Latrobe Valley. Equally, it must be remembered that when Mr Chifley and the then Labor Government in 1947 introduced the rules which it introduced we were in incredibly different times compared with present times. It was a time of unheralded industrial disputes. It was a time when certain unions were using key man tactics which they had not done in the past. Certainly, if the changes that the Australian Labor Party wants to introduce to this legislation resulted in the sorts of key man strikes that were in existence in 1947, the trade union movement, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labor Government would recognise that modifications would have to be made. We would monitor the situation to make sure that that did not occur. But that situation does not arise now.

What will continue to happen is that if we have an unusual situation, such as that which occurred in the Latrobe Valley, which was not a key man dispute situation, we will end up with the Government having to fund, through emergency relief funds, the various welfare agencies-wherever the dispute occurs and wherever the people are laid off-to a very great extent and in a far more efficient manner than one could provide assistance through the unemployment benefit. We would end up with the situation which existed during the Latrobe Valley dispute in which the Salvation Army in Victoria had to close its doors because it was no longer able to support people who were unable to support themselves through no fault of their own. That is not the sort of situation which we want to see in this community. It is the sort of situation which will arise if this sort of legislation persists. One should not use the social security legislation in this way. One should look towards improving industrial relations. If Senator Jessop really is fair dinkum about cutting down the number of demarcation disputes, which he talked about during his speech, he should support legislation to assist in the amalgamation of trade unions. That is something which he and his colleagues will never do whenever it is introduced.

Let us have some consistency in the matter, but let us have the social security legislation in such a state that the Department of Social Security can provide assistance for those who need it without the hindrance of the philosophical and ideological hangups of those opposite. It is for this reason that I am surprised that Senator Haines and her colleagues are going along with this move. The sorts of people who will be affected are not the militant trade unionists about whom Senator Watson is worried. If one wants to make militant unionists more militant one uses tactics such as this.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the cost?

—I will come to the costs in a moment. If one wants to make disadvantaged people who are already embittered with our society more embittered , one does things such as this. One deprives them of the sorts of benefits that they should be able to expect when they are out of work through no fault of their own.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should look at the results of a survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics concerning the disputes which have occurred in this country . The figures have been pretty consistent in recent years. The major cause of disputes is found to be the result of managerial policy and physical conditions. These are the important factors in the majority of disputes in this country. Almost 60 per cent of disputes were directly attributed to management and physical conditions, not to malice, frivolity and economic gain about which Senator Watson talked. In excess of 65 per cent of disputes in this country-the figure is now 67 per cent-are of a duration of fewer than two days. Only about 5 .9 per cent of disputes last longer than 10 days. One cannot get unemployment benefits until one has been unemployed for a week. Even then people do not go out and immediately apply for the unemployment benefit. We are talking about a very small number of people. This was exemplified when these changes were introduced in 1979 when the Government had no idea how much money would be saved . It admitted that the amount of money was miniscule in the overall Budget and certainly in the Social Security budget.

We are talking about fairness. We are talking about, as the Age editorial said at the time, the rights of people who are out of work through no fault or action of their own to receive some support from our social security system. The sorts of people we are talking about are the people on low incomes. We are talking about people such as new migrants who have just arrived in this country, who, in some cases, are still getting in the region of $200 or less a week, who have been laid off in Adelaide or Melbourne as a result of some dispute in Sydney and who will find themselves without support and without any income. There are not many of them because there are not many disputes of this type. But the Opposition, because of its hang-up, will pick these people out. They are the sorts of people who work in the textile mills, I suggest in many cases, in the home town of Senator Watson and me. We will say to them: 'You must suffer in that situation not because of the Government but because the Opposition parties have the philosophical belief that, if you are a member of a trade union movement, whatever that trade union movement does anywhere in Australia, you are collectively responsible'. We think that is unfair and unjust. We are heartened by the fact that, at least in the past, we have been supported by conservative members of this Parliament and conservative newspapers of this country.

I believe that members of the Opposition parties, including the Australian Democrats, should go away and think about this matter. We accept that the numbers in this place seem to be such that this amendment will get through, although I expect Senator Harradine, who is a trade unionist, will support the Government. We expect it will get through; we expect this legislation will be amended in this place. I merely state now that we will not do what the previous Government did. We will not stand up in this place and say: 'We will not accept your amendment and therefore the unemployment beneficiaries in this case and the children of pensioners in this case won't receive their increases'. We will accept the realities of the situation. We will ensure that the other parts of this legislation will get through in time for the very real benefits which are provided for people to be passed on to them in this Budget as they were promised .

Senator Messner raised one other matter with which I will deal briefly. He raised some concern about the authority which is on the bottom of the income form which is used to review the situation of those over 70 years of age on the introduction of the over-70s means test. This authorisation states:
I authorise the Department of Social Security to make such inquiries as may be necessary to establish my entitlement to the pension, benefit or allowance.

I know Senator Messner is new to this area and has just discovered this authorisation, but he tried to draw from it that this was, somehow, some mysterious and sinister declaration on this income test form which had something to do with an assets test which had not been introduced then and has not been introduced now. I point out to him that this authorisation with very similar wording, depending on the nature of the benefit, has been on the bottom of these forms for years. It was on the bottom of the forms released by the previous Government. It is really needed to facilitate the information gathering of those who are assessing these people to facilitate oral inquiries about a person's circumstances and to establish an entitlement to a pension. This may be necessary during the interview stage. In fact, it has always been on the form in some form or another; it is there now. There is nothing sinister about it. It has nothing to do with the assets test. It is a standard part of the form.

I think Senator Messner, before raising questions like this and before making suggestions that this authority has some sinister motive, really ought to check up and see what has gone on in the past, see how the Department of Social Security operates and see whether we cannot make sure that we do as little as we can not to disturb people, particularly those over 70, but all pensioners and beneficiaries in the country, as we make inevitable changes to the social security system if we are going to have a progressive, sensible and rational system. I realise I can do nothing about people like Senator Walters who wander around old people's homes and try to scare the hell out of people over the introduction of the assets test or the incomes test. That is the way she operates. Thank heavens that is not the way everyone in this place operates.

Finally, it must be of considerable satisfaction to my colleague Senator Gietzelt that the only comments made about the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill were comments of praise. I gather that the Opposition parties will support that legislation.

I briefly bring up the matter raised by Senator Jessop who, as did so many speakers in this debate, brought up matters which were not relevant to the debate at all. He complained about the royal commission which was established to inquire into the effects of herbicides and other chemicals on those who suffered in Vietnam. I point out to Senator Jessop and others that for years we, in opposition, advocated an independent judicial inquiry into what happened to Vietnam veterans and, in particular, as to whether they had been affected by the use of defoliants, herbicides and other chemicals in Vietnam. We did that for several reasons. The first reason was that there was a very real concern amongst Vietnam veterans that something had happened to them that may have affected them and that may affect their wives and the children that they produce in the future . Secondly, they were not satisfied with the way that not only the Government but also some ex-servicemen's organisations had ignored their plight for many years. They were anxious that they received justice through an injury which they saw as independent and as separate from government and an inquiry which provided , they hoped, whether it does or not, some of the answers which they and their colleagues had sought over many years. It was for these reasons that we promised such an inquiry.

I think it is incredible that Senator Jessop should come in here one day and condemn us for all sorts of things that we were supposed to have promised and not done and then condemn us for conducting an inquiry that we said for years we would institute and to suggest to Vietnam veterans that the $5m or $7m that Senator Jessop thinks that inquiry will cost is not justified and is a waste of the taxpayers' money. Senator Jessop is a member of a party and was a member of the Parliament at the time that was willing to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on sending people to Vietnam, raining on that country bombs and napalm and everything else that was used, and sending people to that country who were conscripted into the armed Services. It is extraordinary for the honourable senator with that background to come into this place and state that we cannot spend $5m or $6m in an attempt to bring justice to and to ease the anxiety of those who served there. I thank the Senate for its prompt treatment of this legislation. I am sorry that the Opposition parties feel they cannot support the social security legislation in toto.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 17, clause 30, sub-clauses (2) and (3), lines 30 to 43, leave out the sub- clauses.

Sub-clauses 30 (2) and (3) seek to amend section 107 of the Social Security Act . As has been discussed during this debate, the section that is now part of the legislation was first introduced by the Fraser Government, I think in October 1979. Its purpose was to establish the principle that unemployment benefit would not be paid to those persons stood down in the event of a strike occurring somewhere other than the work place of individuals, which position had not been covered in previous legislation. The principle is quite clear. The Government at that time did not see its role as that of paying strike benefits to those who chose by their own actions to take industrial action which led to the stand down of others. Consequently they were insulated from the effects of the industrial action as a whole. The principle which the Government at that time established was that members of a union, in a total situation such as those people found themselves in, ought be responsible for the actions of their colleagues. Consequently that clause became part of the law.

I think Senator Watson, in the course of his remarks during the second reading debate, clearly set out the argument on behalf of the Opposition. I would just like to summarise that briefly. The situation is that in the last several years there has been a growing sophistication-I think as Senator Watson put it-on the part of the trade union movement to use its union muscle in respect of capital intensive-type industries. I think the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) himself acknowledged the La Trobe Valley strike in 1977-78 as one of the key issues which had very significant effects in the community and, of course, on the economy but which were brought into being by virtue of the industrial action of a very few. I think the Minister's example of the La Trobe Valley strike is a most pertinent one insofar as it brings our attention to the actions of some, I think, 300 electricians in the power station at that time who brought to a dead halt virtually half of Victorian industry. As a result there were some very widespread stand downs throughout the whole industrial process. For that reason it was judged very important to ensure that there was collective responsibility on the part of the work force throughout the Victorian community for the actions of a very militant few. As a result the Government saw fit to take the action that it did.

I think Senator Watson drew our attention very cogently to the point that this kind of action which flows through the centralised wage system does not just have its effect on that group of workers or even those who are indirectly affected by it but indeed right across the whole industrial structure. It is that which of course is our greatest concern, because those effects are ones which flow into the economy as a whole; which do lead to a lack of competitiveness in our industry; which do put firms, that are unable to pay the increased price of labour, out of business; which do lead to the destruction of jobs; and which do lower the possibility of people being re-employed.

For those reasons we find it very rational on the part of the Opposition to pursue its amendment to these clauses and we intend to do so. We are very grateful for the support of the Australian Democrats, as they have announced publicly, I understand, in the last 24 hours that they will be supporting our amendment. It is an issue of very great concern. It is an issue of great depth of principle in terms of our understanding of the kind of industrial society in which we live. It is the sort of collective responsibility which we are seeking in this community rather than the selective responsibility which the Government, with its union supporters, is seeking. I think that distinction has to be drawn right home because it is obviously an attempt to face the political pressures within the trade union movement which from time to time inevitably surface within the Caucus and within the Government.

The Minister, in his remarks, did quote some statements, I believe, from people such as Mr Peter Falconer, who was the member for Casey in Victoria and who was reported as being opposed to the amendments of the Fraser Government in 1977 and 1978. I think the Minister made the point that Mr Falconer had referred to the large numbers of rank and file people who would be affected by this legislation. The inference of course from that was that there would be hardship brought to bear on the part of those rank and file members who would be stood down in the event of industrial action and therefore not able to obtain unemployment benefit . I make the point that there is provision in the social security legislation as it stands, as it stood in 1977 and 1978 and before that time, for the provision of special benefits in the situation in which these people find themselves. I ask the Minister whether that legislation does apply and whether the guidelines presently do provide for the provision of benefits for people who find themselves in those extremely difficult circumstances. I hope that the law and the guidelines which did apply during the time of the Fraser Government have not been changed by this Government and that indeed they do still provide for that circumstance.

I believe that quotations by my colleagues-I think Senator Townley and Senator Jessop-from remarks made by Mr Chifley as Prime Minister of Australia in 1947 opposing this kind of benefit for those stood down in the circumstances which we are addressing, are most pertinent. I will not seek to incorporate them in my speech, but I believe that they are highly relevant and I commend to people that they read those remarks by that very esteemed Labor Prime Minister.

The other point that I think does need to be emphasised, which the Minister made some play of in his remarks, is the fact that 67 per cent of strikes these days are of less than two days' duration. He mentioned another figure which I cannot recall in respect of strikes of less than 10 days' duration. The point that he was seeking to make was that a very small number of strikes were of very lengthy duration. He speaks on the one hand of strikes, but he ignores the point about the effect of strikes on the rest of the economy. Even though there may be a shut down for a relatively short period, let us say in a capital intensive industry that may be producing electricity, the long term effect on the rest of industry would be magnified and multiplied as it goes down the production chain.

I would just like to exemplify this case. Let us say that an electricity strike occurs for up to six or eight days. An industry, such as a motor vehicle manufacturing plant which depends upon that electricity for the operation of its production line, would be required almost immediately to stand down its workers but would find it needed to close down not only its production line but also its foundry, its smelters and other parts of its operation.

So we would see an enormous lag in restarting that industry in the event of the immediate switch-on of electricity. It is that kind of lag effect, which has a very significant impact on industry, which the Minister totally ignored in the quotation, in a glib fashion, of mere statistics about numbers of strike days. We speak here not of the strikers themselves, but of the effect on industry and on Australians in their ordinary day to day circumstances of union activity and militant industrial action. For that reason, the Opposition will oppose the amendment to section 107. I commend the Opposition amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly support in particular the latter remarks made by my colleague Senator Messner, and I will concentrate particularly on his latter comments. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), in his summing-up of the second reading debate, made reference to statistics proposed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on the duration of strike activity, which showed that by far the greater number of strikes are of relatively short duration. Therefore, because of the lag in the payment of unemployment benefit, the legislation would not normally affect people involved in these short term strikes. But what concerns me is the need for some sort of mechanism, particularly to curtail in the longer term strikes, which are a great cost to the whole community. True, there is a cost to the strikers themselves, which I acknowledge. There are different sorts of strikes. In some cases strike action must be regarded as last resort action. Some strikes are justifiable but there are many which are unjustifiable. There needs to be a collective responsibility within that union movement, certainly in the event of the long strikes, when there is a great cost to the community, and some internal mechanism or pressure to expedite the cessation of strike action. Australia is no longer in a position to be brought to its knees as a result of irresponsible action. Our competitiveness in industry is at stake. Our future standard of living is at stake. I believe that there is a responsibility to the community at large because it is the silent majority that pays the greatest price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I regret that I was unable to participate in the second reading debate. There are a number of things that I would have liked to mention, including matters relating to the spouse rebate and family allowances. I know that if I attempted to do so now, you would rule me out of order, quite justifiably. Having said that, I want to enter the debate at this stage. There appears to be concern expressed about the need for responsibility to be taken in respect of industrial dispute situations. That is a concern which I have had over 22 years, I suppose, and more particularly in the 18 years that I have been directly involved as a trade union official. As Secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labor Council I fought for and obtained, amongst the affiliates of the TTLC, an understanding and an undertaking with respect to the conduct and control of industrial disputes. Industrial disputes should be conducted not only in the interests of those particularly concerned but also in the general interests of the whole of the trade union movement of the community. That was the fundamental reason why there was a considerable dispute in the Tasmanian trade union movement over this very issue of the conduct and control of industrial disputes.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I believe it inappropriate to attempt to use the social security system to impose some sort of alleged responsibility on the conduct and control of industrial disputes, to take away from the persons who are affected by industrial disputes their rights under the social security legislation up until 1979 when, of course, the Government of that day, the Fraser Government, amended that legislation. I would have thought that those who oppose the current Government's move to delete the Fraser Government's provisions would have been able to point to examples of how the Fraser Government's amendments to the social security legislation have imposed some responsibility in the conduct and control of industrial disputes; how the withdrawal of unemployment benefit has been a factor in the resolution of disputes. Not one such example has been given by those who are opposing the Government's move to take out of the social security legislation the Fraser Government amendment.

I believe that the opposition to this current government measure is based on an inadequate understanding of the structure of the trade union movement and an inadequate appreciation of the fact that in the last 30 years, since the Chifley era, the nature of Australian industry has changed. It has become more complex and more interwoven. To give an example, I believe that any person from the State of Tasmania should think twice about voting for the Opposition's amendment . I say that advisedly because we could have disputes-and very often they do occur-on the mainland, in Melbourne for example, which have dramatic effects on Tasmania. A branch of a particular union in Tasmania, the union which is involved in the dispute in Victoria, may be very much against that dispute and in general the Federal executive of that particular union may in fact have views diverse from those of the branch of the union in Victoria. Under the proposal by the Opposition, we will penalise those members of that union in Tasmania. I cannot see any reason to use the social security system to do that. We will not only penalise them but also penalise their wives and children. Very often this is the case. I think it is necessary to appreciate that. I sympathise with the attitudes that have been expressed by a number of members of the Opposition- Senator Townley, Senator Watson, and Senator Messner, leading for the Opposition -but I point out to them that it is not appropriate to use the provisions of the social security legislation to impose some sort of internal responsibility within the trade union movement.

I think the thrust of the actions by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is to face the trade union movement with the need to accept its responsibilities. I believe that the measure being undertaken by the Government is consistent with the Prime Minister's general thrust. I urge the Committee to adopt this measure and to reject the Opposition's amendment. If there is a failure at some future date and an undermining of the contract by certain elements within the trade union movement directed from outside the trade union movement, we should face that situation then. The Prime Minister may well have to face the situation at that stage. But, in the meantime, I believe that, consistent with the compact that has been entered into between the trade union movement and the Government, we ought to adopt the measure that is proposed by the Government and reject the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again state that I reject the Opposition's amendment. I now have a further reason for rejecting it, apart from the reasons that were given in the second reading speech and the reasons given quite clearly by Senator Harradine. Senator Messner -this became evident in his speech at the Committee stage-is clearly under a misapprehension. The legislation at the moment, as introduced in 1979, precludes from receiving unemployment benefit members of a union who are taking part in a dispute, members of the same union in the same establishment-we on this side of the chamber have no objection to that-and also, under section 107 (4) of the legislation, members of the same union who are laid off, wherever they are laid off, as a result of that dispute no matter how justified or unjustified that dispute is. Senator Harradine gave the same example I gave of a dispute in Melbourne or Sydney which results in people being laid off in Tasmania. Those people in Tasmania who are laid off, although they are members of the same union , know nothing about the dispute. Considering the way in which the trade union movement is organised, they may well disagree very strongly with that dispute. If Senator Messner looks at section 124 (2) of the Social Security Act-again, this was part of the 1979 provisions-he will find that it states:

SPEECH.PARA: A special benefit is not payable to a person in respect of a period if the person is not qualified to receive an unemployment benefit in respect of that period by reason of sub-section 107 (4).

They do not qualify for a special benefit and they are precluded even from receiving that benefit which has rigid and firm guidelines. That is a very severe penalty. That is using the Social Security Act to deprive people who, through no fault of their own, are out of work. They may be out of work by the actions of others, with whom they do not agree at all, on the grounds that they must have some collective responsibility throughout the whole of Australia. The principle I spoke about in 1979, 1980, 1981 and 1982 was essentially the same sort of thing that Senator Jessop and Senator Harradine spoke about today. There are ways to improve industrial relations in this country. There are ways to improve the behaviour of irresponsible unions in this country.

I suggest that to use the Social Security Act to deprive people of benefits they would otherwise be entitled to is using a sledge hammer to get at this problem. No evidence has been produced since 1979 to demonstrate that this legislation had any action. The Government of the day was incapable of producing any figures to demonstrate what effect it thought it would have on the social security budget or the system of legislation that existed. I put it to the Opposition that by taking this action it will make militants more militant and it will make embittered people even more embittered. It will not help the industrial relation situation at all. I think it is most unfortunate that because of some philosophical and ideological hang up the Opposition parties are taking this attitude and that they are painting this Government as being the tool of the trade union movement, the tool of the Australian Council of Trade Unions or whatever one likes because of the actions it is taking. The Government is suggesting that there is a better approach and that probably the worst approach is to penalise innocent people.

I remind the Opposition that the previous Government-I am sure against the wishes of many of its members-not only wanted to penalise this group of unionists but also attempted to penalise their wives and children. The previous Government was stopped from doing so only by the then Opposition in the Senate. I think that the Opposition parties should reconsider their position in this case. However, if they will not reconsider their position, quite clearly we will not let this Opposition prevent us from introducing other reforms in the legislation. We will proceed to take steps to make sure that that happens. I think that a rethinking of this attitude is needed by those who have taken this stand on this occasion.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Messner's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 18 October 1983, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1983-84 totalling $2,860,169,000. Of this amount, $998,737,000 was authorised by the Supply Act (No. 2) 1983-84; the balance of $1,861,432,000 would be authorised by this Bill.

The Bill provides for proposed expenditure on the construction of public works and buildings, the acquisition of sites and buildings, certain advances and loans, items of plant and equipment which are clearly definable as capital expenditure and expenditure on new policy initiatives for which legislation has not previously been provided. Provision is also made for grants to the States under section 96 of the Constitution and for payments to the Northern Territory.
An amount of $120,000,000 is included under the advance to the Minister for Finance, the same as was provided in the Supply Act (No. 2) 1983-84 which this Bill, when enacted, will subsume.
Details of the proposed expenditures are set out in Schedule 2 to the Bill and the main features were outlined in the Budget Speech.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to appropriate moneys for the service of the Parliamentary Departments for the year ending 30 June 1984.

The Bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1983-84 totalling $35,062,000. Of this amount, $14,008,000 was authorised by the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1983-84, the balance of $21,054,000 being sought in this Bill.

The then Government agreed in March 1982 to the provision of a separate Appropriation Bill for the Parliament which, consistent with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, is not a Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government. It was part of the agreement that detailed executive scrutiny of and control over expenditure estimates for the Parliament was not necessary and that the Government would limit its involvement to approval of the overall levels for recurrent and capital expenditure for the Parliamentary Departments. This has been done and the amounts included in the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 12.47 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the recently announced review of the Government's programs of special services for the disabled. Is the Minister aware of the concern within the community that his proposed least restrictive alternative approach to providing services to the disabled may result in cuts in grants given to organisations presently providing worthwhile services and programs for these people? Is the Minister able to allay or confirm these fears? What response, in his experience, has the announcement of the review prompted?

—Yes, the review which was announced by the Government has created considerable interest. I have not been informed by anybody that the view of this Government, which I believe is a continuation of the view of the previous Government, that it should be looking at the least restrictive alternative in providing services to the disabled has caused any problems for disabled people, particularly in regard to the reduction of funds for existing organisations. The announcement I made was that in the future organisations which applied for funds and organisations which had already applied for funds should look at their applications with a view to seeing whether they are providing for the least restrictive alternative for those whom they seek to serve. In other words they should provide an atmosphere in which disabled people can take part in our society within the limitations of their disabilities. The organisations should also provide services which would enable disabled people to play a full part in society. I do not think that approach is objected to by many people in this Parliament. I think it is an extension of the attitude of the previous Minister. I think advertisements about the review were put in the papers a few weeks ago. There has been a considerable response from organisations and individuals both in print and over the phone. I hope that as a result of those initial responses we will be able to clarify the situation and extend the terms of reference so that all people who feel that they have something to say about the matter can give their views to the Government and then the Government and this Parliament can decide where we will go in the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT: OATH OF ALLEGIANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs because it relates to the Queensland Premier' s criticism of a statement made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Stewart West. In his criticism the Premier chose to attack those senators and members who did not take an oath when elected. Does the Australian Constitution allow senators and members of the House of Representatives to choose whether they will take an oath or make an affirmation of allegiance after they are elected to the Federal Parliament? Is any person who criticises a senator or member for making an affirmation rather than taking an oath holding the Federal Parliament in contempt? If so, can the Premier of Queensland be summoned to this place to be asked to attempt to explain both his criticism of Mr West's statement and his contempt of this Parliament?
—Order! I do not think that the last part of the honourable senator's question should be directed to the Minister, but I will allow the first part of the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the statement of the Premier of Queensland arises from a statement made by Mr West, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, whom I represent in this place. It concerned the possible changes to the Australian Citizenship Act which will be discussed in this Parliament next year although I believe the relevant legislation may be introduced this year so that people can review it. Amongst the suggestions was one that the oath of allegiance and the reference to citizens as British subjects be changed.

ANSWER.PARA: I find it interesting that Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Mr Hodgman, the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, should have criticised this suggestion because the former Liberal- National Party Government realised that although citizenship applications had increased in recent years, in excess of one million people-about 1.2 million people, I believe-who were qualified to become citizens of this country still had not applied to do so. As a result, the previous Government took what I think was a reasonable attitude, an attitude that this Government takes for which it is sometimes criticised. The previous Government held a series of conventions or gatherings around the country to which people came to talk about citizenship, what should happen when one becomes a citizen and why one should become a citizen. Two important aspects which came up repeatedly at the citizenship conventions were the lack of Australian character in the oath of allegiance and the reference to Australians as British subjects. As a result, this Government, like the previous Government, will be looking at this matter in the future. As everyone in this place knows, people who become members of parliament or people who give evidence in a court have a choice of taking an oath or making an affirmation. People on both sides of this Parliament, in all parties in this Parliament-

TALK.START.PARA: —And of all faiths.

—And of all faiths, as Senator Tate says, variously take an oath or make an affirmation. I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. We had people of all religious denominations giving evidence before us. In fact ministers and priests of various religions have preferred to make an affirmation. I think, therefore, that Mr Bjelke-Petersen's attempt to criticise this effort to make the act of becoming a citizen of this country more relevant to all of those who live in this country, an effort to make sure that the oath taken or affirmation made at the time of citizenship is a meaningful one, has been done for political purposes which have been brought into operation because of the Queensland election. I think it is unfortunate. If we are to become a united country which has a proper sense of nationalism we have to get together and work out a situation whereby everyone who is a citizen in this country recognises what has happened. I do not know whether Mr Bjelke-Petersen can be called before this Parliament. Personally I do not think he should be, because I think we should recognise his acts as party political stunts indulged in during an election campaign.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the revelation of the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, that the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia has advised that it can be expected that Mr Dawkins's family's company, Coomel Pty Ltd, will be relieved of any recoupment tax liability arising from its shareholding in Metro Industries Ltd? Is the Minister aware that many Western Australian shareholders in public companies such as Metro Industries and Westwools Holdings Ltd have received notice of liability under the recoupment legislation? Can the Minister assure the Senate that no special treatment has been provided for the company in which Mr Dawkins has an interest and that all taxpayers in similar circumstances can expect the same treatment from the Australian Taxation Office?

—As I understand the situation-I will have this checked subsequently-the Coomel company had shares in Metro Industries. Metro Industries subsequently sank to the bottom of the harbour through the principal agency of Denis Horgan, the then chairman of the Liberal Party Finance Committee. Metro Industries incurred a tax liability under last year's unpaid company tax recoupment legislation. Therefore, those shareholders in Metro Industries incurred a portion of that tax liability unless either they gained, in the opinion of the Commissioner, no financial benefit from the sale-that is, their shares were not sold at prices above true market value and at prices which reflected the fact that it had always been intended that company tax due would be evaded-or the liability of the individual was below a threshold level. As I understand it, the Coomel company with which Mr Dawkins was associated does not qualify for liability on either of those grounds.
—Oh!
—Senator Chaney apparently does not accept that explanation, but that is my understanding of the situation. I will have it checked.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to the questions asked of the Minister which, as usual, he did not choose to answer. I ask him again whether he is aware that many Western Australian shareholders in public companies such as Metro Industries and Westwools have received notice of liability under the recoupment legislation. Can he assure the Senate-I would have thought this could be done without any difficulty if this were an honest Government-that no special treatment has been provided for the company in which Mr Dawkins has an interest and that all taxpayers in similar circumstances will get the same treatment from the Taxation Office?

—I am sorry if I did not answer that section of Senator Chaney's question. It was not my intention not to answer it. Of course I can give such an assurance. The Westwools shareholders who are contesting the action will not be responsible-provided they can demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Commissioner that they did not derive a financial benefit because the sale price that they received for their shares was not inflated by the tax which had been evaded and which it had been planned to evade. Those matters, of course, are ultimately matters for decision by the Commissioner. They are decided at the discretion of the Commissioner, not at the direction of the Treasurer. I am sure that Senator Chaney appreciates that the legislation is so worded.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Northern Tasmania does not have a public broadcasting FM station. Proposals to establish an FM station have been lodged with the Department of Communications for five years. What progress is being made in the processing of these proposals? Why has there been such a long delay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have all the details of FM stations at my fingertips, but Senator Hearn was kind enough to indicate that she would be asking this question. The Department of Communications is aware of several groups in the northern parts of Tasmania which are interested in the establishment of public broadcasting stations. Two planning proposals for public broadcasting stations in Launceston have been received by the Department. The Launceston proposals have been subject to considerable delay in the past caused, in part, by the planning backlog in the Department, but due also to protracted negotiations involving parliamentary representatives for the area on the question of whether to proceed with the proposal for one or two stations.

ANSWER.PARA: These proposals are now in the final stages of processing by the Department. It is expected that recommendations concerning the establishment of public broadcasting stations in Launceston will be put to the Minister very shortly. Interest in the establishment of stations to serve other areas in northern Tasmania has also been expressed recently.

I add to that formal answer provided by the Minister the information, of which the honourable senator will no doubt be aware, that in the recent Budget the Government made an appropriation to the Department of Communications for the speeding up of the processing of the backlog of applications for licences. I believe that that is already having some effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of my immediate predecessor, Sir Harold Young, and his wife, Margaret. On behalf of all honourable senators I convey to Sir Harold and Lady Young a warm and friendly welcome upon their return to Canberra.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy a question concerning uranium. I preface my question by quoting from page 134 of the 1982 platform of the Australian Labor Party:

QUESTION.PARA: a declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;
b repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor Government to the mining . . . of . . . uranium; and
c not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium pursuant to agreements entered into contrary to ALP policy.
On page 135 of the platform, it states:
. . . our minimum position would be a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry . . .
In what manner does the Hawke Government intend to implement this policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp used words from the Labor Party platform such as ' moratorium on mining' and 'repudiation of contracts'. He then quoted from the next page of the document. I do not have it in front of me now and I do not know it by heart, but I am reasonably familiar with it. There are, however, other sections in that platform-a fact of which I am sure Senator Chipp is well aware- which many people would see as being somewhat inconsistent with that section. There would be little dispute about that statement. I would be quite safe from criticism, even from within the Labor Party or outside it, in saying that there is significant scope for differing interpretations of what is written in the Labor Party platform on this matter.
—An understatement.

—Senator Button has suggested that I may have understated the degree of that scope for differing interpretations. Substantially because of that fact, the Government has spent considerable time in addressing itself to this question and in finally making a decision-within the parliamentary Labor Party, that is-as to precisely how that platform will be implemented.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chipp would know, I think, that it was anticipated that the matter would be discussed by Cabinet this week. Unfortunately, that could not happen because of the illness of the Prime Minister. I now expect that it will be discussed by Cabinet next week and by the whole parliamentary Party in the next sitting week, which is the week after next.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and concede that there are, to use his term, contradictions in the policy. I anticipated his answer. On page 136 of the ALP platform there is the so-called Roxby Downs amendment which states that a Labor government will:

QUESTION.PARA: consider applications for the export of uranium mined incidentally to the mining of other minerals . . .

I rely on the Concise Oxford Dictionary which defines 'incidental' as 'casual', 'not essential', 'following as a subordinate event'. Is it not the case that the Roxby Downs venturers have made it clear that the uranium deposit-the single largest uranium deposit in the world-is absolutely essential to the viability of the Roxby Downs project? Is it not the case then that the Roxby Downs venture is in fact in contravention of stated and printed ALP policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp's supplementary question probably began to canvass a new issue as well, but I will respond to it too. I do not mind that. The definition or application of the word 'incidental' in the platform is one of the many matters which, in the view of the Government, are open to differing degrees of interpretation. I cannot recall the definition which Senator Chipp gave from the Concise Oxford Dictionary. A possible view is that 'incidental' means anything less than half. That is a view that some people might hold. I do not know whether that is entirely consistent with the definition given in the Oxford Dictionary, but many definitions from that dictionary are quoted. For example, if I remember correctly 'nice' is defined as fastidious, which is somewhat at variance with the common usage of the word. So common usage and dictionary definitions are not infrequently at variance, and one defensible definition in my view of 'incidental' is anything that is less than half. That is the case with Roxby Downs at current mineral prices.
—Are you saying uranium is less than half of the Roxby Downs project?
—Order! Senator Chipp, you have asked your supplementary question.

—With your indulgence, Mr President, I am willing to respond to the interjection. According to the draft mining proposal which the company submitted and the levels of production contained in that proposal, at present mineral prices about 40 per cent of the proposed value of production is uranium. I think that figure is somewhat greater as a percentage of the ore body in total but in the draft mining proposal which the company submitted it is significantly less than half. There is a very substantial quantitative difference between Roxby Downs and any other prospective uranium mine. Again I am quoting from memory and I do not want to be held rigidly to these figures, although they are reliable indicators of the order of magnitude of the minerals to be found at Roxby Downs. Although it is common for uranium to be found in association with other minerals with commercial value, in no other prospective uranium mine in Australia is the non-uranium content worth more than about 5 per cent of the value of the ore body or the value of the proposed output.

ANSWER.PARA: If I remember the final part of Senator Chipp's question correctly, he asked whether I was saying that without the ability to sell the uranium component of the Roxby Downs ore body at something like the prices at which Australian uranium is presently being sold the project was likely to be non-viable. I understand that it is the case that at present prices for the other metals in the Roxby Downs ore body-copper, gold and silver-the project is likely to be non -viable unless the uranium component of the ore body can be sold at somewhere near the current price. Ultimately, that matter will not be a matter for judgment by the Government; the companies concerned will have to decide whether the project is to proceed and whether it is commercially viable with or without the sale of the uranium component of the ore body. In making such a judgment the companies will also be making judgments about the future level of prices for the other minerals contained in the ore body.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What liability, if any, under the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill will be incurred by a person who has received an assessment under the 1982 unpaid company tax legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bearing in mind the very minor possible threshold level of tax liability below which the Commissioner of Taxation will not issue an assessment, the answer to Senator Coleman's question is that everybody who received an assessment under last year's legislation will receive an assessment if the present Government's policy is enacted. Last year's legislation sought to recover from shareholders who benefited from the situation that previously existed. This has relevance to Senator Chaney's earlier question.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question obviously relates to the legislation which is on the Notice Paper and which is to be discussed, we hope, later today. I believe that under standing order 99 the question is out of order.
—Order! There is no point of order. The question was asked in respect of earlier legislation.

—Last year's legislation sought to recover from shareholders who benefited from it company and Division 7 tax evaded by the sale of companies or shares by what became known as wet Slutzkins or bottom of the harbour schemes. The Government's policy is that the personal tax evaded by the beneficiaries of those schemes, whether directly or indirectly, should also be recovered.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I again raise a point of order. According to the program, legislation will be discussed this afternoon which touches on the matters which are the subject of this question and which are now being dealt with by the Minister in his answer. Again I draw your attention to standing order 99, which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions shall not anticipate discussion upon an Order of the Day or other matter which appears on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think general practice is that questions of the type asked by Senator Coleman are allowed and provided a simple answer is given by the Minister to the question there is no difficulty about it. I urge the Minister to observe standing order 100 and not to consider debating the answer but to give a simple reply to the question asked by Senator Coleman.
—Thank you, Mr President. I was talking about wet Slutzkins. Wet Slutzkins are the schemes of which the former Prime Minister said last year:

ANSWER.PARA: In a real sense, the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds , whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers it doesn't matter very much.
He also said:
I do not believe anyone could have taken part without knowing they were wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the Minister is still debating the matter. I suggest he confine his remarks to the simple question asked by Senator Coleman.

—I am endeavouring to do that, Mr President, and I am about to conclude. The former Prime Minister, in his reference to anyone taking part, was clearly referring to those directors who arranged for the sale of companies under schemes which ultimately were to become known as wet Slutzkin schemes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It deals with the same subject as that raised by Senator Chaney. I ask: Can persons receiving notices of liability or assessments under the tax recoupment legislation expect the same immediate attention to their inquiries as was given to the liquidator of Coomel Pty Ltd, who wrote to the Commissioner of Taxation seeking advice on 17 October and received a written reply on the same day?

—I presume that in asking that question Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has in mind the position of a colleague of hers, a fellow Opposition front bencher, Mr John Colinton Moore, who it was revealed last night had a vested interest in seeing the defeat of legislation which was before the Parliament last year and earlier this year, a vested interest which was not disclosed and was unknown to the public until last night. The public record shows that Mr Moore, along with Mr W. J. Wilde, now a member of the staff of Coopers and Lybrand, formerly--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has been asked a perfectly straightforward and simple question about the equality of treatment of taxpayers. He is replying by canvassing matters which have nothing to do with the question. He is at least debating the question but in my view he is simply being abusive in his usual manner. I ask that you call him to order and ask that he either answer the question or say that he cannot.

—On the point of order, Mr President, I do not want to interfere with the substantive issues being raised by both the Liberal and Labor Parties about certain people allegedly in trouble but I say, with great respect to you and with great respect to Senator Chaney and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, that you have a duty to protect public servants in this matter. Some questions asked from both sides of the House today come very close to impugning the reputations of public servants, who are not in a position to defend themselves. I ask you to have regard to their reputations.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is the Chair's responsibility to see that the Standing Orders are adhered to. In that regard, the Chair is carrying out its responsibilities. I draw the attention of honourable senators, and particularly Ministers, to a statement that was made in the Senate in 1973 by the then President, Sir Magnus Cormack, who said:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Minister cannot be required to answer a question but if he does, the Minister should confine himself to points contained in the question with such explanation only as will render the answer intelligible. In all cases an answer must be relevant to the question.
I draw that to the attention of the Minister in regard to his reply to the question asked by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I call the Minister representing the Minister for Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. The central purpose of the question related to the equality of treatment of taxpayers. Yes, I can guarantee that the present Minister for Finance will be treated with the same equality by the Commonwealth bureaucracy, at least to the extent that it is within the Government's ability to control the Commonwealth bureaucracy-and I say that because the Commissioner of Taxation has quite significant discretionary and statutory powers. Both the Minister for Finance and the shadow Minister for Finance will be treated the same. The financial affairs of the Minister for Finance have been a matter of some fascination to the Liberal Party, although there has been a misinterpretation of those financial affairs in recent days. I believe that in order to give a satisfactory answer-

—I take a point of order. Mr President, the question is not related to the Minister for Finance in the way that the answer is suggesting. It related to the treatment of other taxpayers who might receive assessments. I believe the answer is not relevant to the question.
—There is no point of order. I call the Minister.

—I realise, Mr President, that I may not have the expertise in these matters that Senator Chaney has, Senator Chaney having been an active partner of the firm Northmore Hale Davy and Leake in 1973 at the time that that firm set up the first tax evasion scheme for Christo Moll.
—Order! I ask the Minister to relate his remarks to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question.
—I am about to do that, Mr President. The question of whether Senator Chaney was personally involved in devising the scheme is a matter for conjecture--
—Order! I ask the Minister to relate his remarks to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question or I will have to ask him to resume his seat.

—Very well, Mr President. The question concerned equality of treatment of taxpayers by the Government. I can guarantee the Senate that if the shadow Minister for Finance seeks from the Commissioner or the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation a statement about his financial affairs, and bearing in mind that there are discretionary powers in the hands of the Commissioner and the Deputy Commissioner, the Government will do everything it possibly can to see that the shadow Minister receives the same attention as the Minister did. The affairs of the shadow Minister, so it was disclosed or partially disclosed in the House of Representatives last night, are those upon which an opinion from the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner might well be sought. For example, on 31 March 1978, along with Mr W. J. Wilde, now of Coopers and Lybrand, who was then I understand Mr Moore's accountant--
—Order! I think the Minister is now going beyond standing order 100. I ask him to bring his remarks to a conclusion.
—I table documents and summaries of documents relating to the financial affairs of the shadow Minister for Finance and conclude my answer with that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIES ASSISTANCE COMMISSION: DRAFT REPORT ON THE SUGAR INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen statements by the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Ahern, dated 12 October 1983, alleging that the Federal Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, supported the recent draft report of the Industries Assistance Commission on the sugar industry? Did Mr Ahern's allegations accurately represent the Government's position on this matter or are they merely baseless political accusations calculated, without substance, to cause concern to the sugar industry in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was inevitable when the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on the sugar industry was released some weeks ago that it would become a matter of public comment in relation to the Queensland election. It is my understanding that Mr Ahern, the Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland and putative leader of the National Party in Queensland at some future time if events go according to some plans, did allege that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin-
—Not a bad lad.
—At least he is a lad, Senator Chipp. That is something he has going for him.
—What is that supposed to mean?

—Senator Chipp can answer his back bencher's question. But Mr Ahern certainly did make some allegations about Mr Kerin in relation to alleged support of the draft report of the IAC on the sugar industry. I have no doubt that this allegation was made in the context of the current election campaign in Queensland with a view to damaging the prospects of the Australian Labor Party. Mr Ahern knew that his allegations were false but he continued to make them. It is my responsibility, I suppose, to inform the Senate that Mr Ahern has finally agreed that he knew the allegations were false. He has been smitten with a bout of honesty. He has retracted the allegations he made against the Federal Mininister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin.
