He has even taken the somewhat pathetic way out of saying that the allegations were attributable to his staff and not to him. Not only did Mr Ahern, as the Minster in Queensland, retract the remarks he had made about the Federal Minister but also he sent Mr Kerin a telegram on this matter. I would like to refer the Senate to the contents of that telegram from Mr Ahern to Mr Kerin. It stated:

ANSWER.PARA: The statement which was issued was issued by my staff and was not personally seen by me prior to its release, although there is a standing instruction that all Press releases be vetted before release.

I am aware that you have personally expressed views which are highly critical of the IAC report on the sugar industry and I regret that the statement which appeared in my name created a false impression of your attitude and I apologise for any embarrassment or inconvenience it may have caused you.

That telegram is revealing of two things. First of all, it is revealing of a high degree of incompetence on behalf of the Queensland Minister if the statements made in the telegram are correct-that is to say, allegations of this kind are made and they are subsequently covered up by the Minister by saying they were made by his staff. Secondly, the allegation having been made, by whoever, Mr Ahern subsequently repeated it on a number of occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is superior to putting unverified material before the Senate, is it?

—I am answering a question regarding the Ministers for primary industry in the Federal Parliament and in the Queensland Parliament. The honourable senator will have his opportunity in regard to the other matter. Let me say that the behaviour of Mr Ahern in this matter is typical of some of the behaviour which has gone on in the context of the current Queensland election. Allegations have been made not only by senior Ministers in the Queensland Government but also by Senator Boswell in this Parliament that the Australian Labor Party Government in Canberra put pressure on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in relation to programs being shown in Queensland during the current election campaign. It was only yesterday that the Minister for Communications discovered what the ABC had done in relation to this matter in consultation with the political parties in Queensland. That is an extraordinary allegation-on reflection, perhaps not so extraordinary-to be made by Queensland politicians; it is an extraordinary allegation to be made by senators in this Parliament without any substantiation whatsoever. Birds of a feather, it seems, flock together in relation to these issues in Queensland. Senator Boswell, Mr Ahern and Senator Chaney, if he were a Queenslander, would no doubt be in the same bag .

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, follows the question asked by Senator Chaney at Question Time today. Is the Minister aware that a number of small investors in Metro Industries Ltd, who have received notices of liability under the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Amendment Act of 1982, have in many cases, as I understand it, paid the assessments in order to avoid the penalties that would otherwise be incurred without being aware of the interpretation placed on the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation which has now been revealed in the letter that he has written to a liquidator of Coomel Pty Ltd? I ask whether any of those small investors are in the same position as Coomel. If they can establish that to be the case, will the Government refund the money that has been paid?

—I am not sure to what degree the Government has an ability to take action as suggested by Senator Durack, assuming that the facts as he outlined them stand up to scrutiny. I am not sure what scope the Government has under the legislation or whether the Commissioner has the power to do as suggested. As I recall the details of the legislation, on receipt of an assessment a taxpayer may either contest the assessment and accrue interest at the rate of 20 per cent a year or pay in full settlement. As far as I am aware, there is no provision in the legislation for a subsequent refund of a payment which has been made. There may be some discretion for the Commissioner, if convincing evidence can be produced that the shareholder in question did not derive from the sale of the shares in that company a financial benefit which was related to the fact that it had always been intended by the directors who sold that company that the company tax due either for the current financial year or for previous financial years be evaded. But I will check the details of that with the Treasurer.

—My question is ad- dressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In the News in South Australia on Monday, 17 October, there was a report of economic recovery for Australia and, in particular, for South Australia, based on a report by the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The recovery report was based on indicators from the housing sector and industry forecasts for sales and employment. There was a further reference to excellent prospects in the rural sector recovery. Can the Minister say whether these rural figures represent an increase on the predictions before the Budget, to what areas they refer, and to what extent they will affect the economic recovery in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent estimate from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the net value of rural production is that it will be some $4,450m. The pre- Budget estimate was $4,400m. That was not a great change on the pre-Budget estimate. The degree of this increase reflects mostly the fact that very good rains have continued to be received throughout the wheat growing areas of eastern Australia at least; therefore, a record wheat crop is expected. That is, of course, a very large increase on farm product for the previous year. Because of that enormous growth in farm product, it is expected that the rural sector will contribute about 2 per cent of the total of 7 per cent increase in real total gross domestic product which is anticipated in this financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: A recent article in the National Farmer, in the issue dated 22 September, drew attention to the rural economy. Among other things, the article stated:
Thousands of new jobs and millions more dollars will also be injected into the rural economy through the Federal Budget's big spending plans for construction and roads.
That relates to the non-agricultural sector rather than the agricultural sector of the rural economy. The same issue of that paper reported:
Some $23m will be spent over several years on projects in areas ranging from Alice Springs, Toowoomba, Longreach, Orange and Dubbo to Ballarat, the Spencer Gulf, Derby, Broome and Burnie.

So, by reason of an upturn in agricultural output, which is mostly associated with the climate, and also because of the policies of the Government, a very significant improvement in the general state of the rural economy, both agricultural and non-agricultural, can be anticipated over the remainder of this financial year and beyond that into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer again to the extremely favourable ruling given to Coomel Pty Ltd by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Perth on 17 October. I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Will he ask the Commissioner of Taxation to inform the Parliament how many taxpayers have been assessed under the 1982 legislation and how many taxpayers have been afforded the same exceptionally favourable treatment?
—Was that taxpayers or tax evaders?
—Taxpayers.

—Taxpayers. Well, we are not talking about the Western Australian Branch of the Liberal Party, or half of it. If Senator Chaney wants to impugn the integrity of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, which I believe his question does, he is welcome to do so. I certainly will not join him in that exercise. As to the factual content of his question, as distinct from the innuendo which is clearly aimed at impugning the integrity of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia, regarding how many people have received assessments and a number of subsidiary matters, I will endeavour to obtain an answer to that aspect as quickly as possible.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen a report in the Age of 18 October claiming that the Internatonal Red Cross has been prevented from distributing aid in East Timor during the present Indonesian military offensive, and that the Australian Government is receiving misleading advice on the current situation in East Timor? Will the Minister inform the Senate whether there is any foundation for those claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report which appeared in the Age yesterday alleging that, according to cables received by the Department of Foreign Affairs , the International Red Cross is being prevented from providing aid in East Timor during the current Indonesian military offensive and suggesting that there has been some divergence between the advice that the Government has been receiving on the activities of the International Committee of the Red Cross in East Timor and what the Government has said publicly. I think Mr Hayden addressed this matter in a public statement yesterday, but it is appropriate, given the misreporting in the Age on this occasion, to put it on the parliamentary record.

ANSWER.PARA: The information available to the Government was fully reflected in the answers given by me in this place on 7 and 11 October when I said, among other things, that the representative of the ICRC in Jakarta had denied media reports that the ICRC had been refused access to East Timor. The representative said that the ICRC still had access to the territory, although with significant restrictions of movement on the main island. He confirmed that relief operations on the main island had not yet resumed due to limitations imposed by the Indonesian authorities on the ICRC delegates. This explanation from the International Committee of the Red Cross is consistent with a statement made on 14 October by the Indonesian representative to the United Nations when he said:

I can categorically state that the ICRC is continuing its various programs in East Timor and on Atauro Island, including programs on family reunion and repatriation, tracing and mailing. A temporary suspension is in force only with regard to relief operations on the mainland due to the recent security disturbances and here our concern is solely with the safety of ICRC personnel in the area where the earlier mentioned incident occurred-
He was referring there to the killing of 15 Indonesian soldiers on 8 August. He continued:
Negotiations, however, are continuing and we hope that on this aspect too a mutually satisfactory arrangement will soon be reached.
It is the case that the suggestion in the Age that there has been some very significant difference between what the Government knows and what we have said publicly is quite without foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy would be aware of the interdepartmental committee on uranium whose paper has been circulated to Caucus by the Prime Minister. Does the Minister accept the conclusion in paragraph 25 of that paper, namely, that the overall record of safeguards reflects the political influence of the system as a deterrent as well as the technical effectiveness of the safeguards themselves?

—I do not want to and I will not pass judgment, even a personal judgment, on one paragraph plucked in isolation out of an interdepartmental committee report. I would want to read it in context before I gave a personal opinion on it. Even if I were able to read in context-which would take a couple of minutes-a copy of the report, which I do not have with me, I believe it would be improper for me to pass judgment on it as an individual prior to the matter being considered by Cabinet and the parliamentary Party over the next couple of weeks.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and relates to the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. Will the Minister advise what stage the Royal Commission has reached in its inquiries? What steps will the Royal Commission take to ensure that the views of Australians in regional areas, not just those in capital cities, are heard and considered by the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The setting up of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam has proved to be one of the popular decisions of the Government. It has had endorsement in editorial comments by most of the major newspapers in this country. Currently, I understand that the Commissioner has held one or two inquiries in Sydney and has invited written submissions. Consequent upon receipt of those submissions, it is the intention of the Commissioner to hold such inquiries not only in the capital cities but also in many of the provincial areas of Australia. The Commission will seek to establish whether there has been an unusual incidence of birth defects amongst veterans' children and will deal with the questions of morbidity and mortality rates amongst the Vietnam veterans themselves. The Commissioner will also give consideration to whether there is any consequent justification for changes to the repatriation legislation and system.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked me a further question about outlying areas. I indicate to the Senate that, unlike the previous Government, this Government is commited to taking services and facilities to outlying areas. The Commissioner has indicated that he will be travelling to many parts of Australia in order that those veterans-and there seems to be a large proportion residing in Queensland-will have the opportunity to consult him. As a result of a conscious decision by the Commissioner to visit that State, he will engage in consultation , through talk-back radio and other means of communications, with those who believe that they have some evidence to place before the Commission. Active steps will be taken to encourage veterans, and especially those in outlying areas, to participate in the deliberations.

As I will be travelling to Townsville later this week to open a Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Services Office, it may be opportune for me to mention that Townsville is on the itinerary of the Commissioner because a considerable number of veterans live in that area. The Commissioner will be participating in the Government's overall commitment to extending facilities to people who live in regional areas and decentralising the delivery of services. Indeed, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs are determined to extend their range of facilities to those who live in the regional centres of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to a paper on uranium prepared by an interdepartmental committee on which his Department was represented. The report was circulated by the Prime Minister. Does the Minister agree with his Department that Australia's rejection of the nuclear fuel cycle, while possible, would be unlikely to improve its capacity to advance the cause of non-proliferation and, at best, might be seen abroad as a quixotic act? Does he further agree that such action would be counter-productive to the Government' s efforts in regard to disarmament and would have serious consequences for Australia's position as a supplier of other commodities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document to which Senator Hamer referred and from which I think he quoted, although I am not quite certain, is the agreed view of a number of Commonwealth departments. There is a legitimate argument to be put for the views put by those departments as there is probably a legitimate argument to be put against most, if not all, of the points those departments raised.

ANSWER.PARA: The point, however, is that Australia is not governed by that collection of departments or by the total 27 or 28 Commonwealth departments. Australia is governed by a government elected by the party which holds a majority of seats in the House of Representatives. Of course, that is the Australian Labor Party. I was elected by the entire parliamentary Labor Party as a member of that Government.

The final decisions will be made by the Government, not by Commonwealth departments in part or in total. The views expressed by those departments will be taken into account when the Labor Party makes a final decision on this matter .

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL MOTORS-HOLDEN'S LTD: ACACIA RIDGE PLANT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, concerns the proposal by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation to establish a light commercial vehicle assembly plant at the General Motors-Holden 's Ltd Acacia Ridge, Queensland, plant. Does the Minister feel that the proposal , which would involve a consortium of the major car manufacturers, is a feasible proposition? What would be the major obstacles in establishing such a plant? Does the Minister agree that it would be a means of overcoming the present monopoly on light commercial vehicles held by Japanese manufacturers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard an outline of the proposals by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation to use the Acacia Ridge plant of General Motors as a manufacturing area for light commercial vehicles in Australia. I have heard no details of the proposal by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation. I am not sure that there are any. The proposal is, in a sense, a natural response to the news of the closure of that plant and the perceived need for the manufacture of such vehicles in Australia. I am unable to say whether the proposal put forward by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation is feasible.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question related to the obstacles in the road of such a proposal being feasible. I suppose the principal answer is money and an agreement by the principal manufacturers on any such course of action which might, to them, seem desirable or otherwise. The question of the light commercial vehicle imports into Australia has been addressed to the Car Industry Council, the setting up of which I announced about a fortnight ago. Working parties of that Council are examining that matter.

Senator Foreman also asked me whether the use of the Acacia Ridge plant would be an adequate means of dealing with the question of the Japanese monopoly on the manufacture of light commercial vehicles. Any manufacture in Australia of light commercial vehicles, particularly substitute passenger cars, would of course have some effect on the presence of a Japanese monopoly in that area. The question which has to be addressed is whether that is desirable, because I think there is very little doubt that insofar as those vehicles are concerned the Japanese have been very astute in tailoring their product to the needs of particular markets and that their vehicles are very well produced. But those are all questions which are in the province of discussion currently before the Car Industry Council. I do not in any sense dismiss any of the suggestions which have been made. I just say that there must be very serious qualifications about their implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1983 Senator Jessop asked a question concerning the possibility of electronic surveillance of Senate committee rooms and senators' offices. The question was raised again at a hearing of Estimates Committee A on 12 September. I inform honourable senators that last night a physical and electronic inspection of the Senate committee rooms was carried out. In addition a check for possible radio transmissions from committee rooms was made while committees were meeting this morning. The inspection did not reveal any bugging devices or evidence of electronic surveillance. I advise honourable senators that I intend to have random checks carried out from time to time to minimise the potential for electronic surveillance in future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE SQUADRON, MALAYSIA AND AID TO VIETNAM

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October Senator Kilgariff asked me a question concerning the resumption of aid to Vietnam. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided me with the following answer. During Mr Hayden's discussions in Hanoi on 19 and 28 June the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Mr Tach, said that he was not about to ask for aid from Australia. Such a decision, he said, was a matter for Australian sovereignty. From Vietnam's point of view, he said, the most valuable aid was the support and sympathy of the Australian people and the continuation of the Government's initiative to facilitate the search for a solution to the Cambodian problem. The Government has made no decision to move in practical terms on the question of aid to Vietnam.

QUESTION.PARA: In the same question Senator Kilgariff also asked about the future of the Royal Australian Air Force Squadron at Butterworth in Malaysia. The Minister for Defence has said in reply that the question of the longer term future of the Australian presence at Butterworth is currently under review by the Government. A decision regarding the remaining RAAF Mirage squadron has not yet been made. Consultations will be held with the Malaysian and Singaporean governments in due course.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES POLICE REPORT: DRUG SMUGGLING

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 October Senator Durack asked me a supplementary question about the condition of the investigation by the Australian Federal Police into the drug matter arising out of which the investigation concerning Mr Rex Jackson was initiated. I am able to say in answer to Senator Durack's question that the investigation is current. It is not possible to comment at this stage as to when it might be concluded as it is the practice, which I am sure Senator Durack will appreciate, not to speculate on police operations currently in progress. No charges or drug seizures have resulted from the investigation so far.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Labor Government's broken promises and dishonoured assurances to the education community.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Government's record of broken promises and dishonoured assurances in education is a matter of national disgrace. In opening this discussion I want to mention first the fact that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, will not be present for this matter of public importance and to say that it is a matter of regret that that is so. It was the Opposition's intention to bring this matter on and have it discussed last Wednesday, when Senator Ryan was available and when she would have been able to answer it. We actually offered the matter for discussion last Wednesday, but the Australian Labor Party, in accordance with the Standing Orders and acting quite properly, pre-empted us and got in its own matter of public importance. It was our intention to bring this matter up for debate when the Minister was here to discuss it but as she is not here today I wish her well in her trip to Kilkenny. I regret that she is not here to answer to the education community and to the Senate for a shameful record of broken promises and dishonoured assurances. The message out of it is quite clear. It is that we cannot trust the Labor Party and we cannot trust Labor promises.

SPEECH.PARA: Today's matter of public importance is about the extent to which the Labor Government has failed to honour quite specific pre-election promises and the extent to which it proceeded cynically to raise expectations in the education community and the extent to which that community has now soundly condemned the Minister and the Government and has expressed great disappointment at what has happened. Mr Acting Deputy President, just three days ago I attended a large meeting of Catholic parents held on a Sunday night in the western suburbs of Sydney. The meeting was to have been addressed by Senator Ryan. She had been invited and she had accepted. I have here a copy of her letter of acceptance to address that meeting. Senator Ryan decided close to the date of the meeting that she would not so attend.

TALK.START.PARA: —She could not face it.

—It is interesting. I do not believe Senator Ryan was willing to go before a group of Catholic parents and answer the criticisms they have. I attended a meeting recently in Albury of about 950 parents. Not only would the Minister not attend but she would not send any representative, saying that the matter was of great delicacy. I would like to put on record that at both these meetings motions were carried condemning the Minister for her failure to attend, for her failure to meet them and for her refusal to answer face to face some of the criticisms which they have.

SPEECH.PARA: This failure to keep faith at meetings was a small thing compared with the broken promises and the dishonoured assurances to the whole education community that have marked the brief period of office of this Government. There are at least 15 broken promises and assurances, and this matter of public importance concerns those promises and those dishonoured assurances. We will discuss first the assurances which some people took to be statements which they could trust and which were given to them as specific statements before the election. The promises were in all areas of the education portfolio, but first let us consider the specific explicit assurances given to non-government schools before the election. The non-government authorities were fearful before the election of what the Labor Party might do, and as events have turned out they well might have been fearful. Labor's spokesman before the election undertook to speak to the non-government school representatives and to do so in such a way as to try to reassure them. The ALP sought to allay those fears and give those people some assurances. What were the assurances, Mr Acting Deputy President? In relation to non-government school funding, the Labor Party in writing, in a supplementary document issued in February 1983 during the election campaign, said:
A period of time will be required to allow the Schools Commission to determine the community standard and to allow schools, in the light of that determination to make their decision.
It went on to say in writing:
Funding at present levels will be maintained during this period.

There cannot be a more explicit and clearly stated promise than that. It is an assurance in writing and it is an assurance which has been dishonoured. Senator Ryan, after the election, in her haste to appease the teachers federations, did not give non-government schools the opportunity to conform to the community standard, as they had promised to do. She did not even wait until a community standard was developed. She did not wait even for the Commonwealth Schools Commission to go ahead and do what the Government had promised to do in writing. The promise that 'funding at present levels will be maintained during this period' went by the board at the first available opportunity. There is still no community standard which has been determined. We simply cannot trust the Labor Party. The Minister has dishonoured a specific commitment given on behalf of her party during an election campaign.

The Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, when he was Labor's shadow Minister for Education, went to Western Australia, his own State, and for whatever reasons, gave a most surprising but quite explicit assurance there that if the Labor Party produced a hit list of schools, no Western Australian school would be on it. That might be good home town stuff but that assurance has been dishonoured. The hit list contains a school in Western Australia and the parents and students at the Presbyterian Ladies College at Peppermint Grove, while they may or may not have news about being on the list, are very much aware that they are on this list, in spite of a specific promise by the Minister for Finance, when he was in Opposition, that no Western Australian school would be included. They have been let down. We cannot trust the Labor Party.

These assurances were central to the electorate's assessment of Labor's intentions and during an election campaign these intentions were what the people wanted to know. The people have been deceived badly. The Labor Government has sought, since its election, blatantly, in terms of its funding for schools, to divide Protestant from Catholic, to divide school from school, and Senator Ryan' s language in her speeches has been that of class struggle and class division. The ALP has taken a lot from some schools; it has given a little to some others. The amounts of money are modest but the matters of principle are not. They concern the basic grant and the percentage link which we have talked previously. The response to Labor's action has been vociferous and angry. What is interesting is that the condemnation of the policies of the Labor Party have come from those who have been the recipients of the largesse as well as from those who have been deprived.

Let us look at some of the school and church leaders who have attacked the Labor Party for its broken promises. Archbishop Sir Frank Little, Archbishop of Melbourne, writing in his own archdiocese newspaper, said that the sectarianism that this had given rise to was as bad as he could recall and 'Is this Senator Ryan's gift to the nation?' The Central Committee of Catholic Bishops of Australia representing 45 bishops in the Catholic community condemned out of hand as wrong in principle what the Labor Party had done. On 9 October, just 10 days ago, there was read from every Catholic pulpit in Victoria a pastoral letter signed by all the Catholic bishops of Victoria. They condemned roundly what the Labor Party had done as being wrong in principle. Yesterday in Canberra , at the opening of extensions to St Edmund's College, Archbishop Francis Carroll made it clear that he objected in principle to what the Labor Party had done. Are these the responses of those who the Labor Party says it is helping? Are these the responses of people who, realising what has been given to them, are grateful? These are in fact the responses of people who see all too clearly that the Labor Party is proceeding wrongly in principle and wrongly for education. They do not think they can trust Labor. We do not think they can trust Labor.

Senator Ryan should know that it is not just the non-government school sector which recognises that assistance for all schools is a matter of equity and educational justice. The people of Australia understand it too. A poll published last weekend in the Australian newspaper showed quite clearly that 71 per cent of those Australians whose children are at government schools support the continuation of state aid. So the community supports state aid and it supports a fair go. We cannot understand why this white-anting is going on. I would say very seriously that if the ALP ignores this groundswell of concern from the leaders of the Catholic Church and from the leaders of the Catholic education community it will do so at its own peril.

Labor's broken promises go further. They go right across the education portfolio. The Government has failed to put into place promised programs for schools, promised programs for technical and further education, promised programs for universities, promised programs for colleges and promised support for students.

TALK.START.PARA: —Identify them.

—My colleagues and I will set some of these out. Let me spend just a few moments on Labor's promises to support students and, of course, on its failure to deliver on these quite specific promises. The promise was clear and uniquivocal. I will read it. In relation to cash support for students, the Labor Party said:

SPEECH.PARA: To increase TEAS-
that is, the tertiary education assistance scheme-
progressively until it equates with the unemployment benefit and then to maintain the nexus.
It also promised:
To increase the TEAS means test until it equates with the average weekly wage.

What in fact has it done? It has failed to maintain TEAS in real terms. It has increased it in cash terms by 5 per cent when inflation has gone up more than that. We will almost certainly see a decline in the real living standards of our students who are depending on TEAS. Just this morning we were asked to agree to legislation which increased the unemployment benefit. This will widen the gap between the unemployment benefit and the assistance available to students. It increased the unemployment benefit but not the benefit for students. There is a promise to students waiting to be redeemed. Of course, because the means test which goes with that allowance was not increased enough, a smaller percentage of students will get access to the benefit. Let me illustrate that. At the Estimates Committee hearings we ascertained, by way of question, that the Government expects 10,000 more enrolments but at the same time it expects only 500 more people to get access to student assistance. Only 5 per cent of the numbers enrolled will be getting TEAS.

In spite of waxing so lyrical about the need to increase participation in education and to improve access, in its first Budget Labor has widened the gap between unemployment benefit and student allowances. One only needs to recall the words which Senator Ryan herself used in this place when it suited her in Opposition. She said:

While ever there is such a disparity between the level of payment available for unemployment benefit and the level of assistance for full time students, students from modest backgrounds will from time to time be forced out of universities and tertiary institutions and on to the dole. How the Government can possibly defend and maintain that system really defies rational understanding.

Senator Ryan's own words, upon which she and her Government promised to act, now serve to condemn her. The Government's priorities are clearly directed less to the needs of education, retention and participation than its rhetoric before election would have us believe. Here was a chance to redeem a promise to students. The Government failed to do so. It is clear to tertiary students across Australia that they cannot trust Labor.

Let us look at what else the Labor Party promised students. It promised to provide post-doctoral fellowships for 300 scholars to boost the national research effort. It has not honoured the promise. It promised to provide an emergency loan scheme to replace the student loan scheme which it had abandoned. It has not done so. It promised to assist student parents with the provision of child care on campus. It has not done so. Is it any wonder that across Australia , on campus after campus, the student newspapers are taking the Labor Government to task. The students know that they have been betrayed and they are saying so. Tharunka, the University of New South Wales newspaper, in its post-Budget issue, said: 'Government Stabs Students in the Back' and 'Record of Deceit'. That is what they say at the University of New South Wales. The Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, in the Journal of Advanced Education of September , makes it clear where the Government has failed to deliver.

I must say that the Australian National University's own newspaper Woroni saw fit to put a photograph of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the back of that newspaper together with words which the Prime Minister himself uttered in another place last year about his predecessor, words which were clearly against the Standing Orders, words which imputed the worst kind of motive to his predecessor and which I do not care to read into this record. This was the opinion of students on campus at the ANU. Those students know that they cannot trust the Prime Minister, the Australian Labor Party and their promises on the never never. Right across Australia, people have been criticising this Government for the sham that is its Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —You believe in smaller government.

—Senator Gietzelt has been part of that sham. Mr Acting Deputy President, I go further. The $10m that has been provided to allow for 3, 000 extra student places might be all very well, but the Government has not provided the capital to make it a reality. Yesterday in this place the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report was tabled. It actually took the Government to task for failing to provide the resources to make the redemption of its promise a reality; and so it goes on. There is no commitment to continued funding to make these extra places a reality. It is all in the report. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission took the Government to task. Student organisations have taken the Government to task; and so it goes.

SPEECH.PARA: I deal now with residential colleges for students. These are essential for people who live out of the metropolitan areas. Eighty per cent of country students use residential colleges and they will be paying more for their accommodation because there has been a 25 per cent cut in the funding subsidy. Of course, this has been done against the background that their tertiary education assistance allowance will be less in real terms. The Vice-President of the Australian Union of Students-scarcely a conservative organisation-Ms Gayle Sonsakda has stated:
an effective decrease in the level of TEAS is an odd method of facilitating access for disadvantaged groups.
These tertiary students know that they cannot trust the Labor Party.

According to the headline in the August edition of the Teachers' Journal, Labor 's failure to deliver on its promise extends to schools as well. Labor promised to provide an extra $37m in its first year of government for recurrent resources in government schools. That was its promise. Van Davy, the President of the Australian Teachers Federation, in his report in Teachers' Journal wrote an article which was headed:
$37 million still owing!

That was another promise made by the Labor Party which was not kept. The schools cannot trust Labor either. What has emerged from the many promises is that those who trusted Labor in the education area have had their hopes dashed. More specific promises have been broken. I hope that my colleagues will refer to them . How they are redeemed is part of the test of credibility of the Minister and the Government and of their adherence to policy.

The Labor Party's promises were clear. These promises were the bait used to attract voters, just as the Government has been trying to bait the hook for Queensland this week. When the votes came in, the promises were not honoured. They have been put aside to the disadvantage of education. It is a sorry story, Mr Acting Deputy President, of failure and deception. We cannot trust Labor to keep its promises. In education, as in other areas, that failure to deliver has been revealed. Its education program shows just how far the Labor Party in Government is prepared to go to dishonor and to set aside solemn and specific undertakings. I believe that education has suffered unfairly. I believe the education community will find it difficult to forgive the Labor Party for what it has done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it amazing that Senator Peter Baume would open his speech by making a trumped up charge against the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), who is not here this afternoon to defend herself. Senator Giles has full details about the deceitful charges that Senator Peter Baume has made against Senator Ryan and she will provide the details to the Senate when she speaks. I also find it rather amazing that it is Senator Peter Baume who has brought on a debate about broken promises and dishonoured assurances to the education community. The discredited former Minister for Education certainly had his opportunity to bring about greater equity and social justice in Australian education. He did not take that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the Australian electorate showed that the Fraser Government not only in the education area but also in all areas could not be trusted. The previous Government did not have an education policy but rather a funding formula. The previous Government did not direct resources to those most in need. In short, the previous Government failed in the area of education. By comparison, the previous Labor Government has moved quickly to address inequities in the provision of education resources. We are not the first Labor Government to do this. I will mention the current Labor Government's initiatives shortly.

Before doing so, I shall make some comments about former administrations. On coming to office, the Whitlam Labor Government of 1972-75 set about ending the decades of poverty and neglect experienced by many Australian schools under previous conservative governments. The needs principle was given effect when the Government accepted the recommendations of the Karmel report. The Schools Commission was established in the face of strong opposition by the conservative parties. Co-operation between government and non-government schools was fostered through the Schools Commission itself and by the funding of joint programs in which government and non-government schools participated. Funding according to need and special assistance to disadvantaged groups was established as the basis of the Federal role in school funding.

In a display of extraordinary insensitivity, the Fraser Government systematically rekindled the divisions over state aid and pursued funding policies which manifestly failed to close the resource gaps with which it had professed to be concerned. Contrary to the notions of need or social justice, the Fraser Government increased Commonwealth grants to the highest resources category of non-government schools at twice the rate of its increase to the most needy category and it presided over a real decline in the Commonwealth contribution to government schools. Through its laissez-faire policies, the Fraser Government increased tension between government and non-government schools by failing to ensure that the impact of proposed new schools on existing schools was assessed and that resources were used efficiently.

The Fraser Government presided over a real decline in participation rates by teenagers in post-compulsory education. The seriousness of this development could hardly be exaggerated. The loss of talented young people had a serious effect on participation in higher education and the ranks of unemployed teenagers were swelled at the very time when employment opportunities were shrinking. In responding to this development the Fraser Government failed on all counts. It destroyed the Commonwealth's capacity to assist change in secondary schools by dismantling the Curriculum Development Centre and the Education Research and Development Committee. Its economic polices placed greater and greater economic pressure on families. It reduced resources to government schools where the decline was concentrated.

In its guidelines for the education commissions, the Hawke Labor Government has again sought to focus its efforts on the areas of greatest need. The guidelines statement signalled a return to Commonwealth policies for schools under which funds are directed to areas of need and priority and provide a firm basis for proper educational planning. In the guidelines, the Government's policy objectives as they relate to the programs of the Schools Commission were set out . Our objectives are: To assist schools to give a positive and effective education to all children and to make substantial progress towards the more equal distribution of other outcomes of education such as access to paid employment and higher education. To assist schools to respond effectively and appropriately to the diversity of Australian society; to assist and help shape economic recovery and development; and to give the community confidence in our determination to give all children access to properly staffed and equipped schools.

Perhaps the most characteristic example of our approach is the participation and equity program, which will begin next year. The program is intended to encourage young people over the school leaving age to stay in the education system and to undertake useful and fulfilling education training. The program will be the centrepiece of the overall framework of youth policies which the Government is developing. As honourable senators will be aware, the Hawke Labor Government was elected on a platform which included specific commitments to improving public education. As a consequence, $71m has been allocated for the program for 1984; $39.6m will go to government schools, $4.5m will go to non- government schools, and $26.9m will go to technical and further education.

The transition education program will be subsumed by the participation and equity program. An indication of the importance that we place on the new program is the fact that the total of $44m allocated to the schools sector is $20m more than the amount available under the transition education program this year. This additional amount will be used on activities which have a broad system impact, such as the examination of credentialling and assessment, curriculum reform, modification of teacher skills and attitudes to fit the new courses which will emerge, organisational reform, the targeting of support services and, very importantly, the improvement of school-community relations and community attitudes to both education and the outcomes of education.

The program will work to break down the persistent patterns of disadvantage, in which educational outcomes have depended to an unacceptable extent on the socio- economic background, sex, ethnic background or geographical location of students . The major emphasis of the participation and equity program will be to increase the participation of young people in post-compulsory schooling, particularly Aboriginal people, working class youth, some migrant communities, rural youth and handicapped people. The Government has no intention of promoting artificial or contrived schemes for raising retention rates at particular schools at the expense of others. We seek an improvement in all schools.

Apart from the program initiative there are a number of other areas in which the Government has already taken action. The Schools Commission has already established a national advisory committee on computers in schools and is examining issues related to the introduction of a national computer education program. Effective forward planning in this area is of the utmost importance if the program is to succeed, and that will be the primary function of the national advisory committee. We have allocated $18m for the triennium 1984-86, with government schools getting $4.8m and non-government schools getting $1.2m next year.

The establishment of the computer education program recognises the need for students to have an understanding of the uses of new technologies and their social, environmental, industrial and economic effects. From the teachers' point of view there will need to be planning for the introduction of computers and computer-based programs to the curriculum and the professional development of teachers who will have to deal with the new technologies. Additional and appropriate professional development programs, including programs for parents, will be funded from this allocation.

Another area in which the Government has acted quickly is that of capital expenditures on government schools. Next year will be the first time since 1977 that there has been a real increase in the government schools capital program. The 1984 allocation will be $150.5m, compared with $143.5m available this year. Within that $150m we have earmarked $20m for the upgrading of existing schools serving disadvantaged communities because of our concern that, as reported by the Schools Commission, far too many such schools are dilapidated or run-down. Another $5m has been earmarked for government schools serving predominantly Aboriginal communities.

The Government has made clear its commitment to improving the educational opportunities of women and girls. We want to enhance the ability of schools to help girls gain the self-confidence and competence necessary for equal participation in society. There have always been girls who have succeeded. Many more have never reached their full potential because of the disadvantages they have faced in the education system at all levels and the consequences of that for employment opportunities. The Schools Commission is examining the particular educational needs of girls and ways of meeting those needs in both primary and secondary schools. The Government will provide funds in 1984, under the projects of national significance program of the Commission, specifically for projects related to the improvement of educational outcomes for girls. Perhaps more importantly, the Commission will be required to monitor all Commonwealth-funded programs to ensure that girls and boys have equal access to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I should like Senator Colston to assure us that he is not reading his speech. If he is not reading it, perhaps he could look up occasionally.
—I have observed that Senator Colston has been using copious notes. I do not intend to rule in favour of the point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Government also intends to give priority to the development of arts education. All students should have the chance to know and benefit from their cultural heritage. We have established an education and arts task force to advise on ways of ensuring that a knowledge of and capacity to participate in the full range of visual, performing and creative arts can be made available in all schools. Funds for the project will be made available through the Commission's projects of national significance program.
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Could we ask Senator Colston who wrote the speech to which he is sticking so closely?
—I have ruled against that point of order, Senator Walters. Please proceed, Senator Colston.
—I should like to remind Senator Walters, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I have a long memory. Senator Walters should be aware of that fact.
—I take a point of order. Is that a threat?
—No, it is a promise.
—Senator Colston is obviously issuing a threat. I require an apology for the threat that he has made.
—Senator Walters, you may take your point after Senator Colston has finished speaking.
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I draw your attention to the state of the House.

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Are we to have complete disruption of an honourable senator's contribution by Senator Walters? Three times she has transgressed and challenged your ruling. I think she should be asked to maintain a little dignity in this chamber.
—A quorum is not present. Ring the bells. (Quorum formed)

—I inform those people who are listening to this debate today that calling for a quorum is a typical ploy which has been used by the Opposition in recent weeks. When the Opposition cannot accept the fact that the Government is working well and working for the Australian people, it tries to limit the amount of time available to Government speakers. I was talking about the initiatives of the Hawke Labor Government. Another of the Government's initiatives for 1984 has been to increase the funds available for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. For this element of the special education program of the Schools Commission, funds for next year have been increased by 20 per cent for both Commonwealth and non-government schools to allow a more comprehensive development of the program and its services to children and parents.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to mention something about the youth policy of the present Government. The previous Government approached youth policy as if it were a problem to be fixed later. How often did we hear of the problems of youth? Under a Liberal- National Party government youth policy was ignored. The Labor Government has already undertaken a number of significant steps towards its objective of producing a more co-ordinated and comprehensive approach to the development of youth policies. Some of these steps are:
establishment of a new Department of Education and Youth Affairs, and assignment to me-
this refers to Senator Ryan-
as Minister, of responsibility for the co-ordination of Commonwealth policies and programs for youth; creation of a Standing Inter-departmental Committee on Youth Policies . . .

I could go on but because my time has been taken by useless points of order I will just mention this: The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, will be investigating developments in youth policy in Scandinavian countries during a visit to Denmark, Norway and Sweden during the next few weeks . This Government has a definite commitment to youth.

To sum up, the reports of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission welcome the many positive initiatives announced by the Government. The commissions are particularly appreciative of the strong direction of the Government's policies in regard to greater social justice. For instance, the Commonwealth Schools Commission states:

The Commission welcomes the emphasis in the Guidelines on the allocation of resources to schools on the basis of need. This emphasis is consistent with the Commission's charter. It also welcomes the introduction of the Participation and Equity Program, special support for Aboriginal Education and the initiatives in respect of capital funds for government and non-government schools, special education, arts education and the education of girls.
The Schools Commission goes on further to welcome the initiatives of this Government:
The Commission welcomes the introduction of the Computer Education Program for secondary schools and the decision to fund it on a triennial basis.

Similarly we can have a look at statements of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission which indicate how it welcomes the guidelines which were given to it. The only concern of both commissions is that not as much money was available as they would have liked. Whose fault was that? Senator Peter Baume, who spoke earlier, appears to forget that the Hawke Labor Government was elected for a three-year term. Whilst it would have liked to have fulfilled its election promises in its first Budget it still has two further Budgets before it goes to the polls again, or does the Opposition intend to do what it did in 1974 and 1975 and cut short the Government's term? If it is intent on doing that, it is bound to fail. This being so, it should remain patient. In addition, the Opposition must remember that if it had not left the cupboard bare the Hawke Labor Government would have had a greater opportunity to fulfil more of its promises in the present Budget. Who left a $9.6 billion deficit? Who restricted the Government's ability to fund education to the extent that it would like and to the extent that it needs-who, indeed, but the discredited former Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon in the Senate the Liberal and National parties have referred to uproar which has arisen around Australia as a result of the broken education promises of the Hawke Government. Sufficient promises have been broken in regard to schools alone that I will concentrate my remarks directly on them. Why is it that the Australian Labor Party has set out to alienate the one million Australian families who have made a deliberate choice for their children's education by opting to send them to independent schools? Why do the policies, the abandonment of the established principles by the present Hawke Government, set out to alienate one million Australian families? Earlier in his speech today Senator Peter Baume referred to the public opinion polls which showed that 70 per cent of Australians, even those not involved directly in independent schools, support governments giving independent schools state aid. Why is it that before the election the Labor Party sought to give assurances to these people that all would be well but now, following the election, there have been broken promises after broken promises? All those reassurances have been abandoned and those families are now angry, worried and concerned because the Labor Party is alienating them and is out to destroy the bases of the independent schools in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: During the period leading up to the election the ALP had difficulty with Mr Dawkins as its spokesman because he alienated so many families who were concerned about their children's education. So the ALP nominated as its spokesman on education a more moderate and sensible man, Chris Hurford, from my State of South Australia. For months Chris Hurford went around the country meeting with the Catholic schools representatives and with other independent schools representatives trying to discuss with them the actual wording of the assurances he would need to give so that the Labor Party could win back some of their votes in the election. All those reassurances have been abandoned.

Let me remind the Senate that before the election Mr Hawke and his other spokesman from the ALP said that they would set out to provide unity in the field of education and that they would seek to lessen the divisiveness and bitterness of the anti-state aid debate. That was their promise. They said: 'We will build a climate in which that divisiveness, that bitterness, will be overcome'. But on gaining office they have abandoned the well-established principles on which that unity and cohesion within Australia was built.

I will refer to five of these principles. The first is what I call the establishment of choice principle. It is true that the ALP says that people will have a choice, but it is not at the Government's expense. The establishment of choice is directly in jeopardy because the Government has now said: 'In establishing a new independent school you will have to meet not just the normal criteria of the past. There will be extra censorship and extra criteria that you will have to meet before we will allow some capital funds to go to you'. This was announced in late July of this year, but these new barriers were backdated to the day of the election, the day of disaster for Australia and the day of disaster for independent schools. These barriers were set up to abandon the principle that Australian parents can choose to establish an independent school in the local community and receive fair treatment and support in that school's establishment. There is no guarantee any more that in setting up a new independent school one will get even one dollar towards the capital establishment from this Government.

The second principle I want to refer to is what I call 'the honesty principle'. It refers to the nexus, that principle which keeps a government honest. The amount of financial support for an independent school is indexed as a direct proportion of the money which goes towards maintaining a state school. That nexus has been abolished. We are on that slippery slope towards there being no guarantees that independent schools will receive recurrent funding from this Government.

The third principle is what I have called the taxpayers' principle. It relates to the basic grant which over many years had been guaranteed to all Australian children in any school anywhere in the country. That principle of the basic grant has been abandoned by this Government. In the past, taxpayers have thought that at least some small part of the taxes they pay ought to be directed towards the cost of their children's education. But Senator Ryan has called that taxpayers' principle specious. She is quite happy that some taxpayers will receive no support whatsoever for their children's education from this Labor Government.

A fourth principle is the representation principle. We have always thought-at least on this side of the chamber-that, to be fair, any statutory authority or group that is to make decisions affecting parts of Australia ought to be represented on the advisory committee that makes recommendations for government decisions. In the Commonwealth Schools Commission, the representation principle of the past-fair and dispersed representation, with all the interests that the School Commission deals with represented-has been abandoned.

A fifth principle is the needs principle. The first four principles I have mentioned have been abandoned by appeal to this fifth principle which we, of course, also support. It is that children in schools with low educational resources, with greater direct needs for educational facilities, ought to receive some supplementary assistance to give them the opportunity or the means to overcome their present disadvantage. We reinforced that needs principle again and again in decisions in recent years. I am glad to see that the ALP Government has also embraced the needs principle. But it has so embraced it that it has become the basis of all its rhetoric. It has become the blinding light to which it appeals for abandoning all the other principles. I reject that. I will quote from the speech given at Hurstville by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan. With a great deal of bravado in her opening statement to an assemblage of independent schools on 24 September this year, she said:

In the financial guidelines to the education commissions for 1984, I announced a number of decisions which illustrates the Hawke Government's priorities. Of particular relevance to the schools sector were . . . the decision to begin reducing recurrent funding to a small number of schools,-
That is the abolition of the basic grant, the abolition of the taxpayer principle to which I referred. The Minister continued:
. . . the decision to break the nexus between recurrent grants for non- government schools and average government schools recurrent costs,-

That is the abolition of the honesty principle to which I referred, in that no longer is there a guarantee that a recurrent grant from this Commonwealth Government to an independent school will, as inflation continues year by year, have the same real value. The Minister is here blatantly, with bravado, saying that a great achievement of the Hawke Government is that it has abandoned this principle. The third decision to which the Minister referred was:
. . . the decision to revise the conditions upon which Commonwealth Government funds will be provided for new non-government schools.

That is the abandonment of the establishment of choice principle that I mentioned in my earlier remarks. Under this Government, no new independent school in Australia is guaranteed any assistance in its establishment. The barriers have been put in place. It is not a question only of whether that school has a sound educational curriculum, sound educational principles or properly qualified staff. It is also a question of whether that school will take some students away from the government schools in that region, schools that parents, by choice, have decided that they do not wish their children to attend. Therefore, the abandonment of this principle by the Labor Government is only a cover for a straight-out opposition to the establishment of any kind of new independent school. I think that the ALP is in a direct bind because in its ranks it has hundreds, even thousands, of opponents to independent schools. They are directly committed persons, many of whom are genuine; I am not decrying them . It is a free country in which a party may attract those who are bitterly opposed to there being independent schools.

Some people in Australia believe that because we have different sorts of schools this makes for a divided Australia or for a lack of basic coherence. I think that is a load of nonsense. Some people in Australia, perhaps because of unfortunate individual experiences at independent schools, are anti-religious. They are just opposed to what they regard as the superstition that is taught in independent schools. They are opposed to there being schools that have a religious foundation. They are not just secularists expressing a genuine belief, such as there have been in all the decades in Australia's history. Not only do they want to rest with their own expression of opinion; they also, in an illiberal way, seek to oppose the choice and conscientious beliefs and decisions of others. This group has got within the Labor Party and has forced it to formulate policies which are against independent schools which it has set out to undermine. How does it then seek to achieve its goals? It seeks first of all to stop any new independent school being established. Senator Ryan has taken up that approach, that strategy, on behalf of the present Government and made it very difficult for there to be any support given to the establishment of a new school.

How does this group further stop such schools? It will stop indexed grants. It will abandon the nexus. Then it will cut down the tall poppies. It will make sure that those so-called rich schools will get no help at all from the taxpayers of Australia. This group within the Labor Party has bound the ALP to renege on and abandon the assurances given by the then spokesman on education, Mr Hurford, prior to the election and by the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. The re-assurances that they gave have been abandoned. Why is it that the Labor Party seeks to alienate by these broken promises, by this attack on independent schools and those in the community who support choice in education, one million Australian families involved in these schools? Why has it set out to go against the views expressed by 70 per cent of all Australians, as recent public opinion polls show?

Let it be clear in this debate that the Liberal and National parties will stand by the right of Australian parents to have a full choice for their children's education. We will ensure that there is encouragement for the establishment of schools that are the choice of those parents, that there is a nexus and that there is an indexed grant that will give recurrent support to those families involved in Australian schools. We will not abandon the children of Australia whether in government or non-government schools. We reject the abandonment by the Labor Party of the promises it made to Australian schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like first to make some comments in rebuttal of the allegations that were made by Senator Baume, to the effect that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) was unwilling to meet with the New South Wales Catholic parents. The facts of the matter are that the Minister had agreed to meet with the parents, but her plans to go overseas to study education and youth policies in Europe were brought forward several days, a matter which was beyond her control. Giving two weeks notice, the Minister asked the Catholic parents of New South Wales whether the meeting could be delayed. They said no. Therefore, she asked the Chairman of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, Dr Tannock, to attend. This was acceptable to the Catholic parents and friends organisation and to the best of my knowledge the meeting proceeded. But a small and noisy group of obsessives has sought to whip up an insane vendetta against the Minister, apparently advised by the archetype misogynists from the New South Wales upper House. In attacking the Minister, these people have shown their ignorance of the way in which a Labor government determines its policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has had extensive and constructive discussions during the seven months of this Government's existence with the National Catholic Education Commission, with which she has an excellent working relationship, and the State education authorities. However, there has been insufficient time in the lead-up to the Budget this year for the Government to consult the non-government school communities and other relevant authorities on developments of long term changes in funding policy, such as the development of a community standard of resources for schools and a more comprehensive way of measuring the needs of schools against community standards. This has still not been established. It is being worked upon but it was not the basis for the decisions made in this year's Budget.

Consequently, the Government has had to make a number of interim decisions for 1984 and ask the Schools Commission to consult widely with non-government schools and other authorities on the option for longer term funding policies beyond 1984. For general recurrent funding in 1984 the Government decided that additional funds amounting to $7.2m-a real increase of 1.3 per cent on 1983- would be available for non-government schools. These additional funds will be provided on a needs basis. This was one of the principles alluded to by Senator Teague. He managed to invent a few other fetishes of his own, but the needs principle is one which, as he rightly said, the Labor Party has espoused for well over a decade and we do not retreat from it.

Under general recurrent funding for 1984, per capita grants for the 41 schools whose private incomes alone total 95 per cent or more of government school standard costs is to be reduced-not wiped out completely as we might have been led to believe-by 25 per cent. The savings-something like $4m-are to be redirected to those most in need. It is a little bit of a redistribution, another principle which, I believe, has not been alluded to this afternoon. I think it is highly probable that the vast majority of the Australian electorate thoroughly supports the Australian Labor Party on that principle.

Grants for other schools in group I, schools in the highest resource category, will be maintained in real terms. Grants for group II schools will be increased by one per cent in real terms. For schools in group III, the most needy and by far the greatest number of schools with the greatest number of pupils in the non -government sector, the grants will be increased by 3 per cent in real terms. These funding arrangements replaced those of the previous Government, under which increases in grants for all non-government schools were linked to increases in government school costs each year regardless of the fact that many low resource, non-government schools have far greater needs than other high resource, non-government schools. In fact, in recent years the gap between the low resource, non-government schools and government schools has widened. Had the previous Government's funding policy continued, the lowest resource non- government schools in group III would have received some $5m less than they will now receive in 1984. The Government recognises the right of parents to choose a non-government school for their children. However, it believes that its needs based funding policy will bring greatest benefit to the majority of Australian children over a period of time and eventually will substantially reduce the gap between the affluent schools and those with few resources.

In addition to these changes, the Government took further funding decisions for 1984 which will benefit non-government schools. The 1983 level of capital grants was maintained in real terms, including the $9m provided in 1983 for new places. An amount of $4m will be provided for the upgrading of schools serving disadvantaged communities and $2m for capital facilities in schools serving Aboriginal communities. Provision of some $4.5m for non-government schools under the new participation and equity program has taken the place of the transition program which was introduced by the former coalition Government. An amount of $1 .2m has been allocated under a new initiative, the computer education program, and overall grants for non-government schools will increase by 1.5 per cent in real terms. We have reintroduced retrospective costs supplementation, providing greater certainty for education planning, and are planning to return to triennial funding. Amongst other initiatives, all of which are very welcome in the community, is the reactivation of the Curriculum Development Centre, which will benefit all schools.

My interest in schools dates from the early 1960s when my first child started attending a primary school. My youngest child did not finish her state school education until 1977 and during these 17 years I must have been one of the most conscientious state school parents ever, becoming a vice president of what became the Western Australian Council of State Schools Organisations. My experience includes being an undergraduate student for three years at the University of Western Australia in the early 1970s and I have the added benefit of the experiences of my daughters as they have become tertiary students from 1971 onwards. I have had between one and four offspring in tertiary education at any one time ever since.

As a result of those very personal experiences, I believe I am able to speak with some authority about the feelings of the vast majority of parents in Australia who, having little choice, send their children to local government schools. The 1960s saw the starving of the state school systems and the development towards the end of the decade of a concerted campaign by parents and teachers for more Federal funding for state schools. At that time we saw Federal funding going to private schools and a considerable amount of unrest in the community. By 1972, in the year running up to the Federal election, enormous public meetings of parents and teachers were being held all over Australia to discuss the inequites in the state school programs.

One of the really important election issues of that year was the funding of government schools. In 1973 I was among the state school parents who saw with joy the introduction of the Schools Commission Bill. I was also among those parents who worked very hard to persuade the members of the then upper House that that Bill should be introduced to give legislative effect to two crucial principles, as against the fetishes which we have previously heard. Those principles were, firstly, that the Government's first responsibility-not its only responsibility, but its first responsibility-is the education of those who rely upon the public education system and, secondly, that Federal education funding should be allocated on the basis of need.

The first report of the Karmel Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission categorised non-government schools according to their resources. Of course, this was hated by the independent schools in particular which did not want it widely known in the community just what their resources were. During the 1970s a great deal more emphasis was given to the needs of schools generally right across the board and some initiatives that even now have managed to survive the Fraser years. What we saw during those years has already been alluded to by Senator Colston-a deterioriation in the participation rate in tertiary education to the point where one report, by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on demographic analysis, was able to state that we had seen the trend to tertiary education reversed. It had been reversed and that action seemed almost deliberate. Once again in 1982 surveys in the electorate began showing education as a sleeper issue. I believe that it was one of the important issues in the time prior to the last election when once again state school parents and very many private school parents became greatly politicised. This sort of thing happens in bursts. New generations and new cohorts of parents come forward and start to become very concerned about their children's education, their expectations and so forth. They become concerned about education funding. We had very large meetings in 1982-83. These provided the opportunity to remind many of these parents of what had happened during the 1960s and 1970s.

Some parents with good long memories know perfectly well that it is the Australian Labor Party which has the real concern for the education of the ordinary people of this community. Those ordinary people to whom I referred before do not have a choice about where to send their children. Indeed, even some of those who do have a choice send their children to local government schools. I would suggest that the most predominant reason why people send their children to government schools is economic necessity. Often they do so though geographic necessity: There is no other school. If Government schools can be improved so that they offer a broader curriculum and more individual help and are more responsive to the wishes of parents, clearly the educational choices of the majority of Australians will be enhanced. This was my aim and the aim of parents like me who worked within parent participation organisations and those who are still working for those organisations within the government and non- government sectors.

If all schools can provide a sound educational base for all their pupils so that they can go on to choose further learning or be well equipped to look for employment, the choices of those pupils are greatly improved. The Government's participation and equity program to which I previously referred is a significant contribution to enhancing the choices of many thousands of young people through offering them a richer curriculum and a better chance to gain work force skills through the technical and further education system. Similarly, emphasis in the guidelines on improving the resources of the most needy schools in the non- government sector is a specific contribution to enabling those schools to offer a richer curriculum containing more learning choices for the children who attend them.

Mr Acting Deputy President-and parent I am sure-in conclusion I emphasise the fact that very many of the programs introduced by the Labor Government during 1972-75, some of which are being resurrected and some of which have been kept going over the years, are available not only to government schools but also to non-government schools. They have added an important extra dimension to the education of all young people in Australia regardless of which sector they attend for their education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.
