TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the matter of public importance concerning the Labor Party's education promises brought forward by Senator Peter Baume, the shadow Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, is an interesting exercise, not the least because of the election on Saturday in my own State of Queensland. Obviously this matter of public importance is aimed at that election. Of course, the practice of parties going to the electorate with promises is well known in Australia. In fact, it is so well known that discerning electors no longer bother to take any notice of what political parties say because they know that those promises are going to be broken afterwards. However, it is an interesting exercise, nevertheless, to look at the types of promises that political parties make for the cynical exercise, presumably, of winning votes because this illustrates, at least in some way, the types of ideas in which political parties believe people are interested. For that reason, I think it is useful to look at the promises that the Australian Labor Party made before the March election and to see how it has implemented or failed to implement those promises.

SPEECH.PARA: The first area at which I would like to look is the very obvious one of private schools. I do not happen to agree with what the previous speaker, Senator Giles, said was the major reason why parents in Australia send their children to government schools. I happen to send my children to government schools because I believe they are better schools. However, that is a personal view that I have as a parent. Many people who send their children to private schools are concerned- and probably with some reason-about the Labor Party's attitude to private schools particularly in view of the labor Party's 1982 Platform, Constitution and Rules. The Labor Party conference document says that a Labor government would require the Schools Commission, in making its recommendations, to have regard to:
The requirement that Commonwealth funds be available only to those non- government schools whose total private and public resources do not exceed the resources of comparable government schools.
That type of idea, presumably, was expressed in greater detail in the main education document prior to the election entitled 'The Hayden Education Plan'. Item 12.4 of that document states:

In government, Labor will take new initiatives to improve the resource levels of schools with little capacity to improve their level of resources. These initiatives will require discussion and agreement with the non-government school sector. During the period of these discussions Labor will maintain in real terms the existing levels of funding for all group 2 and group 3 schools and for those group 1 schools which choose to operate within the community standard.
In other words, there were to be consultations and the opportunity was to be offered to private schools to come within those community standards.

Mr Hawke's policy speech on 16 February of this year went even further. It stated that an Australian Labor Party government would reduce by only 5 per cent per year the direct Commonwealth grant going to a very small number of wealthy private schools endowed with resources far above those of any other schools. Quite obviously, what has occurred has been a blatant disregard of that promise. What we had in fact was a reduction of 25 per cent in the first year instead of 5 per cent per year. In other words, there has been a 500 per cent increase in the reduction mentioned in Mr Hawke's policy speech. Further, the Australian Labor Party promised to 'maintain in real terms the existing levels of funding for all group 2 and group 3 schools'. That promise has been broken in that group 2 primary schools will, in fact, be worse off in this financial year and a number of group 2 schools have, of course, been reclassified as group 1 schools.

The Australian Democrats support the general thrust of what the Government is attempting to do in this area. Indeed, we were the only political party to go into the election making it quite clear that we supported the concept of funding of private schools on a needs basis. Having had the courage of our convictions, we were utterly outraged that the Government, during the election campaign, should deliberately weaken its policy on this matter presumably to try to attract a few votes and then, before it had time to warm the government benches, toss it aside. This in an exercise in cynicism of which I think the electorate has had quite sufficient. Indeed, that was the reason why the electorate tossed out the Liberal-National Party Government. After so many years of breaking so many promises, the electorate could not stomach it any more and the Labor Government looks like heading down exactly the same track.
Item 12.6 of the Australian Labor Party's education document states:

Labor's approach when in government will be to discuss and to seek agreements with the non-government sector about a set of resource objectives for their schools which are appropriate to contemporary circumstances and achievable within a reasonable time.
That sounds perfectly acceptable. The document continues:

Provided agreements can be reached with school authorities, Labor will increase its recurrent support for low resource non-government schools to assist with closing the gap between their current level of resources and the agreed objectives.

In fact, the thrust of the entire 'Hayden Education Plan', as it was called at that stage when Mr Hayden was leading the Australian Labor Party, was this principle of consultation, a principle which the Labor Party has now made its hallmark in terms of dealing with a whole variety of issues, and more particularly, the economy. It is indeed a pity that in this most vital area of education the Labor Party has not seen fit to pursue detailed consultation. We had the excuse from the previous speaker, Senator Giles, that there was not enough time. There is always enough time to consult if one is on the government benches in as much as the decisions that are to be made are made at the behest of the Government. There was no pressure on members of the Government, except the one which they wished to create or accept themselves-of making any move in the Budget before they had time to draw up a detailed plan of how they wished to proceed with a needs base. I believe that that would have been much more equitable. I think it would have led to a lessening of the heat in this argument . Item 12.8 of the 'Hayden Education Plan' talked about the needs principle. It stated:
. . . a Labor Government will assess needs on a more comprehensive basis taking into account the capacity of the community to contribute . . .

I think no one would disagree with that item. What upsets the Australian Democrats is that the Government has not kept this commitment to seek a comprehensive basis for a needs program. It is a difficult matter. Presumably, some people, when thinking about institutions, tend to forget that they are populated by people. One of the major problems with the funding arrangements which we currently have-I believe that it is one which this Government is perpetuating and one which can never solve the acute education problems that exist in this country-is the continual operation of funding at an institutional level.

By and large the only way to tackle the real problems of education, many of which stem directly from poverty, is to attack the social problem-not the institution-that underlies it. A particular institution may be excessively well endowed, but if the child who goes to that institution happens to come from a family of five or six and lives in a house with only two bedrooms-perhaps honourable senators do not believe it, but they do exist in Australia; I have taught quite a number of children who have been in that type of circumstance-his or her capacity to study at home is reduced to almost zero. Regardless of the resource level of the school, those children are still in a deprived educational environment. No matter what the school has to offer, that can be offset only by direct assistance to those families to enable them to get additional tuition for their children and to enable those children to undertake studies in an easier environment, particularly at the secondary school level. For some reason that escapes me entirely, in this country we insist on directing ourselves totally and solely at the institution and staying away from the real problem of the family disadvantages that are built into the very system itself.

The Australian Democrats have spent a great deal of time with many people in the non-government sector discussing with them their problems. I have been quite critical in the past of many people in the non-government school sector for the way in which they have operated. I believe now that many people within that sector are willing to discuss education and are willing, in fact, to look at sensible compromises. I believe that now is the time to try to get people from all sectors in the education community to sit down together, away from media attention and those types of pressures where they cannot state their real feelings around a conference table, away from the situation in which they have to posture on behalf of their constituents, and get down to deal with what might be, and we hope would be, in the interests of them all; that is, to come up with some reasonable basic principles upon which those groups could agree as to how funding might proceed in the future.

I do not believe that it is beyond the wit of reasonable people who have the interests of children in this community at heart actually to devise a system that would be acceptable not only to the teachers' union but also to the non- government school sector. I believe that it is possible. I believe that the fact that it has not occurred is due to the unwillingness of government to grasp that essential problem and to bring together those groups of people so that they can discuss the matter away from the glare of any publicity and away from the need to make their positions definitive. I would even go so far as to say that anybody who is allowed to take part in such a conference ought to agree not to divulge anything said at the conference table to any person who had not taken part in the conference, but only to agree to a final communique principle. Having spoken with so many groups around Australia, I believe that they are capable of solving the problem. They are not capable of doing it at public meetings at which people, for their own political ends, whip up further sectarian divisions within this community. It can be done only in such a congenial and low key environment.

In the brief time which is left to me I turn to another item which is of extreme concern to the Australian Democrats, that is, the tertiary education assistance scheme. Item 2.2 of the 'Hayden Education Plan' maintained:
Improvements to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS), will . . . have three objectives:
To provide allowance at a realistic level;
to encourage more students to enrol in higher education;
to encourage more students from less privileged backgrounds to enrol in higher education.

That idea is laudable. The plan said that an ALP government would progressively increase TEAS; increase the maximum benefit to equate it with the single unemployment benefit; and liberalise the definition of 'independence'. What we have seen is, in fact, the exact opposite. We have seen a reduction in overall terms. We have seen the Government renege on each of those items. I believe the last item is the worst. The Government has failed to remove anomalies in the TEAS regulations or to liberalise the definition of independence, which it promised to do. The students are having as much difficulty now in getting TEAS as they were under the previous Liberal-National Party Government. I believe that that is to the detriment of tertiary education in this country and ultimately to the detriment of the entire country itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Those people who had been listening to this debate earlier today would have heard both Senator Peter Baume and Senator Baden Teague brilliantly expose the subject of today's debate, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government's broken promises and dishonoured assurances to the education community.

Let me endeavour to summarise very quickly the 15 broken promises or dishonoured assurances of this Australian Labor Party Government under the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). Firstly, in the realm of higher education, the Government promised post-doctoral fellowships for 300 scholars. That promise was not honoured. The Government promised to increase student assistance through the tertiary education assistance scheme until it equalled the single unemployment benefit and then to maintain the nexus. That promise was not honoured. The Government promised to raise the TEAS means test until it equalled average weekly earnings. That was not honoured. The Government promised to establish an emergency student loans scheme to replace the existing tertiary student loans scheme. That promise was not honoured.

Let me divert there for a moment to mention the enormous pressure that was put on students by disinformation last year when the then Federal Liberal-National Party Government introduced a student loans scheme to assist students to get through their tertiary education. What happened was that the Australian Labor Party tried to-in fact, it did-persuade many of those students to believe that this was a first step in the taking away of their TEAS allowance. Of course, it was not, but this disinformation caused great hardship at university and tertiary campuses around Australia. We were subjected to a lot of pressure because of that disinformation. What happened was that the loans scheme was taken away from the students of Australia and not replaced with anything, notwithstanding the promise, as I have said, to establish an emergency student loans scheme to replace the then student loans scheme. In other words, the promise was not only not honoured but, in fact, the scheme was cancelled and the students are now in a worse position.

The Government's promise to institute a new program for primary schools at a level of $9m per annum was not honoured. Its promise to provide an additional $ 37m in the first year of the Government for recurrent resources in government schools was not honoured. Its promise to provide an additional $16m in the first year of the program for needy non-government schools was not honoured. Its promise to provide $24m over three years for a computer education program was partly not honoured. Its promise to establish a revolving loan fund with an initial contribution of $5m to bring forward construction of planned new non- government schools was not honoured. Its promise for the funding of non- government schools was not honoured. I will come back to that. The Government's promise to provide a special triennial program in technical and further education to cost $30m to upgrade equipment and facilities for the latest technologies was not honoured. Its promise to provide an immediate boost of $15m in capital and recurrent funds to the States was not honoured. In migrant education, the Government's promise to provide $45m per capita grants for ethnic schools was not honoured. The promise to provide $3.68 per annum for transferring all eligible casual migrant teachers to permanent positions was not honoured. The people of Australia have been deceived by this Government and the Minister. They are now awakening to that problem, as is evident by the enormous number of complaints and meetings being conducted around this country. I refer specifically to the meeting of over a thousand people at Albury. They complained bitterly about the Government's broken promises on education. Senator Baume pointed out quite rightly that the people of Australia realise once again that they cannot trust the Labor Party.

Let me refer to an address given by Senator Ryan to the annual meeting of the Queensland Teachers Union on 26 June this year. In my view she demonstrated, in this speech, her divisiveness, sexism and deep prejudices in relation to education. I will quote parts of the speech. She said:
Public education is under attack.

Public education is not under attack. It is not public education which is under attack; it is the non-government schools which are under attack. The only attack which might exist in regard to government schools would be from those parents who are opting out of the government school system to send their children to non -government schools at their own enormous expense. During previous speeches Senator Gietzelt kept interjecting that if people want to send their children to another school let them pay for it. The people of Australia are opting out of the government system and paying for it at great sacrifice. I shall come to that in due course. Senator Ryan said:
Teachers and parents who are committed to public education need to reaffirm that commitment.

That is sheer rabble rousing and divisiveness by the Minister. Why is there any need to reaffirm that commitment? Of course, the people of Australia are committed to public education. They are desperately concerned about public education. She continued:

Public education is under attack from those who want to return to a golden age in which they believe schools produced students, one hundred per cent of whom were literate, numerate, obedient and employable.

That is a fascinating statement by the Minister. She is critical of those people who want students to be 100 per cent literate and numerate. The people of Australia of course want their educational institutions to produce literate children. We want our children to be able to read and write, not just to be employed, which is what Senator Ryan seemed to be going on about. We want to open up the culture of our society and give people the opportunity to be able to read what this nation is all about, to read the history of this nation and of the world, to study our literature, to study what is going on in the world and to understand what it is all about. Senator Ryan criticises those of us who want our children to be literate and numerate and those of us who want our children to be able to add up a hundred and to do their tables. Is there something wrong with that? The Minister would have us believe that there is something wrong with that. Let me go on with her address to establish that further. In stating what she believed education to be all about, she said:

. . . a capacity for creative thought and action, a capacity to live harmoniously in a multi-cultural, multi-racial society, a sense of self-esteem and identity sufficient to enable the individual to resist manipulation by the massive institutions of capitalism and to make autonomous decisions.

Those are the fine points of what the Minister believes education should be all about. She believes education should create a body of people in this nation who are able to resist the manipulation by the massive institutions of capitalism and to make autonomous decisions. It is no good honourable senators interjecting and implying that she is not putting that at the top of her priority list, because she is. She has quite clearly dismissed literacy and numeracy and put at the top of her list that we should teach children to have a capacity for creative thought. Is there any suggestion by any Government senator that people who were educated and who became literate and numerate do not have the capacity for creative thought? Is that something that has to be taught in our schools? Of course she is living in an unreal academic world. She talks absolute nonsense. She continued in this great speech:
The fact is, there is simply no evidence for the proposition that educational standards have fallen.

Of course, on her standards, she is able to say that. Of course, if she believes in those things that I have just talked about, she is able to say that there is no evidence for the proposition that educational standards have fallen. But why does she not look at the evidence of what the parents of the children of Australia believe today? Why does she think that the government school system is in trouble? Of course, the government school system is in trouble. Not only do the parents recognise this but so many teachers also recognise it. I feel sorry for the teachers. Let me quote from an article in the Canberra Times on 9 May this year:

The newly formed Professional Association of Classroom Teachers (PACT) . . . is one of many raised in recent years that have bemoaned the growing trend of anti- intellectualism in Australian education systems.

This is another one of the many teacher organisations being established around this nation which are so desperately concerned about the education of their pupils. I remind the Senate that my education history was totally in the government school system. I am proud of my history within the government school system. I can look back to the teachers who taught me with pride and remember the dedication they had to their service and their attitude towards their job. To have this Minister criticising teachers who try to teach literacy and numeracy within a community is absolutely appalling in my book. I have little time left, but the Minister went on to say in her speech:

Insofar as excellence in education has been traditionally available, it has been available to those who could pay for access to it and whose gender, social class and family wealth fitted them for its expectation.

What a terrible criticism that is of the teachers in the government schools system. What a terrible criticism it is for the Minister to say that the only excellence in education has been available in those schools in which parents could pay for the education of their children. This Minister has divided this nation. Already she has created an elitist system.

I turn now to a major question being considered around this country, that is, the question of state aid. Prior to the last election, Mr Hurford, the then shadow Minister for education, in travelling around this nation and endeavouring to seek the support of Catholics, other education authorities and various other people made all sorts of promises. In particular he said this:
We reject unequivocally the anti-state aid position being advanced by some in the community.
. . . we shall be responsible for ensuring that there is available to every Australian child a minimum level of resources for that child's education.
We hope to rid our society of the wasteful and divisive state aid debate.

Now, Mr Acting Deputy President, let me take up those words: 'We hope to rid our society of the wasteful and divisive State aid debate'. What it has in fact done is to raise the State aid debate. Let me quote from the Canberra Times of 13 October an article written by Monsignor John Kelly, which states:

Some old sores had healed during the 1960s and 1970s . . . partly from pragmatic and political considerations, but partly from a maturing of society. While this was welcome to most Australians, it caused alarm to some small but influential groups-the DOGS (with access to surprisingly large funds), the Communist Party of Australia, the Socialist Left of the ALP (with influence in formulating ALP policy on education), the teachers' federations, sections of the educational bureaucracies and some academic circles.
The persistence of these groups has now being to pay off in dividing society . . .
A trend has appeared in a variety of developments, converging to form a concerted attack on the funding of non-government schools.
There is the state aid debate, wide open. It was raised by Mr Santamaria of the National Civic Council in an article in the News Weekly in which he said:

. . . powerful forces connected with the Socialist Left of the ALP using the machinery of the new Labor governments, are intent on weakening and ultimately destroying the independent sector in education.

There is much more from Mr Santamaria which I could quote but I know that people on that side of the chamber will treat what he has to say with irrelevance so let me quote from the Canberra Times editorial of 8 October which states:

notwithstanding assurances from the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, that integration of government and non-government schools is not ALP policy and that the Government does not intend to proceed with the committee 's integration proposal, it has begun implementing policies that are both necessary and sufficient for integration.

So it is clear that this Minister is determined, in my book, not only to destroy the non-government system so far as the wealthy schools are concerned but also to integrate the Catholic system ultimately into the present government system. The Archbishop of Canberra-Goulburn, the Most Reverend Francis Carroll, made that very clear yesterday when he called upon this Government to promise a basic grant for every child.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleagues, I find it incredible that the Opposition and Senator Peter Baume in particular should have brought on this matter of public importance for debate today. Senator Baume was a member of the Government that was renowned for breaking promises. It is the Government that perhaps will go down in history as the one which has broken the most promises in its seven years of office. It certainly broke more than it kept . Honourable senators will recall the stories about the Prime Minister of the day. Many of those circulated through the corridors. They were amusing and all were true. Certainly I will not bore honourable senators with them now but let me say that nobody would ask him what the time was, that is for sure. The Ministers of that Government did the same thing as their Prime Minister. I can recall when Minister after Minister came to the Northern Territory and offered us the railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin. That started in about 1972. Of course, nothing was done. That was just one more of those promises. This was the time-1976 to 1983-when the credibility of all politicians dropped to its lowest level ever. I am surprised that the Opposition brought this matter on when it was the Government that is responsible for the economic mess we are in at this time, the mess that it passed on to us when we were trying to do something about the situation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make a few comments on the various speakers in this debate. The shadow Minister for Education who opened the debate waited until the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) had left the chamber so that he could make his vicious attack upon her. This shadow Minister who made statements about not being able to trust the Labor Government, in his first statement-I suppose we would call it a terminological inexactitude if we were on that side of the chamber-made the comment about the Minister not going to Sydney and not sending anyone in her place to a meeting. He then went on to make the most extraordinary comment that the present Government is one that is trying to divide school from school, system from system. If there is anything which characterises the shadow Minister at the present time, both in the chamber and outside it, it is that very element of divisiveness. He has obviously moved around the country trying to stir up trouble, certainly not the consensus that he talked about when he was in government. He was the one who used to call across the chamber: 'With a little understanding and a little consensus we will achieve our goals', but, of course, that meant doing what he wanted.

He then went on to talk about the Catholics, with whom he seems to have formed some sort of liaison at present, and to say how much they did not like what the Minister is doing. I refer to the Hansard of 14 September. The Minister in this place read letters from various Catholics indicating that a good relationship exists. Let me read a couple of them. The Minister said this:

First of all, I would like to read a telegram from the Reverend Father Doyle, the Director of the Catholic Education Office of Victoria, who telegrammed me immediately after the appearance of the guidelines and said this:

Commend you and your Government on budgetary provisions for 1984 to meet needs of Australian children. Balance in guidelines between government and non- government schools should forestall divisive debate.
It did not, of course. We have it from Senator Peter Baume. Senator Ryan then read from a letter from Archbishop James Carroll, who said:

As already intimated to you, the many positive initiatives of the Guidelines have given great encouragement to all concerned with the quality of schools and with the particular needs of the present time.
Mr Faulkner from the Catholic Education Office of Victoria said:
I write to you personally and as a Schools Commissioner to commend you and your Government on the quality of the Commonwealth Schools Commission Guidelines for 1984.

This is the group that Senator Baume says does not think much of what the Minister is doing. He went on to talk about the tertiary education assistance scheme. Let us look at the contribution Senator Baume made when he was in government. In 1978 there was no change in TEAS. In 1980-no change in TEAS; in 1982-no change in TEAS. This is the man who has the gall now to come in here-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—It is a fact. The honourable senator can read it from table 1 in the School Commission's report. He can get his table and have a look.
—That is not true; that is ridiculous.

—I do not talk nonsense. It is that side that uses bad arguments. I am not talking about the Commission's report. He can look at it himself. That is what we are saying. Senator Baume also said there were no capital funds to support increased participation. The fact, of course, is that the Government has increased capital funding by $3.8m, an increase of 8 per cent in real terms, to universities and colleges. Senator Teague, after acknowledging at the beginning of his speech that the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, and the Minister for Education had both had discussions with all groups, and commending them for this, then went on to talk about one or two select groups that he had spoken to. I suggest that he goes to as wide a group of people as did Mr Dawkins and the Minister. The honourable senator said that people cannot choose the school they want to go to. What a lot of nonsense this is. The Government acknowledges and accepts that parents exercise a choice in the education of their children but the extent to which that choice will be funded by the Government will be based on need, not on geographical location or on some proximity to any particular Minister's electorate. We will look at the important things.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague then spoke about the advisory committees and complained about its composition. I suppose Senator Teague would want us to do what his Government did when in government-that is to say that the right person to go on a committee, any committee at all, is a Liberal or perhaps even a National Party member, but certainly not a representative of the community. He then spoke about the nexus. I remind the shadow Minister what the Minister said in referring to the nexus. She said that the nexus is not a religious law or testament but rather a funding mechanism. The shadow Minister will know that the nexus discriminated against the poor and non-government schools under the Liberal Government. It will be replaced by a community standard that funds on the basis of need, and this is clearly what we have put forward. The Liberals do not have an education policy. They have never had an education policy. They have had a funding policy. They have no well articulated or other policy on education.

Senator Teague then went on to talk about logic but I am afraid it is not his strong point. Honourable senators will remember that, in the debate last week, Senator Teague was saying that it is the ALP's fault that there is not enough room in tertiary institutions. He was suggesting that after seven months in office, we have not built enough tertiary institutions to cope with the needs of the people. I will remind Senator Peter Baume and Senator Teague that when they came into office the problem was that the tertiary institutions had to go out and look for students to fill them up. There was an excess capacity. After seven years of Liberal rule, Senator Teague is able to stand up in this place and say that there is not enough room in our tertiary institutions.

Senator Macklin indicated that the debate was in some way connected with the Queensland elections. If that is the fact, perhaps we should just point out that Queensland, as a State, spends less on education per student than any other State in the Commonwealth. In 1980-81, while the national average expenditure per pupil at the primary level was $1,376, in Queensland it was $1,320, more than $50 less. At the secondary level, the gap was even greater. The national per pupil expenditure at secondary level was $2,232 while in Queensland it was only $1,928. But, that will change after Saturday and they will get a much better deal. The only comment I would make to Senator Lewis, because I was involved in something else, is to suggest that he have a look at the list. He said there were 15 areas that he would speak about. He only got to three and he did not do them very well. But let him look at the policies and the policy document and see what promises were made.

Let us remind ourselves of the March Federal election. It was early, as usual, because the Prime Minister of the day thought that he would be able to get back. Before we talk about these broken promises and assurances, let us have a look at how the Labor Party forms its policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Humph!

—All right, we will go on with something else, if that does not suit Senator Messner. Let us go back to the Prime Minister who thought that he would catch the Australian Labor Party on the hop. But of course he did not catch the Labor Party on the hop. He made two of those monumental mistakes that he was quite renowned for. The first one was to tell terminological inexactitudes and the second one was to make bad decisions. When the Labor Government came into office in March, it set its policies in train. It set the policies that will do so much for Australia, given some consensus and some assistance from the other side. But we need to hasten very slowly in these matters. The present Opposition had seven years in office and in that time it achieved very little of what it said it would achieve. We have had seven months. But let us say that we have more sense than to rush madly into the implementation of policies which might suit some of those select areas which the Opposition seems so keen about.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Messner does not want me to talk about the way the Labor Party develops its policies, let us talk about the way that the Liberals developed theirs. These are the people who have never had policies. When Menzies was in power, of course, he did not have any policies at all. He just plucked them out of the air. Then, because the Labor Party had them, the Liberals were shamed into producing a document and so they produced a platform. The only reason for that, of course, was to keep the young Liberals from criticising the Prime Minister of the day over some years. If they did not have the policies to talk about, they would get on to the Prime Minister.

Let me say quite clearly that the ALP policy was costed before the election. It was devised before the election. We work on our platform for years. Coming up to an election time-and this election was thrust on us 12 months early, as has been the case in the last four elections-we cost our proposals on the figures available to the people who will try to say: 'The education policy will cost this much,' or 'Within the framework that you have given us, that is what we can do.' But, of course, if the figures are wrong, if we are given the wrong figures or if somebody covers up the figures, some adjustment would have to be made. This is what the three speakers on the other side were not prepared to concede. If the money had been available, the policies would have gone forward exactly as they were articulated in the document that not one of the Opposition speakers has read. They have been making wild statements from outside the policy document . Quite clearly we can ask the question: What were the policies and were the figures accurate? If the figures were not accurate, what adjustments would have to be made?

Let us look at the second question first. We all know the answer to the question: Were the figures accurate? Senator Walsh has provided us with this information time and time again to the obvious embarrassment of the people on the other side of this chamber. The Budget deficit was to be $6 billion and the hidden figure was $9.6 billion. The costing was done, quite clearly as it should have been done, on the accepted figure which means that when the correct figure came to light, after the election of course-a certain discredited former Treasurer kept it hidden so that the people would not do anything about it-we found that we would have to make some changes. These changes-and this is what the Opposition is not prepared to accept at the present time-are completely the result of the mess that we inherited from the former Government. Now Opposition members have the gall to come into this place and criticise us for trying to work within the Budget imposed on us by its handling of the economy. In other words, the promises that we are talking about are the things that we suggest in our platform, in our policy speech. Honourable senators opposite know very well that the policy speech which is presented is the one that is worked on. That has not been the one that has been quoted by the speakers who have spoken today.

I would invite Senator Peter Baume who tells me he has read it and he probably has and then the other 'whydonchas?', the carping 'whydonchas?' on the other side of this chamber- to have a look at the policy document. It will be a novel experience for them. They have probably never before looked at documents that are actually followed. They look at a thing which is pretty on the outside but which is not followed when they get into government. I suggest that they stop searching waste paper bins, that they stop ferreting out clippings from various places, but look at the document and point out clearly where our policies have been enunciated and modified publicly and then say that we have not implemented them.

I should like to look very quickly, because of limitations of time, at the Aboriginal affairs policy. This would be of special interest to Senator Peter Baume, as he has had some responsibility for it in the portfolios concerned with education and Aboriginal affairs. He might like to compare his record, have a look at it and see what he did in the areas of education and Aboriginal affairs in the time when he was in office and compare that with what is happening at the present time. We had a claim by Senator Sir John Carrick that he would leave behind in the Northern Territory the best education system in Australia, the one that would act as a model for all the others to follow. I have catalogued in this place before today his inability to do this; and I will not repeat it. It is fair that I say nothing more about Senator Peter Baume than that he simply did not arrest the slide backwards from the Whitlam era. The policy said that we will have 1,000 Aboriginal teachers by 1990. This will be done. This has been put in train. We said that we would expand the role of the National Aboriginal Education Committee. This has been done. I would contend that the proposition brought forward by the Opposition today is not only carping but also in itself dishonest. An attempt has been made to go beyond our policy document, which is the only document to which we can refer, to try to make some spurious case which would denigrate the wonderful work being done by an outstanding Minister for Education, Senator Ryan. I move:
That the business of the day be brought on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is, I think, the thirteenth annual report of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. As is well known to all honourable senators, this Corporation is one with a remarkable history and one which is performing a very worthwhile role in Australia's development. It is certainly doing a great job, I believe, in promoting Australia's image as a consultant engineer and promoting Australia's image as one of the leading technological nations and consequently offering income from overseas in that particular area as well.

I think it is a little disappointing that the report reveals a very big change in the financial position of the Corporation in the last financial year. It shows that profit has dropped from a little over $2.5m in the last financial year to a sum of only $41,500 in this financial year. That is somewhat disappointing considering that the turnover for the year was $56m. That turnover apparently did not grow to any great degree above the turnover of the previous year. From a quick reading of the report I do not think clear reasons are given for the fall in the total revenue of the Corporation. At some stage I would like the Government to give some amplification of that point.

On the other hand, the report is very clear in respect of the kinds of projects that are being undertaken, particularly overseas. Very clear reference is made to operations being undertaken in Bangladesh and the Yemen. There are 20 other assignments all over the world. Within Australia a number of works are being undertaken in the States. These include the largest project, the Wivenhoe pump storage scheme in Queensland which, through the power station of the same name, will improve power supplies throughout the whole State.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the significant downturn in the operations of the Corporation in the last financial year. I think it is significant that this has occurred, although the report reveals that the Corporation has taken steps to redress the problems by retrenching staff and cutting overhead costs in a number of ways. That action certainly is to be welcomed. On the other hand, attention is drawn in the report also to the appointment of private consultants to investigate these questions. I wonder whether the report of those consultants will be made available to the Parliament in the same way as this very important report has been made available so that all honourable senators can get a further insight into the problems that have caused this downturn in the last financial year.

Clearly, the Corporation is to be commended. Its operations and general management have been well known to honourable senators over the years. It has a grand history, one of which I believe all of us should be proud. I hope that its good work in developing Australia will continue. I hope that in future it will continue in its efforts to provide technological developments to the rest of the world. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 204th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts on expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate a tabling statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The 204th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts is an examination of the expenditure from the advance to the Minister for Finance ( Appropriation Acts 1981-82).

The advance to the Minister for Finance is a provision authorised by the annual Appropriation Acts and made available to the Minister. In 1981/82 amounts of $ 125m and $100m were provided for this purpose in Appropriation Acts Nos 1 and 2 respectively.

The only amounts which should remain a charge to the appropriations for the advance to the Minister for Finance at the end of the financial year are urgent and unforeseen expenditures which arise between the time of preparation of the additional Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 and the close of the financial year. In its examination the Committee seeks to ascertain whether or not expenditure from the advance has been confined to urgent and unforeseeable requirements for which provision could not have been made in the original or additional estimates .

The Committee has required Departments to submit explanations for all items of expenditure. As from 1982/83 copies of all Departmental applications for funds from the advance which will remain a final charge to the advance at 30 June are forwarded by the Department of Finance to the Committee as soon as possible after approval is granted. We expect to complete our examination of the use of the advance in 1982-83 before the House rises.

For 1981/82 the commitee received 118 explanations for items included in the Minister's statement in August 1982. Supplementary written information was obtained in respect of eleven items and one item only, Government Printer-loss on operations, was selected for public inquiry.
The operations of the Government Printing Office are funded from the Government Printer Trust Account. The committee found that:
The financial statements on the Government Printer's operations are not required to be published and are not subject to Commonwealth Audit;
A loss on operations of $312,989 was sustained because of
A reduction in Parliamentary work
Industrial disputes
Quotes for certain jobs at lower than established rates
Three national wage decisions instead of two as expected
Insufficient work was directed to the Government Printer
The Government Printer experiences considerable difficulty in matching capacity with workloads;
The Printing Office is unable to operate in the way a commercial printer would;
Some accounts rendered by the Government Printer on client Departments remained unpaid for over twelve months.

The committee noted with concern that there were no formal written objectives for the Government Printing Office and that the charter of responsibilities being formulated over the last three years had not been completed. The committee also found difficulties with financial management and accountability of the Government Printer's Operations and aspects of its relations with client Departments.
The Committee responded by recommending that

The financial statements on the Government Printer's operations be made subject to Commonwealth audit as a matter of urgency. (I note that the Auditor-General tabled a report on the Government Printing Office on 6 September this Year).
A review of the Financial Management Information Systems be conducted urgently.
An urgent review be undertaken of the Government Printer's billing and accounts receivable systems and
The requirements Departments must follow in procuring printing are to be stated in unequivocal terms. Inspection mechanisms should also be in place to ensure that the requirements are observed.

In connection with the relationship between the Government Printer and its clients, the committee is extremely critical of delays in the payment of accounts by client Departments contribute to the inefficiency of the Government Printer's Operations. The committee again reminds all Departments of their obligations, as set out in finance regulations and directions, to pay accounts promptly.

The Committee considers that in view of the important role played by the Government Printer in meeting the Parliament's Printing requirements, it is imperative that the Government Printer's viability be assured. A Permanent Head is responsible for the efficient management of his Department's resources and is therefore required to obtain the best value for money in meeting his printing requirements. The committee supports the examination of the funding options which aim to enhance the competitiveness of the Government Printer and thereby attract the necessary fill-in, non parliamentary work.

Following an examination of supplementary information the committee is satisfied that in most cases the expenditure from the advance to the Minister for finance in 1981-82 was confined to urgent and unforeseeable requirements for which provision could not have been made in the appropriations acts.

The Committee has also taken note of comments by the Auditor-General at paragraph 20.2 of his May 1983 report. The Auditor-General points to the possibiity that Departments avoid recourse to the advance by deferring payment of due amounts. The Committee would regard this action as totally unacceptable in that it could not only result in avoidance of proper Parliamentary scrutiny but also is contrary to finance directions. It is imperative that the Commonwealth is seen to be a prompt payer of its bills!
I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 September 1983, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, to which I am pleased to have contributed and which is aptly titled 'Two Hundred Years Later', is an encouragement to take stock of what has occurred in the relationship between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians over the last 200 years and to look to the future in a positive and constructive way. The subject is incredibly complex and difficult although the concept of makarrata is in fact simple. The concept is a coming together, a recognition of the failings of the past but now a determination to make a new beginning, a new start. This has been the sentiment of most of those advocating a makarrata or a compact. They have said that there needs to be a settlement of the disputes and shortcomings of the past and agreement on what is necessary in the future to enable a new relationship to come into being. This is, however, when difficulties begin.

SPEECH.PARA: There is much in the early history of white settlement which must be regretted but the concept of successors of the settlers or subsequent immigrants paying a price for wrong doings of previous generations is not easy to sell. In fact, in the concept of today's non-Aboriginal generation paying to today's Aboriginals compensation for failings of past generations, there is the seed for the very disunity and racial intolerance which a makarrata is designed to overcome. It is a delicate matter. Furthermore, time has marched on and it is not possible to go back 200 years and say: 'Let us start again and we'll do it differently'. Much Aboriginal land has been lost to settlement, to agriculture and to industry. Much of the culture, language and law has been lost. A great deal of integration of lifestyles has taken place. Two centuries of intermarriage and interrelationship have had a profound effect. Additionally, I see great danger in the concept of self-government advocated by some more radical Aboriginal groups-wrongly, I believe, but nevertheless advocated within the makarrata umbrella. I strongly believe in one nation and that Australia must remain so. We now all constitute one Australia.

These difficulties exist even without looking to the content of the settlement. The answer of governments to these difficulties-and it has been the easy answer- has been to treat Aboriginals as another disadvantaged group in Australian society and attempt to improve their lot from that approach. The difficulty with that rationale is that the community then looks to Aboriginals receiving similar support to that received by other disadvantaged groups, and concepts such as the returning of land appear out of step and resentment builds. The kernel of the makarrata argument is, on the other hand, a recognition that the Aboriginal people have a legitimate right to claims, such as land, not as a disadvantaged group within the Australian community but as recognised prior owners of the Australian continent. In accordance with this recognition, certain consequences, set out in the terms of granting land rights and compensation and other rights to the descendants of those original owners of the land, would be seen to flow.
The Senate has previously accepted the prior ownership argument. The call for compensation then follows, in the terms of the report, from:

the absence of any negotiated agreement by Aboriginal people to the British occupation and settlement of Australia and the subsequent dispossession and ill- treatment of the Aboriginal people by the new settlers and their descendants.

The British settlers, of course, saw no need to negotiate or come to agreement over the terms of their occupation, because it was regarded in law that the country was not conquered or ceded but peacefully settled-a concept that has served as the basis for the settled colony principle, whereby the law has regarded Australia at the time of white settlement as terra nullius or land belonging to no one. But there is now a growing appreciation of evidence that there was in existence at the time of white settlement an Aboriginal people with a complex system of social, cultural and religious networks and of land tenure.

If this understanding existed at the time of settlement, the whole legal basis of the occupation and the rights of prior inhabitants may have been different. As a question of international law, the argument is now too late. But that does not alter the attitude that we as legislators should take, which presumably is based on our perception of what is right and proper; and on a moral basis it appears to me that the descendants of the original inhabitants have a good case for compensation or reparation as having been wrongly dispossessed. The form of such reparation is important because it must be consistent with the overall goal of building a strong, united, just Australia.

Reparation is usually seen as-and I take two recommendations of the original Aboriginal Treaty Committee-the recognition and restoration of rights to land by applying, throughout Australia, the recommendations of the Woodward Aboriginal Land Rights Commission; and compensation to Aboriginal Australians for the loss of traditional lands and for damage to those lands and to their traditional way of life. But that is only part of the makarrata. There is the new attitude that is to follow, according to the makarrata concept. That is, a growing knowledge of and pride by both Australian Aboriginals and Australian non-Aboriginals in Aboriginal identity, law, language and culture. It appears to me that these goals can be achieved without a makarrata, and to varying degrees they are being so achieved.

I have tended to firm in my view that the concept of makarrata is not a prerequisite to achieving such goals and in fact it involves so many extraneous difficulties that it might be counter-productive. I think that is the particularly constructive contribution of the Committee when it has looked to the legal and constitutional feasibility of the makarrata. It looked at the treaty proposal and found the problems of sovereignty, and if the goal is, as I have stated, a strong, unified Australia, in any event I would question the desirability of pursuing the concept of a treaty.

The Committee considered the alternative of an agreement with constitutional backing either incorporated totally within the Constitution or in a general section giving the Commonwealth power to negotiate an agreement under various heads that would be binding on all. I for one have considerable reservations about expecting the Australian public to sanction an agreement the terms of which are not on the table; and I am concerned that a referendum campaign might in fact prove divisive when the very objective is to overcome division. An agreement with legislative backing has been suggested and examined. But I foresee difficulties in the State-Commonwealth relationship. One of the difficulties currently existing is that State governments are pursuing different policies in relation to what should really be a question of national principle. This leads to the fourth alternative of a simple agreement, and I suspect that a lack of status and also the problems of who would negotiate such an agreement indicate that it would not be the perfect alternative. Who would negotiate for the Aboriginals and, even more so, who would, on their behalf, be a party to such an agreement has remained a major obstacle.

Therefore, in some ways I see the makarrata as looking for a simple answer to a difficult problem. I do not believe that we can simply say 200 years later that we will enter into an agreement and that relationships will be substantially changed for the better. The circumstances in light of 200 years history are not even comparable to the North American, New Zealand and Alaskan experiences that are often quoted to us. The difficulties are enormously more diversified and complicated. Really what is needed is a change of attitude. To some extent that is already occurring. Many Australian Aboriginals now live as owners of their own land. The Australian Law Reform Commission continues to work on the subject of the place of customary law in Australia's legal system.

As I have mentioned, there has been a resurgence of pride on the part of many Aboriginals. We now have also Aboriginal diplomats, lawyers and educators. Soon Aboriginals will be seen in all roles of Australian life, and those who choose such goals should be encouraged. Others have sought traditional tribal life and many now have a better opportunity to achieve that aspiration. Whatever lifestyle is chosen, each should have pride in the achievements and culture of the Australian Aboriginal.

As I said earlier, an essential ingredient in a new relationship is not only a resurgence of the Aboriginal's pride in his race and his heritage, but an education of non-Aboriginal Australians that they should also have pride in that heritage. Such an education, a change of attitude and awareness take time. They can be facilitated by the teaching of Aboriginal studies in the school system. I have considerable sympathy also with the concept of National Aboriginal Day being a national holiday-a day for recognition and respect of the unique part that Aboriginals play as the original inhabitants of this now multiracial and multicultural society.

With a greater understanding of the history of white settlement, of the dispossession of the Aboriginal of his land, of his culture and the part that land plays in that culture, of the unique contribution that the Aboriginal can make in our society-the Australia of the future-there will come about the objectives of the makarrata, as they are already coming about, but in a way that will not be divisive but, as I have stated, as a contribution to a united and just Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably inappropriate that I be conclusive in my observations because I was not on the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for the duration, only for the part during which the majority of the evidence was gathered. The terms of reference do not refer to desirability, so that in itself relieved the Committee of having to make some important determinations. I say at the outset that even the word 'makarrata' was most unsuitable and, in my view, is most unsatisfactory as a name for an agreement of any type between the Commonwealth and Aboriginal Australians. I suspect that somehow it was not chosen by accident. As the report of the Committee shows, 'makarrata' is an Aboriginal word from north-east Arnhem Land, commonly describing the coming together after a struggle, a ceremony at which the aggrieved party almost invariably lets blood, death on some occasions occurring. I ought to point out that such a ceremony does not always signify the conclusion of the feuding. Very often the fued goes on. This demonstrates that the very title makarrata does not suggest a coming together with good will in a sense of co-operation but rather a blood sport or a retribution on the part of one party towards another.
—That is why we gave it up.

—There are those who still seek to use the word. I notice that the report uses it more often than I would have thought appropriate. Other names have been put forward as a substitute. In my view the word 'compact' is unsatisfactory. I think Senator Gareth Evans suggested that.
—By definition, it is unsatisfactory.

—Yes. Of course if one bothered to read the Bible- Senator Evans claims he does not: and that he has no knowledge of Christianity- one would know that most compacts in the Bible ultimately resulted in some sort of blood-letting also. So, the name may seem irrelevant and inconsequential. I notice that the word 'treaty' was given considerable currency for a period; however, the word in itself implies an internationally recognised agreement between two nations. The judges in the case of Coe v. the Commonwealth found that the Aboriginal people did not have Australia as a nation. Many matters are considered by some to be appropriate to be contained within the agreement. I refer to demands such as:

SPEECH.PARA: return of tribal lands including sacred sites and freehold title-should be taken up . . .
compensation in cash as percentage of GNP or percentage equivalent to Aboriginal proportion of total Australian population . . .
compulsory employment of a fixed proportion of Aboriginal people in government bodies . . .
substantial land and resource rights, including land 'vested in freehold title to the Aboriginal people' . . .
extensive self-government in 'tribal territories' . . .
five per cent of GNP for 195 years . . .
extensive welfare services such as Aboriginal medical services, legal aid, schools;
extensive tax exemptions.

These are but a few of the items which are included in the proposals. In my view the essence and the heart of this inquiry is inextricably tied to land rights of an inalienable type. That of course raises the question of the legal position which, I notice, has been given some attention by the Committee in its conclusions. To this extent the terms 'invasion' and 'settlement' take on a particular significance, without going into it in great detail, under the doctrine of terra nullius, which means that land belonging to no one, or a piece of territory not under sovereignty of any State, is deemed to have been settled. That includes land which is occupied but in which there is no recognisable political, social or economic structure. On the basis of the British Government' s 1770 determination that no such structure existed, the country of Australia was deemed to have been settled. Of course, had that not been the case the land would have been deemed to have been occupied by invasion. The distinction is that land obtained through agreement or conquest was held to be already vested in its inhabitants and the British Government recognised their prior ownership.

There has been much debate in recent times as to whether Australia was settled or invaded, for the reasons I have just outlined. If Australia is regarded as settled, Australian Aboriginals do not have a legal claim; if Australia is regarded as invaded then of course they do have a legal claim to Australia. That argument has been tested on more than one occasion, including the Blackburn case , in which it was found that Aboriginal Australians did not have legal title and that Australia came into the category of a settled or occupied colony.

That matter was again subject to litigation in the case of Coe v. the Commonwealth. The plaintiff claimed to sue on behalf of the Aboriginal community . He claimed that Britain failed to recognise the existing sovereignty of the Aboriginal people. In addition it was claimed that Australia had been acquired by conquest. As we know, that case also failed. That being so, one is moved to ask: On what basis should land rights be granted? On what basis and on what premise should that provision be contained within an agreement between the Commonwealth and the Aboriginal people of Australia? The Committee calls, quite properly so in my view, for a better understanding between all Australians. That of course begs the question-

TALK.START.PARA: —Where would you put yourself in the political spectrum?

—I would probably occupy the middle ground. Is the law and the number of determinations in respect of original ownership wrong in principal or wrong morally, or was the British determination at the time of settlement wrong? Should land rights be granted to seek to preserve the traditional life style of some Aboriginals? Should land rights be given by way of compensation for past ill-treatment? Should land rights be created to provide a source of permanent on-going self-funding for Aboriginal groups? I believe that all those who are committed to land rights need to give this matter proper consideration and declare a proper public position so that this may be the subject of a sensible and logical debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course one needs to ask the obvious questions. Where will Australia be in 50 to 100 years time in respect to the community as a whole? Will Aboriginals in some cases still retain their traditional life styles or will we have hundreds and perhaps thousands of inalienable acres of land held by absentee land owners? I found, during the period the Committee was taking evidence, that the greatest complaint of many elders was that they were unable to persuade the young people to maintain their traditional life styles; rather they wanted to gravitate towards the metropolitan areas. I believe that in order to have proper debate on and proper understanding of this question of land rights there ought to be a much more frank, open and honest contribution from those who support it. They should seek to explain on what premise, on what basis and on what principle they support land rights.

I commend the Committee for its report. I think the first part of the report contains considerable subjective judgment. The Committee noted that people are now becoming aware and conscious of the type of nation that Australia was at the time of settlement and that it had a community with greater economic, social and cultural values than were recognised at that time. I think there is a type of unreality about that statement. I notice some reference was made to the Noonkanbah case, suggesting that a misunderstanding existed but, by and large, I think the Committee has done a very fine job.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robertson)-by leave-proposed:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Electoral reform is a subject in which I have been vitally interested for a number of years, both before and after being elected to the Senate. In 1979 and again in 1980 when the Australian Labor Party was in Opposition in the Senate I moved that a select committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report upon a number of issues including all provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, public disclosure of the sources and the amounts of donations to political parties and to candidates, and also the public funding of political parties and candidates. The Labor Party did not have the numbers at that stage and the Committee was never established. Therefore I am extremely pleased that one of the first acts of the Labor Government was to set up the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which is very similar to the select committee that I proposed in 1979 and again in 1980. It is also pleasing to have the Committee reporting to the Parliament only six months later.

SPEECH.PARA: There had never been a complete overhaul of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and this report, therefore, is long overdue. Senator Withers and Senator Chaney are now in opposition in the Senate. When they were the Ministers concerned with the Electoral Act both promised a full review. Both Ministers publicly expressed dissatisfaction with the existing electoral laws. They in turn were followed as Minister for Administrative Services by Mr John McLeay who, in answer to a question in the House of Representatives, also said that our electoral system needed review. But what was done? Absolutely nothing!

In 1976 in a speech in the Senate I pointed out that the electoral legislation concerning elections to the Senate-that is, the method of casting a formal vote and the method of counting votes-was introduced in 1948 and was badly in need of reform. In 1983 it is still badly in need of reform. I do not have time this evening to go into great detail concerning the method of counting votes for election to the Senate. But I point out that any procedure that involves a vote on 13 December one year, the result of which is not known until 6 February the next year, is urgently in need of review. That was the situation in 1975 in the election in New South Wales for the Senate. What a farcical sitution it would be if the government elected to the House of Representatives did not know for nearly two months who was going to control the Senate, especially if we compare this situation-one that could occur in Australia-with the situation that exists in the United States of America and Great Britain.

In the United States the result of the election for the President, the Congress and the Senate is known within a matter of days. In Great Britain, with over 500 seats in the House of Commons, the result of an election is known within a matter of only two or three days. Any system in which a recount results in 10, 000 fewer formal votes than in the original count is in need of review. Any system in which the donkey vote decides seats and, therefore, ultimately who controls the Senate, is in need of review. It has been estimated that in New South Wales up to 25,000 votes are donkey votes if the Senate ballot paper is complicated. In New South Wales a few years ago we had a ludicrous state of affairs. The Liberal Party received 22,000 preference votes from the Socialist Workers Party, which was a Trotskyist group. In fact, the 25,000 donkey votes were not genuine votes that were meant to go to the Liberal Party-

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably a thousand were genuine.

—A thousand were probably genuine, but at least 22,000 of the 25, 000 donkey votes were votes that went straight to the Liberal Party. The Committee's report recommends a list system which will not make it compulsory to fill in every square of the ballot paper. This will certainly correct this sitation.

SPEECH.PARA: The present system disadvantages the elderly, the infirm, Aborigines and migrants and one must wonder why the Liberal-National parties persistently discriminated against these people. Perhaps it was because they suspected that a large proportion of these people would vote for the Labor Party rather than for their parties. The situation that occurred in 1974 highlights the seriousness of this problem. Australian political history would have been changed if either the sixth ALP candidate in New South Wales or the fifth ALP candidate in Queensland- our colleague Senator Colston, who is now a member of the Senate-had been elected at that time. But those candidates were not elected. We have to ask ourselves why they were not. The reason was not because they did not attract enough votes, but because thousands of people who tried to vote for them made a simple mistake and cast an informal vote. Thousands of people conscientiously tried to vote formally. People with bad eyesight made mistakes transferring marks from the how-to-vote card when they had filled in 32 or 33 of the squares. Even though they had voted correctly to that stage, their vote was cast aside. Some people filled out the ballot paper completely and only missed one number, yet their vote was made informal along with hundreds of thousands of others throughout Australia. I am pleased to say that this situation will not occur in future if the Select Committee's report is adopted, as I am sure it will be.

I now turn to the subject of public funding of elections. Why is the Opposition worried about the issue of public funding? Why have the Opposition members of this Parliament and the New South Wales Opposition called public funding corrupt , especially when it can be argued that the most democratic of countries have some form of public funding? I instance France, Holland, the United States, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Belgium, Switzerland, West Germany, Italy and Canada, to name but a few. Public funding has been in existence for over a decade in a number of these countries. These countries have working parliamentary democracies at a time when the number of parliamentary democracies around the world are declining. In fact, it could be argued that public funding has made these countries more democratic.

I believe that the reason this Opposition is terrified of public funding is that it would have to account for the money it receives for its election campaigns. We know that millions of dollars-$5m or $6m in the 1980 campaign, and certainly more in the 1983 election campaign-came to the Liberal and National Parties. That money was completely unaccounted for. We do not know where 1c of those millions of dollars came from. Public funding has already been an issue in an election in Australia. In New South Wales this issue was one of the Liberal- National Party coalition's main areas of criticism of the New South Wales State Labor Government. Full page advertisements in the Sydney Morning Herald costing $7,000 attacked the Labor Government's proposal for public funding. It did not hit the deck as an election issue and the Labor Government increased its majority.

In 1962 President Kennedy in the United States said that some form of public funding was inevitible with the way that costs were rising in the United States. He proposed a commission on campaign costs. This proposal was not acted upon until after Watergate, which made public funding possible in the United States. In the last United States presidential campaign, President Reagan received $21m in public funding. Does the Opposition think that President Reagan is corrupt because he accepted this public funding? On 20 August 1981, during a debate in the Senate on public funding, Senator Baume said:

To seek or to accept a public subsidy is a political party's admission of failure. That it should need to look to public funding is an admission that it cannot get support from those who should be attracted by the force of its ideas and its ideology. The need for public funding reflects a lack of confidence in the acceptability of the party's objectives, a lack of confidence in its policies, a lack of confidence in its performance and an unwillingness to make the necessary efforts to raise its own funds. It is an assertion by an unsuccessful and failed party . . .

At that stage, of course, he way saying that the New South Wales Liberals would never accept public funding. The National Party in New South Wales was not that silly. It decided that it would accept public funding. After the money had been paid both to the Labor Party and to the National Party, the New South Wales Liberals announced that they would be taking part in public funding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform on one particular issue-public funding of elections. Every speaker who has taken part in this debate so far has mentioned public funding but has spoken about it as if we have never had public funding at a Federal level in this country before and that we do not have it now. That is a myth which I think needs to be extinguished once and for all. In Australia at the moment we do, in fact, have a very thriving public funding system for election campaigns. Not only is it thriving, it is also highly inequitable. It is a system which relates more to how much a particular candidate spends and to how much that particular candidate earns than to any electoral support that candidate might receive.

SPEECH.PARA: It operates in this way: If a candidate for an election chooses to spend $20, 000 on his or her election campaign and retains all the receipts for that expenditure, at the end of that financial year that candidate can claim it as a tax deduction. The Government then generously returns, as part of his or her rebate, that proportion of the expenditure that related directly to how much that particular person earned in that financial year. The amount earned determines the marginal tax rate, which determines how much the candidate receives as a tax refund. Let us take as an example two candidates in two separate electorates, who both spend $10,000. Let us assume that one of those candidates earns $15,000 a year. We will leave aside the fact that on that amount of money he probably could not afford to spend 10 grand on an election campaign. The tax rate for the candidate earning $15,000 a year is 30c in the dollar. As a taxation refund he will get back one-third of that $10,000. So, the Government refunds him slightly more than $3,000. If the other candidate who spends $10,000 is earning, say, $50,000 a year, his marginal tax rate is 60c in the dollar and he gets back slightly in excess of $6,000 of the $10,000 he spent on his campaign. So, to say that we do not have public funding in this country overlooks the fact that the taxation system has been used for many years in order to fund a particular candidate's campaign expenses.

Prior to a change by the Fraser Government a couple of years ago, there was a limit on the amount anybody could spend. In 1981, the Commonwealth Electoral Act was changed so that unlimited moneys can be claimed as a tax deduction, providing only that receipts are held to prove that the money was spent on that particular candidate's personal campaign and not as part of the Party campaign. I know that, when I was in Western Australia during the March election this year , it was fairly common knowlegde that one of the Liberal candidates was spending something in excess of $21,000 of his money on his own campaign. That of course overlooks, too, another inequity, that is, that the more one earns, the more one is able to spend on an election campaign. So, it is not merely a case of how much one gets back through the tax system; the mere fact that a person earns a large amount of money means that he is in a position to spend a large amount of money on his election campaign.

The other method by which the public has been for many years funding political parties is a device by which companies which do not wish to have it made public that they have been donating money to a particular political party offer the political party of their choice the use of their advertising companies.
