Advertising for the political party is placed with an advertising agent who puts it on the advertising account of the particular company concerned, and that charge is then credited to that company so that it becomes, in itself, a tax deduction. A system in which a candidate and a political party are funded by the public only to the extent to which they receive public-that is, electoral- support at an election is a considerable improvement. It has been needed for many years and I sincerely hope that both sides of this chamber support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to make a short speech, which is all that time constraints will permit, in respect of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I say in the first place that that report, which was arrived at very quickly by the Committee, is a credit to all members of the Joint Committee because it covers a great number of matters that have been of concern to many people in the electoral area for many years and I think its general submissions and general solutions are, on the whole, very sensible. It received some 212 submissions from the public and from other sources. It has made 132 recommendations. When one considers that there has been only a little public debate about one or two items, it is important that people get the report and read it all because the report and the dissenting reports are most worthy of study.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to deal with only a few aspects of the report, as that is all that is possible in the short time available. I believe that there are two particular dangers in the report-two recommendations which are most unwise-and other recommendations which are most unpopular but I think wise. In the first place, the report proposes that redistributions be carried out by the Australian electoral commission. The setting up of the Australian electoral commission is an excellent idea; taking redistribution out of the hands of politicians and putting it into the hands of officials to whom representations can be made is important. One of the significant weaknesses in the proposal however is that a redistribution will not come before the Parliament; the Parliament will not have a chance to comment and make suggestions. I believe this is unwise. It should come back to the Parliament so that it can make suggestions, although of course it would leave all fundamental decisions to the electoral commission. I think, therefore, that this is an omission in the report.

The second matter-some mention has been made of it today-is the proposed 'list' system for voting in the Senate. There are some excellent proposals as far as Senate voting is concerned, including the one whereby, if people make a mistake in marking a very long Senate ballot, the ballot will be counted up to the stage where the mistake is made. I think that is wise and will save a lot of votes being rejected as they have been in the past. But I find the 'list' system proposal highly unwise.

Only a few moments ago Senator Sibraa spoke about how the Liberals, at some stage, got the accidental preferences of the socialist workers who were on top of the ballot and followed by the Liberals, and he found that somewhat extraordinary. Imagine what will happen if we have the 'list' system. A person will put a number in a square, indicating that he wants to vote for a particlar list, thereby implying preferences to all the people who make up that list. It means that there will be a great scramble to get to the top of the list. Organisations and parties will put up groups-probably bogus groups-or lists of individuals, hoping to win the ballot and get to the top of the list.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read the section relating to political parties? You need 500 members before you can put a political party in a list.

—Yes, but the fact is that great benefit can be found in this. It means that by winning the top of the list a party can thereby direct voting across the ballot as it likes. Instead of being a matter of accident it will be a matter of design. I put it to the Senate that it certainly should avoid that system. Time does not allow me to go into detail on this aspect today but I believe that is one of the follies of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to a proposal put forward in the report-no doubt it is unpopular in the public's eye-which relates to the size of Parliament, to the increasing of Parliament by 12 senators and 24 or 25 members of the House of Representatives. Of course it is very easy to take a populist view and say that it is never the time to increase the size of the Parliament. I refer to the interesting dissenting report by Senator Sir John Carrick, who does not think that this is the time. He very succinctly puts the case for an increase though he opposes it and he sets out questions that are raised. I will demonstrate my argument for this proposal by answering the questions that he poses. He points out that many arguments have been raised for an enlarged Parliament. Indeed there are, because we have one of the smallest national parliaments in the world. The Canadian House of Commons has 280 members, our House of Representatives has 120.

To my mind, the salient reason for an increase is not just the fact that members are representing many more than they were and have much heavier tasks but also the fact that the executives of the parties in the Parliament have too great control. If we have nearly 30 ministers and a number of people who hope to be ministers, we have too big a predominance in the Houses of the Parliament, on both sides, of people who have ministerial positions or aspirations. I believe that this is one of the fundamental reasons for increasing Parliament's size. If we could get into the Parliament a number of members who have an interest in being effective parliamentarians and who do work, we will have achieved something.
When these questions were raised, as I said, Sir John Carrick pointed out some facts. He asked:
Is there justification for a larger Senate, whether to fulfil its evolving responsibilities or simply to enable the enlargement of the House of Representatives?

I believe there is a strong case for a larger Senate; I believe that these days the Senate membership cannot cover the work of its own committees. If anything, there is a better case for an increased Senate than there is for an increased House of Representatives. Senator Sir John Carrick continues:
Is a Senate of 72 members . . . inclined to deadlock?
This is the fundamental point which he raises and for which I think there is a lot of argument. I will come back to that. He goes on to say:
Would the public now support the breaking of the nexus . . .

In that case, the size of one House could be increased without affecting the other House. I do not think that that matters very much, and I do not think that the public would carry such a proposal. As I say, I think there is a good case for increasing the size of the Senate. Coming back to the main point, if we increase the number of senators in each State from 10 to 12, with six senators going out at each election, it is quite correct that there will be deadlocks and probably no party will have a majority in the Senate at all. There will probably be a situation in which one or two senators will be able to dominate and control the Senate. I believe that is undesirable and it is not in any way 'practicable' to take steps that will do that. It is obvious that deadlocks will occur because it needs only 43 per cent of the vote to elect three senators in any State. With preferences, that result will be achievable by the major parties-the Labor Party and the coalition on this side of the House. However, a party would need 57 per cent of the vote for four of its candidates to be elected to six vacancies. That position will never be achieved. I do not think it has been achieved in recent times. So we can see a situation in which there will be deadlocks and a lack of a majority even for a popular government. Under such an arrangement, governments will have no opportunity to gain a majority in the Senate.

Moreover, Senate elections conducted under this system would be uninteresting. There would be no point in the public getting very worried about an election because there would not be a fifth position. The extra postion would go to the candidate of one major party or the other. This will almost invariably mean that whoever the party selects will be elected. A candidate will be elected whether his is placed No. 1, No. 2 or No. 3 on the party ticket. So this proposal is one way of reducing the importance of the Senate.

Unfortunately I cannot now refer to the good things that are in this report, which I would like to do. There is an easy solution to this problem I have raised, and that, at one election, is to elect five senators in three States and seven in the other three States. At the time of the next half Senate election three years later seven senators from the first three States and five from the other three would be elected. This proposal would preserve the importance of having uneven numbers and would solve the problem of deadlocks.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be unconstitutional.

—It would not be unconstitutional. Section 13 of the Constitution requires that after each election senators from a State shall be put into two different divisions-the first and second divisions-and they shall be, as far as practicable, equal in number. It does not say that they have to be equal in number. I say there is nothing practicable in the solution of having six senators elected at each election. Such a proposition is absolutely fundamentally hopeless. I think the public would gladly agree to a constitutional amendment to solve this matter if it were required. However, I do not believe that that would be necessary. It is my belief that this solution I have raised is easily achievable. The idea of increasing the size of the Parliament by having six senators elected from each State at each election would reduce the Senate to futility and could not be supported. I find the report very valuable. Marvellous things have been done in it. However, there are some things in it that need to be looked at still further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a few minutes to deal with a couple of points with regard to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. At the outset I would Like to draw the Senate's attention to the dissenting reports which, to a large extent, were written by Senator Sir John Carrick. I find I am very much in agreement with most of them. Of course, Senator Sir John Carrick has had a great deal of experience in electoral matters . I remember when I first met him many years ago in his office in Sydney he was Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party. I agree with nearly every recommendation that he made. I would like to suggest that people who are interested in electoral reform read the dissenting reports which are contained in the report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to mention a couple of matters, the first of which relates to public funding. Many reports and papers on this matter, particularly in the United States of America, have indicated that control just does not work. Recommendation 99 on page 217 of the report states:

donations designated for Federal election purposes in excess of $200 to a candidate or constituency organisation and to a party in excess of $1,000 should be required to be disclosed and the donor identified.
I think the important words are 'donations designated for Federal election'. Recommendation 101 states:
donations made specifically for a State or Territory election or to a party maintenance or administrative expenditure fund should not be required to be disclosed . . .
How on earth does one distinguish between donations that are made for election purposes and donations that are made to party organisations?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a further recommendation that no part of the party' s maintenance fund can be spent on elections.

—Senator Ray says that no part of a party's maintenance fund can be used for elections. If that is a fact, how does one determine whether a donation is being used unless one has total access to all parties' funds?
—Because there is also disclosure of expenditure. It does interlock.

—I do not think it does. There is too much room for manoeuvring. I do not think it will work; it has been shown that it will not work. Loopholes have been found in the United States. I imagine that what will happen here is that we will not only end up with public funding, which I am against, but also we will have a system under which disclosures will not be able to be controlled properly. Therefore, parties will be getting money both ways and I do not like the idea of political parties getting their hand in the public till.
—It is already there and you know it.
—The honourable senator may say it is already there--
—What about VIP planes. You still get paid at election times- the whole lot.

—Let me give my opinion. The honourable senator can hold his opinion. I want to talk now about the issue of writs. I cannot see why the enrolment for an election has to be cut off an arbitrary seven days before the issue of writs.
—You agree it should be longer?

—I am going to suggest something that will give the maximum number of people the opportunity to vote. Why on earth people who have a birthday on the Friday before an election and who want to vote should not be included--
—That is taken care of.

—I am glad it is. Why should they not be able to apply for a vote the next day and sign a document to the effect that they have had a birthday. Why does the roll have to be closed seven days before the issue of a writ?
—There is a proclamation day now. You are missing the point.
—I am not missing the point. The honourable senator obviously has not thought of a few of the things that can be--
—The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—I certainly will, Mr President. I also want to know why an individual who chooses to stand for the Senate should have to pay a higher deposit than someone who stands for the House of Representatives. I do not see any reason at all why candidates for the two Houses should not pay an equal amount. I think that recommendation 65 on page 212 of the report is very dangerous. At the moment an elector can vote in the subdivision in which his name is recorded. Such a subdivision may contain six polling booths.
—Or one.

—Yes, but I am just taking six as an example. An elector could vote at each of those six polling booths. He could receive a ballot paper at each of the six polling booths. Each of his ballot papers would then we mixed with the rest of the ballot papers. In other words, he would have cast five votes which he was not entitled to cast. Under the Committee's recommendation an elector would be able to cast his vote at any polling booth in an electoral division. There might be 50 polling booths. Therefore he could vote 50 times in one day. Again, his votes would not be able to be distinguished from the other votes that were cast. Half a dozen people could go round the whole electorate-as was the situation in Wilmot a couple of years ago-voting a number of times. We could pick out who had done it, but it could well be that somebody used somebody else's name. For instance, I could use Senator Missen's name. He could then say: 'It wasn't me'. He could have an alibi because he was somewhere else. It is quite easy for somebody to rig an election in this way. To extend the situation to such a degree is quite dangerous. I am sure Senator Sir John Carrick would agree that there have been times when people have voted more than once. I think we should think about this matter very seriously before we agree to any change being made.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to enlarged parliaments, here again we have an attempt to change the system to the detriment of the public purse. I could not go along with the recommendation at all. I do not believe the public of this country wants more politicians. I do not believe the public wants politicians to have any better facilities than they have now. I very much agree. Senator Sir John Carrick dealt with this on page 235 of the report. On page 243 then Senator Steele Hall stated :
The public view is that there are politicians all over the place and one has only to attend public functions to find this to be often the situation.
Taking all 788 politicians including members of the two Assemblies into the calculation, Australia has a Member to each 12,000 electors.
The public would rightly be offended if the size of Federal Parliament was increased at a time when many businesses are reducing the number of their employees because of recession.
An increase in Members would inevitably swell the bureaucracy and put a stamp of approval on its growth when much of Australia is asking for smaller government.
My view does not hold that there should never be an increase. Population growth will make this desirable probably at the end of the century.
In the meantime, Members of Federal Parliament and the public would be well served by an increase in electorate office staff.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 September 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only does the Opposition not oppose the Meat Inspection Bill; it welcomes it. It represents what many of us have been working for for a long time now. Briefly, the Bill covers the administrative arrangements for the undertaking of domestic meat inspection in New South Wales and in other States if they wish to join the service. It is the first step towards the development of a national integrated meat inspection service. The purpose of the legislation is to provide a sound legal base for the development of the inspection system. The Bill provides for the setting of inspection standards for meat intended for human consumption and meat intended for use as animal food within Australia. The Bill provides for authorised officers to enter premises, to seize and retain meat and to carry out a variety of other duties. The appointment of authorised officers will be made and they will be issued with identity cards as required.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also provides that the owner of any premises be prohibited by law from supplying meat to any authorised officer unless he has special approval. This is dealt with in clause 35. It has been one of the matters that have created quite a lot of discussion and dissent over many years. The Bill also provides a whole range of penalties for contravention of the various provisions. As I have said, I am very pleased to see the Bill. I have given a lot of thought to it over some years. I go along with the thought behind it.

The industry at large has seen some innovation recently, but it needs to undertake more work in breeding, handling and, in particular, feeding. Of course , that will go a long way towards standardising meat and making the job of inspectors much simpler as well as providing improved returns to the producers. The real difficulties lie in the question of authority and the Federal issues, such as who will be in charge, who will want to be in control, and who will give up some of the items which they now believe to be their own. There is also the question of duplication of cost and authority. These are the three areas that have created most of the problems. I was interested in the proposals to which the journal of the Cattlemen's Union of Australia referred on 26 September. The Cattlemen's Union conference outlined an alternative which I thought was quite interesting. I will read some of the points that it made on the question of overcoming the duplication of authority. Its conclusions were:
(A) That export plants be staffed by Commonwealth inspectors an veterinary officers only.
(B) That State plants be staffed by State inspectors and veterinary officers only.
(C) That duties currently performed by State inspectors in export plants be performed by Commonwealth inspectors under agreement between the Commonwealth and State.
(D) That no second fee be applied to meat coming from export plants into the domestic market.
(E) That the states find some other method of funding their resultant shortfall of revenue.
(F) That the Commonwealth be responsible for the establishment and operation of whatever services it needs to maintain the integrity of Australia's export meats . . .
(G) Areas of common ground could surely be handled by reciprocal cooperation between states and Commonwealth.

If we are unable to get one universal service, those recommendations would go a long way towards ironing out some of the difficulties that have existed in the past. In view of the fact that the meat inspection service has been a government responsibility, economics have not been a prime consideration. The costs are certainly extravagant. The whole system has become institutionalised. We have had advice from the Government that the Commonwealth system is under review and under development. I think all sections of the industry-the producers, the processors and the exporters-are looking for an approved and improved service. The cost involved now is quite unrealistic and it has to be contained. In the recent debate on the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill and other Bills I requested a breakdown of the arbitrary add-on cost of 50 per cent. I still have not received that advice. I hope that the responsible Minister will be able to inform me as to when I can expect to get details of just what is involved, because it is a very significant amount in the overall cost of meat inspection.

I was pleased that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his statement on 24 August outlined the two principal objectives-a more efficient inspection service and a more cost effective inspection service. Australia depends very largely on its export industries. Of course, export meat is one of the main items on which we depend. This affects a considerable number of people and provides a lot of income to vastly diversified areas of Australia. We will always have difficulties with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade when it comes to export incentives, costs, payments to producers and so on. We take these matters very seriously in Australia. Of course, that prevents us from doing many of the things in which most of our trading partners openly indulge. Many countries are seeking ways of providing some assistance to their exporters. They depend on their export industries the same as we do. In our case such assistance could be provided to a very worthy industry. I fail to see why it has been decided that it is not good enough for us to do it in this case. Assistance with the export inspection charges would be an ideal way to do this. It would not be seen to conflict with the GATT arrangements. At present we need to take into account what is virtually an enormous tax that the present revaluation will produce on all our export industries including the meat industry. On top of these enormous increases in inspection charges and on top of trying to re-stock after the drought, the revaluation will make an enormous difference and set back all exporters and producers. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) may recall that we raised the question of costs in the Estimates Committee hearings this year. I asked Mr Miller a question about costs and what was being done about them. I was pleased at the time because he said:
I think if is fair to say that most of the ideas that we have about saving costs in the Service have come from within the Department . . .
Later he said:
. . . including such radical changes as passing over a substantial part of the responsibility to industry under a quality assurance program.

That was what he said then. Much the same has been stated in what is generally known as the Kelly report, the report of the Committee of Inquiry to examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems. The whole question of cost has to be dealt with more often. It has been dealt with, I think, on two occasions by the Industries Assistance Commission. It has been dealt with by just about every primary industry group. It has almost been a permanent fixture on agendas of the Australian Agricultural Council. All that is happening at the present time is that costs seem to be going up and up. It is worth recalling that in 1978 the Prices Justification Tribunal, in its assessment of beef marketing and processing, made a judgment in paragraph 6.22 of its report. It stated:

The Tribunal was heartened to learn that the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation was already sponsoring research, at the Veterinary School of the University of Queensland, designed to examine the validity of Australian procedures of meat inspection. A progress report furnished to the Tribunal illustrates the nature of the problems at issue. The work to date strongly supports the view, not only that the scientific basis of current inspection methods should be objectively examined with a view to bringing them into line with contemporary veterinary knowledge and the present incidence of disease, but that substantial reductions in the costs of inspection could be achieved with insignificant hazard to the consuming public.

That was stated in 1978. Regrettably everything but that has happened. We have certainly had no diminution of service but the costs have gone absolutely wild. I trust that the re-vamping of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation will be beneficial. I only hope that it grips the problem firmly and that the Government accepts its recommendations when it deals with the problems and brings some respectibility back to the industry. There certainly needs to be more responsibility put on the processors. I think this would increase the quality and reduce the costs.

By any standards, I think it is totally inappropriate to add 200 per cent to the costs of the scheme when the Government says that the program on which it is working is incomplete and that the decisions made in relation to it are not firm and are still changing. I was distrurbed to see that the Chairman of the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council, Mr Bowtell, was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 14 October 1983, as saying:

Whilst other governments in other countries with which Australia has to compete provide their industries with massive assistance to produce and market meat, our Government turns to its third largest export earner and imposes an inspection charge equal to almost a quarter of the total cost of processing meat.

He said the meat exporters and meat processors may jack up and not pay the costs . I think it would be a disaster if there was this confrontation. But I think the Government ought to have another look at the costs it is charging so that we can avoid that sort of problem. The timing of it could not be worse. We have been battering our heads against the brick wall of the drought for the last four years. Markets are not good. The currency revaluation has not helped and we will shortly face a 200 per cent increase in costs.

The Government has said, in various statements, that it predicts that there will be cost-savings. I want to know when people can expect these savings to become apparent and how much the Government believes will be involved. The inspection service that we have is highly professional. It is of paramount importance. There is no need for there to be any downgrading of the service. Hopefully, it will improve. The Bill, together with the revised AMLC and the fury that exists at present against the new rates, offers the opportunity for a thorough investigation and rationalisation of employment and conditions of employment. I think inspectors should be engaged by the Commonwealth either directly on wages or on contract as circumstances find appropriate. Processors should also be brought under that responsibility. Hopefully the opportunity to set a more streamlined, efficient and economic system will not be missed. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Meat Inspection Bill makes provision for the extension of an objective which has been sought by the meat industry and, I think, by major political parties generally for some time. I did not hear the beginning of Senator Archer's speech but I gather the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. I shall not delay its passage to the next stage any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 14, paragraph 25 (3) (b), after ''premises'', line 14, insert ''or board, enter, stop or detain any vehicle, ship or aircraft''.
(2) Page 14, paragraphs 25 (3) (c) and (d), lines 15 and 16, leave out the paragraphs.

(3) Page 14, paragraph 25 (3) (f), before ''break open'', line 18, insert '' with the consent of the occupier, master of a vessel or aircraft, or in pursuance of a warrant granted under sub-section (6)''.
(4) Page 14, sub-clause 25 (5), line 29, leave out all words after ''to'', insert the following paragraphs:
''(a) enter any premises that are not prescribed premises;
(b) stop, board, enter or detain any vehicle, ship or aircraft; or
(c) break open any hold, compartment or any container or other receptacle ( including any place that could be used as a receptacle)''.

My amendments are almost identical to an amendment that I moved in May last year to the Export Control Act 1982. I think the reasons for moving these amendments are set out fairly cogently in the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I have moved the amendments basically because of the extremely wide power of entry, search and seizure which is conferred upon inspectors. As I said last year, I do not believe that it is necessary to confer such a power. The methods which are available and are used under other Acts, I believe, are sufficient here.

The various amendments that I have moved look at the notion not only of premises but also of vehicles, ships and aircraft. The problems of course, as I acknowledged last year in relation to this matter, are very large, but I believe that the principle that ought to be involved here is one that we should not overlook. I think there would be no difficulties involved if the amendments which I have suggested were passed. However, I imagine that the Committee will probably be of the same opinion as it was last year in relation to the similar amendments, but I felt it was necessary to move them to raise yet again this matter of what I believe are the unwarranted wide powers being conferred upon inspectors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I think it would be useful to divide the amendments into two groups. On superficial examination, the first two amendments simply seek to change the form in which the same powers and authorisations are presented. Let me detail the consequences which have been drawn to my attention if the amendments were to be accepted in the form that Senator Macklin has proposed. Sub-section (6) entails an application to a justice of the peace for, effectively, a warrant of search. Such an authorisation from a justice of the peace would have to be procured before an inspector could enter a vehicle, ship or aircraft or stop or detain any vehicle, ship or aircraft. By the time an inspector, who had reason to suspect that a ship or aircraft might be carrying, for example, mislabelled goods had met that requirement, the ship or aircraft might have moved out of the country. On those grounds, the Government finds those two amendments unacceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the remaining two amendments, whilst I recognise and understand the concern of Senator Macklin and his Party about strong powers of detention and search being granted to Commonwealth officers, the Government believes that the circumstances in this case are such that those powers are necessary. The effects of amendments (3) and (4) proposed by Senator Macklin are that, unless the occupier of the ship, building or whatever grants permission, a Commonwealth officer must obtain authorisation from a justice of the peace before making a compulsory entry or search. For example, a Commonwealth officer may have reason to believe that a container of meat which is labelled 'beef' might be stuffed full of kangaroo, donkey or some other meat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Possum.

—Possum, yes; but mislabelled in some way or another. There are possible circumstances which could be outlined no doubt, but I cite this as an example. The Commonwealth officer would then be obliged firstly to ask the occupier of the premises or the person in charge of the transport vehicle whether the Commonwealth officer could open the container to see whether the goods were incorrectly described or mislabelled. Just suppose the goods were mislabelled, the occupier, owner or custodian would be unlikely, to say the least, to grant permission to such a Commonwealth officer. The Commowealth officer would then be obliged to go to a justice of the peace to obtain authorisation to do so. Although I recognise the genuine concerns which Senator Macklin has and particularly given the recent history of this industry where mislabelling, substitution and fraud are not just a matter of hypothetical speculation-it is a matter of history that those malpractices have occurred-the Government believes on balance that the provisions provided for in the Meat Inspection Bill in its original form are justified and therefore the easing of those provisions or the additional impediments, if I may put it that way, which Senator Macklin proposes are not acceptable to the Government. We will therefore not be accepting the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I comment on clause 36 of the Bill. I understand that the regulation-making power established by sub-clause (1) defines the limits of sub-clause (2). I seek advice from the Minister on whether that indeed is the case. I will elaborate on that while the Minister seeks some clarification. The situation, as I understand it, is that the purpose of sub- clauses (2) and (3) is to allow a process of legislation by reference by which the provisions of existing legislation, which presumably in this case is State legislation, will be incorporated by regulation into the legislation currently before the Committee. I do not believe that, if we remove sub-clauses (2) and (3 ), that action would in any way limit the regulating power of the Bill. I believe it would merely mean that the actual provisions, as distinct from the title, would have to be incorporated by regulation. In other words, the State Act that we wish to incorporate would have to be spelt out in some detail in the regulations. That seems to me to be a preferable manner than by actually doing it, for example, under sub-clause (3) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A power conferred by this Act to make modifications by regulation includes the power to omit any matter or add any new matter.

This seems to me to be extraordinarily wide. It is the type of legislation which one sees going through the Queensland Parliament. However, if indeed it is the case that sub-clause (1) defines the limits of sub-clauses (2) and (3) I think I would be assured that there was not any undue attempt to make massive changes to this Act without reference to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, Mr Temporary Chairman, I am advised that the concern Senator Macklin has is covered in the Bill. Sub-clause (2)-I have been hastily advised on this and I trust I have it correct-does make provision for the powers of other Acts to be called up. But if the powers of those other Acts exceed the regulation- making powers in this Bill they may not exceed the regulation-making powers provided for in this Bill itself.
—That is in sub-clause (1).
—Yes, in sub-clause (1). Is that an adequate explanation?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Macklin

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 September 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill repeats many of the features in the Bill which was introduced in May of this year and which was rejected by the Senate. Some features of that Bill have not been contained in this Bill, but essentially the Opposition's attitude to the current legislation is similar to that which we described when dealing with the Bill which was introduced in May; that was, that it retrospectively created liabilities for tax that did not exist at the time at which it was described to relate. In this Bill there is the creation of a new tax liability for vendor-shareholders, and that liability is created retrospectively. As was stated by the shadow Treasurer in the other place when dealing with this legislation, the Opposition is opposed to it. I believe that there are about 12 speakers on the list, and I will not be making the lengthy explanation that could be made with regard to it. I do state our very solid objection to the features of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, it has retrospective effect and creates a new tax that was not previously payable by those to whom it will apply. It is, in many senses, a vindictive piece of legislation. It is a discriminatory piece of legislation. It is penal in its approach. It creates double taxation in some circumstances, and it has abnormalities. I would think that with those features it is not surprising that it is a Bill that we feel we must object to and reject in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Other than all that, it is good legislation.

—Other than that, it may be able to be described as tax legislation, but those features make it quite unacceptable to the Opposition. I should say that this legislation is, coincidentally, brought before the Senate during the Budget session and, in some sense, there would be those who would describe it as Budget legislation. In general terms, I believe that it is accepted that a government is entitled to expect the passage of normal Budget and Budget-type legislation and other legislation that is an essential part of its financial program. However, there will be rare occasions when an opposition will feel compelled to reject or substantially amend such legislation, within the constitutional limitations of the Senate, where it is demonstrated to be capricious and arbitrary or vindictive legislation or where it creates new tax burdens of a retrospective kind. For the reasons that I mentioned earlier and as has been stated already in the House of Representatives and will be stated in the Senate tonight, the legislation clearly falls within all of those grounds of exception and the Opposition, we believe, would be failing in its public duty if it voted to pass this Bill. I therefore state quite unequivocally that it will be rejected by the members of the Opposition parties.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it ought to be made clear precisely what occurs with this Bill. It will be recalled that in May 1983 the Government introduced legislation to amend the existing legislation by extending the recoupment tax to deem that the company distributed as a dividend all accumulated tax paid earnings and capital reserves since incorporation, and this was to be taxed at up to 69.6c in the dollar. That Bill, as I said, was rejected by the Senate. The new amendment Bill introduced during the Budget session of the current Parliament differs little from that legislation which was introduced last May, the only difference being that the legislation will exclude capital profits and after-tax retained earnings of the company where primary tax was paid in the normal manner. In essence, the amendment extends the scope of the original recoupment legislation by deeming that a dividend has been distributed by the company equal to the total after-tax retained earnings where tax has already been paid under the original recoupment legislation. This dividend will be subject to additional recoupment tax. This means that the Government makes the unrealistic assumption that if the company had continued in operation it would have made 100 per cent dividend distribution , with the total tax of the income being up to 82.5c in the dollar, depending on the year in which the company was sold. Many examples can be given of the punitive nature of the legislation that is before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not punitive.

— I would have to style the taxable rate that would be applied to those people who would be affected by the legislation as being punitive in the effect that it would have in the total tax rate that would be extracted from those people who were shareholders of the companies concerned. There are some other amendments to the 1982 recoupment legislation. I do not intend to speak at any great length on them. I said that it was discriminatory legislation, and I believe that it could also be classed as being unfair, because it is directed only at companies sold with a current year profit component. They were styled as being wet Slutzkin companies. Companies sold to the same promoters with only retained earnings, that is, those that were called dry Slutzkins, escaped this new tax, as also do companies which paid their primary company tax but failed to meet their Division 7 sufficient distribution requirements. However, it ought to be understood that when the vendor- shareholders have paid the primary company tax and Division 7 tax under the original recoupment legislation, the situation is no different from the dry Slutzkin scheme. Yet the Government proposes to place the new tax only on such shareholders. This is extraordinary, particularly as some of the statements that we can recall of the Ministers involved with this legislation, such as the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), were to the effect that there is no question of retrospectivity being applied to schemes which were totally and absolutely dry. We wonder then how we can differentiate between the two schemes that could be called wet or dry when, after the primary company tax and Division 7 tax has been paid, they are in exactly the same position. It does seem that the rationale for the proposed amendment is the completely unrealistic assumption that after-tax retained earnings are distributed 100 per cent to shareholders.

SPEECH.PARA: I think anyone who knows anything about company practice understands that that is a totally unrealistic assumption. It does not occur in fact, and the provisions in the amendments that are before us ignore the retention provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act and ignore what is properly retained by companies in their businesses to provide working capital, to provide for development, to provide for a continuation of the company. It seems to me to be absurd that we have before us a Bill that completely ignores the existing provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act with regard to sufficient distribution and the retention of profits in the company, when the Australian Labor Party went to the people with a policy that it would allow 100 per cent of profits to be retained by small companies. That policy of the present Government , which at the time of the election talked of the retention of 100 per cent of profits in the companies, ignores completely what has now been put before us. I could class it only as being a punitive form of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The companies, of course, have already paid their proper primary tax.

—The companies have paid their proper primary tax, but the distribution of 100 per cent of their profits to shareholders is something that has never been required of companies, and the existing provisions of the Act enable them to retain some of their profits as retained earnings. To suggest that retrospectively one can now impute a distribution of 100 per cent of such earnings ignores completely the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act and proper business practice. For that reason the amendment is no more than a penalty tax. It can be clearly seen that in the 1980-81 year, for example, the rate of 78.4c in the dollar far exceeds the maximum personal tax rate of 60c in the dollar or the normal company plus Division 7 tax rate, which totals 54c in the dollar. The proposed amendment will increase the recoupment tax payable by approximately 45 per cent. If that is not punitive, I would like to know what sort of figure the Government regards as being punitive when we look at what will occur under this legislation if passed by the Senate.
—They are exactly the same rates as if they had gone out as dividends.

—Yes, but they did not go out as dividends and that is a big difference. That is the whole point. It is imputing something that did not happen. It is penalising people for something that did not occur. I suggest that if honourable senators opposite were to look at the practice of companies they would find that this does not occur and it did not occur. These profits are not currently subject to a tax of the nature that is now proposed under this legislation. When vendors sold their shares the proceeds they received in respect of the sale were of a capital nature and non-taxable. That situation is in accordance with a decision of the High Court of Australia. The fact that the proceeds were of a capital non-taxable nature is recognised in the second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: The examples that I know have been put before the Treasurer (Mr Keating) by many professional bodies should have alerted him to the provisions of the Bill and what they were seeking to do in assessing tax on imputed dividends which were not actually declared or paid, and which did not have to be declared or paid under the existing provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I think it could be argued that the whole premise of the Bill is based on a fundamental misconception. The following passage appears in the second reading speech:

Rather, those persons should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of after-tax profits that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands.

This is clearly a wrong assumption. If the companies had continued to operate as going concerns they would have been entitled to retain sufficient distribution and claim the exemptions that remain in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Those profits would never have been subjected to tax. All the tax that would have been payable, if the sale of shares had not taken place, has been imposed by the principal Act. The further liabilities to be imposed by the Bill are new, additional taxes which will apply retrospectively.

I think I have given sufficient reasons for us to be able to say that we reject completely this form of legislation. The retention allowance in the Income Tax Assessment Act is a very important part of the provisions that enable companies to carry on business, to improve capital and in general, particularly in times of economic difficulty, to remain in business. But what I think is quite important is that the Bill creates a liability for the new tax even where a person has paid out his liability under the principal Act. Payments since 25 July 1982 are to be ignored for this purpose. The new and increased liability having been established, a credit is given for the payments made since 25 July 1982 and additional payments will no doubt be demanded. Had persons who made arrangements to make payments under the principal Act known that further payments might be sought, they may not have made the payments at all or they may have sought to bargain for less or to make arrangements that would mean that they could have some relief from what is proposed. Such person may not have the capacity now to raise the additional amount. I do not think it is any answer to say that such cases might be taken to the relief boards. I think it would be known by those who have practised in the taxation area that applications to the relief boards are rarely successful. There is a long delay in having such matters settled. The provisions that are to be applied and the nature of the liability that is to be created under them would be beyond the scope of many of the people who would be affected by this Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bankruptcy is no defence either.

— Of course it is no defence. I think that what is important and what has arisen in the last day or two is the way in which the Commissioner of Taxation is dealing with some of the people who would have come within the scope of the Act. I refer to the matters that were raised by a number of honourable senators at Question Time today relating to the letter of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia concerning Coomel Pty Ltd. The Deputy Commissioner gave reasons as to why he would exercise discretion to relieve Coomel Pty Ltd in liquidation of any recoupment liability arising out of its holding in December 1976 of 600 shares in Metro Industries Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise this matter because it has caused considerable interest, particularly in Western Australia, because so many of the shareholders live in that State. Questions that were raised with regard to those people who have received notices of liability or assessment under the recoupment legislation are now confused with regard to the positions in which they find themselves and what appears to be a discretion that has been exercised in accordance with the Act by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia. Questions raised sought information as to whether the shareholders in public companies who have received assessments or notices of liability under the recoupment legislation can be assured that they would have the same treatment for their circumstances as has been set out in a letter dated 17 October from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia.

It is apparent that throughout the Press in Western Australia this evening there is some concern with regard to the matters that have now been raised. One headline stated 'Thousands want Dawkins treatment'. The article stated that thousands of people wanted to be given the same treatment as Mr Dawkins in relation to their liabilities under the recoupment legislation. Another headline stated 'Many may claim tax exemption'. The article stated that many people may claim tax exemption under the Act. Legal companies and tax accountants have received letters from the Commissioner of Taxation. I have in front of me one such letter relating to Metro Industries Ltd and the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act. The letter states:
. . . a copy of notice(s) of assessment and/or a copy of a copy of notice(s) of assessment, served on you as a preliminary step towards the raising of a Recoupment Tax assessment.
Also enclosed is a list of all vendor shareholders and former owners to whom a copy of the notice(s) of assessment in respect of the above company is being sent.

In this case it was a notice of assessment in respect of Treamog Pty Ltd. It mentioned the former name of White Way Sign and Lighting Co. Ltd. The letter goes on to explain objection rights and states:

. . . that any former owner nominated by a majority of the former owners, who received the company notice or a copy of the company notice, is entitled to exercise the same rights of objection and appeal against the company's assessment as are available to the company itself.
The letter goes on to state:

Accordingly, if there is any dissatisfaction with the company assessment, the nominated former owner, may within 60 days after service of the company notice of assessment, post to or lodge with the Commissioner an objection in writing against the assessment stating fully and in detail the grounds relied upon.

I think it is interesting that those who have come within the scope of the recoupment legislation now have that ruling of the Commissioner of Taxation in the letter dated 17 October, in which he clearly sets out this discretion under sub-section 6 (18):
Where a secondary taxable amount exists or existed in relation to a person and-
(a) the Commissioner, having regard to- (i) the circumstances by reason of which the secondary taxable amount exists or existed; and
(ii) such other circumstances as the Commissioner considers relevant,
considers it unreasonable that the secondary taxable amount should be taken to exist or to have existed in relation to the person; or
(b) if the secondary taxable amount is less than $100- . . .
The matters have been expressed in the Deputy Commissioner's letter. Set out clearly in sub-paragraph (c) on page 2 is the statement:

that sale took place . . . and in circumstances which did not reflect any benefit in relation to that sale or in relation to circumstances connected with that sale and subsequent handling of Treamog's affairs-
This led the Commissioner to relieve Coomel Pty Ltd of any recoupment liability.

I think that what is exercising those in professional practice in Western Australia and those who are personally affected by the recoupment legislation is the question of whether the same discretion will be exercised by the Commissioner with regard to their assessments or their notices of liability, as has been set out in that letter. When seeking information about this matter in the Senate at Question Time today, we were acting on behalf of a number of inquiries, which have intensified throughout the day, with regard to the position of those people who are either receiving notices of liability or who are the representative shareholders who have been affected by the recoupment Acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting, Senator, that the Commissioner is exercising his discretion partially?

— No, I think that what is described as being the effect of section 6 of the Act gives that discretion to the Commissioner. I think that the question we are now posing is whether those who have been advised of liability, who have received assessments or who have paid assessments will have an opportunity to have the same discretion exercised where, in particular, as the Deputy Commissioner has stated in this letter, there was no benefit derived by those shareholders. I think that that is what has exercised the people with regard to this matter today, particularly as we have had the public release of the ruling, through the Deputy Commissioner's letter of 17 October.

SPEECH.PARA: I said at the outset that the Opposition will oppose this legislation. The way in which the retention allowance provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act have been ignored and the punitive retrospective effect of the provisions have come before us have led us to believe that this is not a Bill which ought to be supported through the Parliament. It is a Bill which will have many far-reaching effects. It is a Bill which, I would think, in view of the ruling that has been given by the Commissioner, will be very difficult for him to administer impartially in a way in which he can determine, within a matter of a few hours, whether a firm or an individual had gained any benefit from the ownership of shares in one of the companies which is caught under the legislation. It is interesting that he had denied the company the possibility of electing to pay undistributed profits tax and has deemed that 100 per cent distribution of profits ought to be made in assessing a person under this new legislation.

Other senators will follow me and perhaps give their own points of view. For the reasons I have stated, on behalf of the Opposition I leave the matter at that point. I hope that we shall have some information from the Commissioner or from his officers, or through the Treasurer or his representative in this place, that will set at rest what is occurring now, particularly in Western Australia, as the professionals are seeking information on behalf of their clients. I state on behalf of the Opposition that this Bill will be opposed at all its stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government in this enterprise in the Senate tonight. We are trying to convince the chamber that it ought to support the Government's attempt to replenish the revenues of this country with moneys which are in the hands or have passed through the hands of those who have benefited from the operation of bottom of the harbour tax avoidance schemes. Somewhere along the line, the people upon whom we seek to place a liability tonight benefited from those bottom of the harbour tax avoidance schemes. This legislation, which is very modest compared with the legislation brought into this chamber and rejected in May and June of this year, seeks to obtain for the Treasury some $60m this financial year, and $270m overall. It represents part of that overall attempt by this Government to ensure a degree of equity and fairness in the application of the tax laws of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe this should be done in fairness to the pay as you earn taxpayer, the ordinary employee, who has no way of avoiding the payment of tax by indulging in contrived and highly artificial schemes or in the perverting of the best legal and accounting brains of the country to the selfish ends of the taxpayer concerned. That is not possible for the great majority of Australian taxpayers. Where there is a clear instance of people benefiting from a highly artificial tax avoidance scheme, we believe that we ought to require of them that they repay to the Treasury those amounts of money avoided.

Why are we dealing with this matter here again in the Budget session, when we already had before us a similar Bill in May, although, as I say, a much more complex and more far-reaching Bill? The Australian Financial Review, a conservative journal, had this to say in its editorial of 3 June about the defeat of that earlier legislation in this chamber:
But the defeat of the bottom of the harbour tax recoupment legislation . . . is a victory for selfishness and a defeat for fair play and social equity.

But one has to concede that there were in the chamber, and perhaps in the community at large, some misgivings about the operation of that legislation in relation to the possibility that its application would create severe unemployment in those firms and business enterprises into which it was said the moneys derived from bottom of the harbour schemes had been reinvested.
On that, the Australian Financial Review had this to say:

Senator Harradine and other critics of the proposed legislation have made much of possible but unprobable effects on unemployment. While our unemployment problem is indeed deserving of great concern it should not be used as an excuse to justify any form of anti-social behaviour. The argument is in fact a clever smokescreen albeit, apparently, an effective one.

That was the view of the Australian Financial Review on the defeat of the similar legislation earlier this year. There was an air of hysteria around this place which I hope now, in the light of the considered response of financial commentators and their assessment of the true impact on employment is ' unprobable', as the Australian Financial Review said. In any case, in respect of the greater criterion of fairness and equity which ought to prevail, one could ask that that particular fear or misgiving not be the guiding criterion in decisions of honourable senators in relation to their support or otherwise for the Bill.

In any case the argument is misguided, because one could well say that if the Federal Government does not have available to it the sorts of revenues which are required for its programs and for the stimulus of the economy-and despite all sorts of budgetary constraints, we have managed to put forward an expansionary Budget of some $8.5 billion-if money is not available for Government redistribution throughout the economy, many pockets of unemployment, in areas different from those which would be created by the application of this law, would continue or would be exacerbated. In any case, why should honest PAYE taxpayers and those firms which are prepared to receive and act on ethical accounting or legal advice, be penalised by a higher incidence of tax than would be the case were this legislation to be passed?

This Government is not prepared recklessly or heedlessly to apply this law in a way which would cause undue hardship either to individuals or to businesses, which clearly might be put under immense strain if required to cough up the moneys which are sought overnight. I know that Senator Jack Evans would be very pleased with the present structure of the Bill in that plenty of facility for time to pay is provided within the legislation.

In relation to the dividend recoupment tax liabilities, a person is allowed 12 months to pay by instalments, without any late penalty being inflicted or imposed upon the taxpayer. I emphasise that in relation to some remarks made by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The fact is, as I say, that the 12-month period of payment by instalments, which was largely inserted at the request of Senator Jack Evans in June, is a feature of this legislation. It is also true that section 265 of the Act will still operate. Honourable senators will know that under that provision, where there is a case of extreme hardship, an appeal can be made to an utterly independent arbiter who will decide whether that tax liability ought to be pursued. But it may be that that would apply only in a very narrow range of cases. I concede that that might well be so. In relation to the great majority of cases hardship, dislocation and the impairing of present business arrangements need not occur on the devastating scale which it was suggested they might occur. This is because, as I say, the Government has built in this 12-month payment-by-instalment proposition, which should alleviate a lot of that hardship and therefore allay many of the fears of those who in June felt they could not support the then legislation.

As I have said, this Bill has been modified in several ways, indeed to such an extent that the Government now expects to raise only $270m rather than the $570m which it said it would be able to raise under the June legislation. That indicates the extent to which this Government is prepared to go. I would concede that the Bill is probably better for the several months consideration over the winter recess, but the indication of the diminution of revenue is, I think, in itself a fair indication of the very large extent to which the Government has been prepared to go to meet the requests and concerns of some senators who felt unable to support the Bill last June.

What the Bill does, of course, is carry into effect the Government's decision that the restitution expected of those persons who benefited from the sale of shares in companies that were stripped of pre-tax profits should not be limited to the primary company tax that ought to have been paid by the companies concerned, rather those persons should also pay the tax who as shareholders or former owners escaped from paying through receipt of a non-taxable capital form of after-tax profits; if the companies had continued to operate as current concerns these would have been taxable as dividends in their hands. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said: 'Well, of course, those moneys may have been retained in the company and never distributed as dividends'. That is not exactly the point. Had they been distributed as dividends, they would have attracted this marginal rate of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not.

—Senator Macklin will not let me finish my paragraph. He should give me a fair go. I am saying that had the moneys been liberated in the form of dividends they would have been taxable at the marginal rate in the hands of the persons concerned. Under the arrangements entered into by these company shareholders, the moneys were liberated not in the form of dividends but in the form of the consideration in the sale of the company. So they were liberated in exactly the same way as they would have been had they been paid as dividends. As far as our company tax structure is concerned, whenever such retained moneys are liberated they are liable to taxation. The mere fact that the liberation was by way of sale consideration rather than through distribution by way of dividend is beside the point.
—Ha, ha!
—That is the law. That is the company tax law which obviously the honourable senator is not prepared to accept.
—It is not the company tax law at all. That is why you are changing it. Don't be absurd.
—I am advised that it is.
—If it were the company law you would not need this Bill. Don't be idiotic.
—I do not think I am being idiotic. I am trying to state an argument in relation to--
—You would not need the new law if you had a law.

—There are all sorts of things one had to do in this chamber, because of the slackness of the administration of tax laws over the past seven years, in order to clarify what is the case. The taxation offences law is a very good example of such legislation. It was passed some two years ago. I think Mr Hurford spoke in another place in relation to the argument that the Bill seeks to impose a tax on retained profits which would not have borne tax had the company continued to operate. He indicated what nonsense that was by speaking of it in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with a quasi-liquidation situation. The people who sold the shares knew it was a quasi-liquidation situation. The fact of the matter is that profits were not retained in the companies concerned but were liberated to the vendor-shareholders in the form of the sale price of their shares reduced by the promoter's fee. The income tax law as it now stands and as it stood for the whole of the period from 1 January 1972 to 3 December 1980-the period in relation to which the recoupment tax law operates-requires that distributions of profits to shareholders by a company that is a going concern be taxed as dividends.
That is the simple situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever heard of retention?
—But it was not retained. They sought--
—You are making assumptions.
—They sought to liberate the moneys by way of a sale consideration and they have been treated the same way as if they had done it through distribution by way of dividends.
—As if they were idiots.
—As if they were idiots, yes.

—No, they were not idiots; they were very slick operators who took advantage of perverting the best accounting and legal brains in the country to their own selfish ends, and now they are being caught up with. I have been a little repetitious on that fact, of necessity, given the interjections by Senator Macklin. I have had to be because of the distortions and the lurid pictures painted by the Opposition, which could quite mislead those unfortunate enough to pay attention to them in regard to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, very considerable concessions have been made by the Government in relation to these Bills. We will no longer seek to recover personal tax on the total accumulated profits cashed up and the stripped company. The legislation will now be confined to the tax avoided only in relation to the after-tax revenue profits for the year in which the evasion of the primary company tax occurred. In other words, it will apply only to the current year profits. These are very considerable concessions and will meet a lot of the requests which were made in this chamber in May and June. It would be sheer bloodymindedness-if that word is permitted to be used in this chamber, Mr Acting Deputy President-

TALK.START.PARA: —Marginally.

—Of the senators concerned if they obdurately held to their objections to this Bill in the face of very considerable concessions which have been made by the Government. This is reflected in the diminution of revenue expected, from $570m to some $270m in the full operation of the Act. Some $60m is expected in this financial year. Nevertheless as a government senator I must not get carried away because of some zealous attack on those who have evaded their contribution to revenue. One is required to ask: Is this legislation penal and retrospective? If that were the case I would be the first to object to its operation and would feel that the abhorrence of our whole legal tradition should be brought to bear against it. I refute utterly the penal character of the Act, which was attributed to it by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. There are no penalties. I have already indicated that even in the case of late payment-the 12 -month instalment facility-no penalties are attached. Indeed, no extra penalties are built into the amending Bill at all; no additional taxes are imposed. The Bill simply seeks to recover tax that ought to have been paid years ago when companies were stripped of their assets.

SPEECH.PARA: In no way does that Bill attach the stigma of criminality to those concerned. It does not impute to them any criminal intent. If they had had any criminal intent or if they were engaged on criminal tax evasion, the general law and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act in relation to post-1980 matters would apply. We are not saying that; we are not imputing criminal intent. There are no criminal penalties. We are simply asking that the moneys which were avoided be paid. We are not even asking for the moneys to be paid at a rate which takes into account inflation or the fact that most of these moneys would have been used in a profitable enterprise. The argument used back in May was that these moneys had been ploughed back into various firms and business enterprises and that to apply the legislation then would disrupt their operation and would cause bankruptcies and so on.

We are not taking into account the fact that people who have had these moneys for five, seven or 10 years have been operating profitably with such money, perhaps in the capital gains area or at least in profitable business enterprises and certainly no doubt beating the effects of inflation. We are simply asking for the money back in money terms equivalent, and not taking into account any inflationary erosion of those moneys. It can hardly be said that these provisions bear any penal character at all. There is no criminal stigma attached and there is no extra amount built into the moneys sought to be recovered such as could lead to its being said that there was any penalty involved. Thus, these are not penal provisions. That allows me then to go--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—The honourable senator can gasp in astonishment--
—There is nothing penal about sending someone bankrupt; it is all in good, clean fun.

—As the Australian Financial Review, which is a conservative journal and hardly the most radical, trendy, left wing journal of opinion in this country said, bankruptcy of some companies, if such were the case-the Review speaks of predictions of bankruptcy as being in the range of 'unprobable' which is a word it had to coin to deal with this particular assertion-is not the only consideration. There are other values and criteria at stake, such as fairness and equity. It is these values which appeal to some of Senator Chipp's Democrat colleagues. I am sorry to see that, despite all the concessions that the Government has apparently made in relation to this Bill, the honourable senator can still not find it in him to do what is fair and equitable according to every commentator who has made any assessment of these remarks.
—Argue for the Bill if you must, but do not say it is not penal.

—I am saying it and I am asserting it. If the honourable senator is not convinced, I am sorry; but most Australians and most financial commentators are convinced. I am, therefore, free to deal with retrospectivity without it being considered as being of a penal character. I find that very important for myself, and I have explained why. It is part of our legal tradition that if we have retrospective penal laws we would find them so abhorrent that we would want to have no part of them.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have pointed out in this chamber before in relation to retrospectivity, I find some reassurance in the words of Lord Greene who was the custodian of the common law tradition in England, the parliamentary and common law tradition which we seek to continue in our own traditions. He was Master of the Rolls in the 1940s. In a 1941 Court of Appeal decision, speaking for himself and Lord Justices Clauson and du Parcq in a taxation case-this is the Court of Appeal in the United Kingdom-the custodian of the common law tradition had this to say:

The fact that the Section has to some extent a retrospective effect again appears to us of no importance when it is realised that the legislation is a move in a long and fiercely-contested battle with individuals who well understand the rigour of the content.

Surely this is the case in this contest going on between the legislature and those involved in various tax avoidance schemes. The legal traditions to which we are heir realised and conceded that particular point in this narrow compass of tax laws, the to and fro between the tax avoiders and the legislature.

Again, the Australian Financial Review on 17 August last year in relation to the Government's then retrospective legislation which was brought in by the then Treasurer, Mr John Howard, in another place and supported in this chamber by Opposition senators had this to say:
. . . non-retrospectivity of the tax law is by no stretch of the imagination an absolute moral or political value. Clearly, retrospectivity is more a serious issue with respect to criminal law--
I interpolate penal law--
than with respect to income tax law.
That is exactly my position.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a ridiculous point of view to put.
—Of course, Senator Chipp always asserts that when he finds something is not to his liking.
—What gives the Australian Financial Review some sort of expertise in morality?
—It certainly has more on this point than I find coming from certain elements within the Democrats. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the bottom of the harbour schemes the abuse of the tax system and the injustice is so gross that justice and fairness are on the side of retrospectivity.
But the opponents of retrospectivity rightly warn of the dangers of taking it lightly. It should almost never be done.
The general principle remains true as-

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not bottom of the harbour.
—Of course, we are moving on to those people who avoided paying tax on dividends by these particular arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: That largely deals with the considerations of the Bill as far as I want to raise them in the chamber tonight. The fact is that we are in a situation in which the passage of this legislation will enable the Government to gather several hundreds of millions of dollars which ought to be, and were expected to be, gathered had the previous Government taken a more vigorous and robust attitude towards the gathering of taxation over the past seven or so years.

It is well known that the ordinary taxpayers of this country have had to bear the brunt for too long of the consequences of the maladministration and the refusal of the Liberal Party when in Government to give the Commissioner of Taxation the sinews of war. Year after year he pleaded for more staff in order to enable him to pursue tax avoiders; yet the Liberal Government adamantly refused to give him that staff. I was on the Senate Estimates committees when that refusal was made apparent year after year. In relation to the administration of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office which also gave rise to so much possibility for tax avoidance, the people on the benches opposite bear a grave responsibility. This Bill is merely in a much milder vehicle than was the case in May and June. As I say, that mildness, that modesty, in the proposal tonight is reflected in the diminution of revenue expected from $570m to $270m as the Bill takes effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still retrospective.

—Of course it is still retrospective, but it is not penally retrospective. It is part of that continuing to and fro between tax avoidance and the legislature which the common law tradition of England has sanctioned in the decision of the Court of Appeal in England to which I have already made reference. The fact is that this Government came into office on 5 March with a general mandate to create a fairer tax system. This Bill is part of the fulfilment of that mandate. When we can get to a situation in which all Australians-whether wealthy enough to be able to employ the best legal and accounting brains to pervert their talents to their own selfish ends or whether ordinary Australians filling in their tax forms year after year at the end of the kitchen table or ordinary businessmen who take better ethical taxation advice from their accountants and lawyers-make their fair contribution to the revenue, this will be a much fairer and more decent society. That is what this Government is trying to create. That is what this Bill seeks to serve. Therefore , it deserves the support of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill, the latest effort by the Government to pass through this chamber the legislation which, it claims, is connected with an expansion on previous tax avoidance or evasion legislation. We have heard that these Bills are modest Bills. Indeed, they are modest compared with the earlier one. To some extent, I suppose it might be said that the activities of Mussolini during the war compared with those of Hitler were modest. It does not necessarily mean that that modesty leads one to be supportive of it. I would think that, in this case, there is much for the Government to be modest about.

SPEECH.PARA: I will trace very briefly the events that have led to this Bill. The legislation which the Fraser Government introduced last year was bitterly opposed. It was amended to some extent. It was legislation which might have come earlier. There might have been actions at an earlier stage but for the lack of realisation by people of the extent to which there was massive tax evasion. Moneys which had escaped the revenue should have been paid. In that year that legislation, based upon principles of equity and fairness which have been referred to tonight, was passed into law. People have since acted on that legislation and have paid moneys and taken certain actions. I supported that legislation and supported it strongly.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was retrospective.
