—Yes, it was retrospective. If the honourable senator would like to check, he can read my speech of 24 November 1982, which can be found on page 2744 of Hansard. I stand by everything I said on that occasion. I said that the earlier legislation, which was necessarily retrospective, was needed in all the circumstances. I continue to support that legislation, realising that there are very doubtful reasons why and that very rare occasions exist when one should see retrospective legislation which alters the state of affairs. But, in this event, I thought those reasons existed. But the later legislation-the legislation in May-is an excrescence upon that earlier legislation. The Government has attempted to say that the present legislation is of the same nature as the previous legislation; but of course it is not. I will go into some detail as to the way in which it is different. Tracing as we were the history of the period, we realised the position of the Australian Labor Party, particularly through the voice of Senator Evans, who is now Attorney-General but who is not here tonight. He spoke so strongly about the legislation of the Fraser Government and after that proceeded to discuss what he and his Government would do. We have heard tonight of a mandate that should be exercised and of what the Labor Government is now entitled to do. I suppose part of that mandate is included in Senator Evans's statements as reported in the Law Institute Journal of 1 November. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party would confine retrospective legislation, recoupment legislation against tax avoidance to schemes which are blatant . . . our legislation would not be penal in character, but simply seek to recover-like the Government's ' bottom of the harbour' legislation-the tax which was avoided.
He said, even as late as April this year:

it is our intention . . . to remove loopholes created by section 3 (12) (in the Act) . . . Beyond that we have no intention of proceeding on retrospective recoupment legislation in relation to any of the schemes which are already the subject of remedial action or legislation by the present Government.

It is not surprising that Senator Evans did not speak on the legislation in May. He did not take part in the debate at all, and I see from the speakers list tonight that he is not taking part in this debate either. I am not surprised, because he is the one person opposite who has a conscience on these matters and obviously he is not prepared to be here.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an outrageous statement! You ought to be ashamed of yourself. Why don't you speak when there is legislation to deal with disadvantaged people?

—I am afraid the honourable senator is a windbag who will interrupt anyone's speech. I will seek the protection of the Chair only if necessary; otherwise I will go ahead and make the speech which I intend to make. Neither the Minister nor the media of this country will stop me from doing so. I point out that one of the Labor Party's strongest supporters when this new Bill was introduced in May this year was a gentleman by the name of Tim Margetts, a strong Labor Party man. He had this to say in relation to that Bill, which was only a little different from this one:

SPEECH.PARA: From my reading of the Bill and explanatory memorandum, it would seem that the Government intends now to impose a further recoupment tax on the vendor- shareholders of these companies. This penal tax-
I remind honourable senators that it is a penal tax-

will operate on the assumption that as the companies now cease to exist, it will be assumed that their total assets should be treated as distributions back to the shareholders and then taxed as dividends in their hands.

This assumption and consequently the operation of the Bill is in complete contradiction to our present system of taxation of companies and ignores all the tax laws concerning distributions on liquidation of the company itself.

Of course it is penal legislation. The idiocy of the argument that Senator Tate tried to raise-that penal tax has to be a criminal tax; that is, there has to be a crime! This penal tax may send people into bankruptcy and may require them to pay 81 per cent tax. I have had plenty of examples given to me of that. They are penalties indeed, and this is penal legislation if it is anything. I voted against that Bill in June of this year. I also proceeded to take an interest in this Bill when it came up. I point out that what was said in the other House in May by the shadow Treasurer, John Howard, rather succinctly points out the difference between the legislation of May and this legislation as against the Fraser Government's legislation. He said, as reported in the Hansard record of that debate:

This legislation goes far beyond the recoupment concept contained in last year' s legislation and it will not be supported by the Opposition parties in this place or elsewhere. The legislation is not a mere toughening up of the recoupment legislation that passed through the Parliament last year. It not only retrospectively imposes a capital gains tax but also seeks to collect a new tax which has never been the subject of an illegal evasion, which was the single distinguishing point about the legislation introduced by the former Government and supported by the then Labor Opposition last year.

That is what the legislation was doing last year; it was collecting moneys which were due and which the ordinary taxpayers of the country should not have had to pay. Those who gained the benefit had to pay. There were some people in those areas who might well have been said to have been innocent. I am sure some of them who suffered were quite innocent. Many others were greedy; others were deliberate. I have no doubt that that legislation was justified on a completely different basis to this year's legislation, which is of a different character altogether.

I came into this matter because certain scraps of news and scuttlebutt appeared in Australian Financial Review, the newspaper about which Senator Tate was so keen. Look at this headline: 'Lib senator wavers'. The paper described my attitude and said that if one Liberal senator changed his mind, it would make all the difference. Of course that led to dozens, even hundreds, of people writing to me. I have been filled with information since that time. Of course this, as we all know, was a deliberate attempt by some enemy of mine in Canberra to do me some harm by suggesting that there was a leakage from the Party room. The article states:
The senator expressed his opposition to the Liberal-National Party's decision to vote against the legislation at a joint parties meeting in Canberra on Tuesday.
I have already denied that. I made it very clear to the Age when it repeated that rubbish that that was untrue and that certainly I had not done that. The article continues:
Several Opposition senators are also thought to have expressed reservations at private discussions about moving to block the legislation.

I do not know exactly what that means, but the Australian Financial Review then mentioned my name in the next paragraph. This was on the front page of this estimable journal. The writer of the article rang me the next day and asked whether I wanted to reply to it, did I want to refute it. I said: 'Certainly not , you have presumed to take the stupidities which people put to you for obvious reasons; so you will have to wait to hear what I say in this debate'. So he can wait to hear what I say in this debate tonight. That goes for the other newspapers that have my pretty picture and various things about 'Liberal waverers', 'a rebel Liberal passing the Bill' and all that, all based on a lot on nonsense because we were talking about something else, perhaps of more importance, in the Party room when this matter was so greatly distorted. I come back to the fact that we are concerned about this legislation. I have taken an interest because people have written to me, and I am sure that many of them are people whom one should take with a grain of salt. Others have justifiable cases to put, and I have gained a great deal of information from the material I have read.

So I come to the view I have formed on this Bill. I heard what Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said about the nature of the Bill tonight. Yes, I agree with what she said. Of course the Bill has some minor alterations from the previous legislation, but they are not of any great consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only about 200 million bucks worth; not much for people like you .

—Well, it does not cover a number of years; it covers one year and it is doing one or two of these things. Basically, the whole structure of the Bill is the same and there is a new tax. In discussing this Bill on 7 September 1983 in the House of Representatives, Mr Howard had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we have nothing better from the Government than this scaled down but still objectionable version of the legislation, which was not really anti-tax avoidance legislation but in many parts retrospective capital gains tax legislation and which was rejected by the Parliament in May. So not only does the Opposition state here and now that it will oppose this legislation at all stages in both houses of parliament but also it states quite categorically that this is further evidence of the emptiness and bankruptcy of the claim made by the Labor Party in opposition that we have been soft on the tax avoidance industry. It is the Government which has demonstrated this by its inaction and its inability to act because there are no substantial sophisticated tax avoidance arrangements left to strike at.

What in fact this legislation says is that certain people have been attacked and have had to pay moneys. These people are now the victims. We can squeeze them still further; we can destroy their companies. Nobody will come to their rescue; the Opposition will be blackmailed because its members will fear that they will be branded as supporters of tax avoiders or tax evaders. I have a good record in this regard to show that I have never supported these people. I never had any knowledge of or interest in this area when I was a practising lawyer. But the fact is that it is easy to get at these people. It is easy to drive them to the wall.

This is all that the present Government has been able to come up with as new tax avoidance legislation in respect of the thousands of millions of dollars that it claims was being evaded. The fact is, of course, that it is a new tax and it has been formulated on a completely different basis. It is all right for Senator Tate to say: 'Oh, yes, we imposed it last year on those people whose companies went into liquidation into the bottom of the harbour and so forth, and now we will act as though that never happened, as though the companies still continued and we will tax them'. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has pointed out the absurdity that proceeds from that situation. It assumes, of course, that people who continued to operate their companies would have been subject to Division 7 tax. Is it not the limit for Division 7 tax that the Labor Party was going to abolish as one of its election promises?

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred per cent retention.

—Yes, 100 per cent retention. The Labor Party was going to make it absolute. But when it comes to the victims who have been 'fingered' by this legislation, of course the Government ignores the fact that they have a right to withhold some of their profits. No, the Government works on the basis that they are absolute economic idiots and would proceed, of course, to distribute all their profits and pay tax on them. This Bill is based on something that they would not have done.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said, as Mr Howard has said, that this is a restrospective capital gains tax. I do not have a 100 per cent absolute objection to capital gains tax. Perhaps we will have to look at that subject some time or another in a rational way. I think that all parties will have to look at this tax as a way in which we can spread the tax burden. But this Bill creates a retrospective capital gains tax, imposed on a few selected people and companies. Of course the tax is penal. Of course it is vindictive; because it is deliberately designed to take the people who the Government thinks are least able to defend themselves. Of course it is going to send to the wall a number of companies that are still in existence and operating at a time when the Government is doing so little to overcome unemployment in this country. With all its promises, it proceeds, of course, to put many people into the position where they have no jobs. It is a personal tax on profits which would be lawfully retained and would not be taxable.

I want to mention one or two things that have been said in material I have received from a number of sources in regard to this matter. All members of the Senate received a document from the Taxation Institute of Australia, an organisation which I think has a good general repute. On 9 September the Institute wrote to all members of this chamber and the other chamber pointing out various facts and giving examples of the way in which the legislation would work. The Institute in its document came to the following conclusions:

Suppose in the year ended 30 June 1978 the company returned a profit of $120, 000 from trading activities alone, but the Commissioner disallowed portion of an investment allowance claim and increased this figure to $122,500.
That is just an increase of $2,000. The Institute further stated:
Suppose the company paid tax . . . of $55,200, lodged a notice of objection and left outstanding tax of $1,150 on the disputed $2,500.
Of course, the result is that the company is really hit to leg later on when it is taxed. The example concluded with the following words:
For the past justified non payment of $1,420, therefore, the vendor shareholders will be subjected to an additional $27,452.25 in tax or a shift in the tax rate from 56.8 per cent to 79.21 per cent.

Not penal activities! Other examples show that the rate goes up in some cases to 81 per cent. They show that if somebody in a year just has not paid or that there has been some objection to some relatively small amount they come within the scope of the legislation and would be caught if the legislation went through the Parliament.
I have also had an interesting memorandum from Mr R. K. O'Connor, a lawyer who has taken a very considerable interest in this matter. He pointed out:
The Bill imposes a personal tax liability on profits lawfully retained within the company, and which are not currently subject to tax of the nature now proposed.
Later in his document he comes to various conclusions and says:
The whole premise of the Bill is based on a fundamental misconception. The following passage appears on page 3 of the Second Reading Speech-

'Rather, those persons should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners, they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of after-tax profits that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands'.
He says:
This is clearly wrong. 'If the companies had continued to operate as going concerns' they were entitled to retain $60,000 which would never have been subjected to tax.
This Bill has been concocted in a flimsy way on things which never happened or which would be done only by lunatics in charge of companies and not by people with any business sense whatsoever.

The legislation, of course, reaches into the past to deal with people in this way. It also imposes a new tax on people who have already paid under the 1982 legislation, people who had to make decisions in 1982 and also at the time lost their grounds for objection. They could have objected to the assessments if they had know that they were going to be liable for bigger and further imposts. They perhaps would not have paid and would have challenged the assessments. But, of course, this is another example of retrospectivity. Now we are telling them that the judgment that they made to pay was wrong and if this Bill goes through they will be ruined beyond redemption.
Other people have written to me and raised other matters. McNally and Partners, a firm of chartered accountants, put it in this way.

The new Bill highlights the compounding dangers of retrospectivity. Many people who may have had some right of objection against the existing legistation have forgone those rights because of the stigma created by the Government's propaganda and the incentive of obtaining twelve months interest free to pay. Had they known that there would be another 50 per cent of tax to pay they have not forgone their rights, however they now have no choice as after the sixty days have expired (which in their case has already expired) they have no further rights of objection.

This reminds one, of course, of what Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said about the Dawkins case and the particular benefits which he or the company with which he is associated is going to gain. People did not know they would have these rights. They were not told.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might have paid their assessments.

—They paid their assessments and committed themselves. One is reminded of the well-known American statement of what the people wanted and what they formed was a government of laws and not a government of men-not a government that just provides for what powerful individuals will do but a government that will provide laws which are fair and just among people.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not understand all of the ramifications of this extraordinarily complex legislation. But one can see that this is a piece of legislation which really could be said not to be the Evans or the Attorney-General's legislation but very much the Dawkins-Walsh type of Bill, very much the vindictive type of way of dealing with people who, it is believed, are down and can be ground into the earth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the people that your former Prime Minister identified as thieves.

—I have always been something of an admirer of Senator Walsh. He has a good brain. He has an ability to speak and argue well. But he ruins it all the time by the vindictiveness with which he operates and the stupid and childish way in which he personally grinds victims he thinks he can destroy. I say that this is a case of trying to destroy.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other aspects of this legislation which I will not go into, matters which, as has been pointed out, are being removed by the legislation. I believe two members of the Australian Democrats are putting up the idea of an anomalies commission. This is not the sort of Bill which an anomalies commission will do anything about. I say with the greatest respect to Senator Jack Evans and Senator Colin Mason that I believe they tend to damage their reputations by having anything at all to do with this legislation. They cannot clean up the legislation by way of an anomalies commission hoping that it will overcome the problem. What will this do to the people who will be destroyed by the legislation? If there are a few anomalies do they intend to overcome them? It is not a matter of anomalies. It is a vicious penal tax which is disguising the lack of other Government action.

In conclusion, I want to make two other points. In this legislation there is reference to the 1982 legislation and to a constitutional challenge which has been made against it. I will not talk about the details of that because the matter is sub judice and has not yet been determined by the High Court of Australia. There is some concern about evidentiary provisions in the Bill which the Government is seeking to alter. They are extraneous to this new legislation, but they are there. It is argued that they may be necessary if, in fact, the High Court should find against the Government. I want to say this: I think it would be quite improper for this Parliament to interfere, when litigation is before the Court, to take away people's rights and therefore to alter the situation. If that defect, which is of a legal nature, were to upset the 1982 legislation, I for one and I hope my colleagues would be ready to vote for any remedial legislation that was necessary to repair that defect. It is not a matter which should be dealt with in this place or at this time. It is a matter which I am sure the Parliament would readily remedy so that the laws which were approved by this Parliament have effective operation.

In the last case, I say this: We are seeking to remove what is fortuitously a Budget Bill. It just happens to be before us at the time of the Budget. Of course, the Bill, in a slightly different form, was before us in May. One cannot be mesmerised by something that is introduced in a Budget context. Tonight we heard the remarks which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle made about the way in which an Opposition should face up to legislation and that there would be rare occasions, of course, when we would not pass normal Budget and Budget-type legislation. That is true. However, on those occasions we may feel disposed and compelled to reject legislation, as well as amend it, when it is demonstrated to be capricious, arbitrary or vindictive-those were Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's words-and when it creates new tax burdens of a retrospective kind.

The Australian Democrats and the Labor Party had a lot of difficulty in deciding whether they would vote against Government legislation. They jumped around last year and the year before in a very curious way. In the past I have criticised them for it. I will not go into it now. Regarding the criteria which were enunciated by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, these two Bills come within every description of them. They are penal, capricious, arbitrary, vindictive and they create new burdens of a retrospective kind. I believe, along with Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and the Opposition-there has never been any reason to think that I would not-that it would be abhorrent to the public if we, in our duty as legislators, did not vote against the legislation. I will certainly, with great pleasure, vote to defeat these Bills in the belief that they are obnoxious to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on behalf of not only myself but also Senator Chipp and Senator Haines. The basic proposition upon which we agree is that, since the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill imposes a new penal retrospective tax, we will be opposing it when it comes to a vote in the Senate. Senator Chipp, Senator Haines and I are three of only nine members of the entire Parliament who have consistently voted against retrospectivity. I believe every citizen has a basic human right to know whether an activity is legal when the action itself is performed. Such a situation cannot be obtained if, at some later stage, that activity is retrospectively declared to be illegal. That essentially is the argument on retrospectivity. Further, I believe it is a requirement of any just democratic legal system that a person should not be declared guilty without a trial before jurors or peers. Guilt by legislation is, I believe, abhorrent to any democratic method of government. The fact that the actions of many who were caught by this legislation were lawful is beyond question. If they were not then new legislation would not be needed-only effective prosecution under existing legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This amending Bill undoubtedly imposes a new tax. It does not simply seek to reimpose existing tax in a new way. This amendment imposes a new personal tax liability on profits lawfully retained within a company and which are not currently, under legislation, subject to tax. It has been declared by the High Court of Australia that when shareholders sold their shares the proceeds they received in respect of the sale were of a capital nature. If the Government does not think that the people ought to be able to retain all of that capital then it can impose a capital gains tax. It has chosen not to do so. The capital nature of the proceeds is, of course, recognised by the Government, since this Bill would also have been unnecessary if the proceeds that people received had been otherwise assessable. I think those two elements are extremely important: It was lawful and it was capital. The Government, by introducing this legislation in these very terms, has said that this is so.

If we take it from there, I think it is a very easy step to see why I believe honourable senators ought to oppose this legislation. The Bill seeks to assess tax on imputed dividends which were not actually decalared or paid. This Bill continues the fallacy of the May Bill which the Govermnent introduced, that tax was avoided in respect of retained allowances. The sale of a current year profit company would not have involved an obligation to pay out the retention allowance . This particular absurd notion suggests that the advice from the Department of the Treasury is out of touch with all company practice in Australia. Retained capital is a company. That is what a company is. It is often the major source of capital reinvestment in plant and equipment. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech, very interestingly, said:
. . . Persons should also pay the tax that . . .they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form . . .would have been taxable as dividends in their hands.

This is simply false. There is no obligation in law to distribute the retention allowance. Goodness, that is, after all, what 'retention' means. One retains the money. One does not distribute it. Therefore the suggestion that the Government has made that a company would have distributed that which it retained must be the most absurd notion that has ever been introduced into this Parliament. No tax liability upon a company or its shareholders arises at the point of sale. That is another item that has been used not only in this Bill but also in the former Liberal-National Party Government's Bill. That does not occur. Therefore, to talk about a sale as somehow being relevant in this situation is another attempt to confuse an otherwise bemused public on this aspect.

The assumption that the Government is making to get its Bill through is unrealistic, because it assumes thoroughly irresponsible actions on the part of management, actions for which management could be held to be accountable in law. When prudent managers plan the affairs of their company they do so in such a way as to minimise tax. I assume that most Government senators would do so in relation to their own personal affairs. Certainly, any prudent person in the community ought to do so. It is absurd, therefore, for the Government to suggest that if companies had continued in business they would have paid more than their lawful requirements. Managers and accountants have a legal duty to minimise tax. I refer to two recent cases to support this contention. In the recent case in the House of Lords-I quote that case although it is not now pertinent to Australian law but it is very interesting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate used it.

—He did indeed. The case was Inland Revenue Commissioners versus Burmah Oil. Lord Fraser held that not only was it perfectly honest and respectable for directors to act on professional advice but also it was the duty of directors to seek such advice. I quote from the judgment:

SPEECH.PARA: It was the duty of Burmah's Directors to take such lawful steps as were open to them to minimise the impact of tax on the company's profits, and in carrying out this scheme they acted upon professional advice from reputable sources.

The Bill proposes to increase the tax on persons who acted on legal advice which , if they were directors, they were duty bound to seek. Furthermore, the Full Court of South Australia on 18 May this year found an accountant guilty of negligence for failing to warn a client not to sell until the expiration of 12 months to avoid the provisions of section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act . We now have the extraordinary situation facing directors and accountants that directors could be subject to a claim for negligence if they failed to seek advice and accountants if they failed to give advice, yet in this area, the advice the accountants were legally bound to give and the directors to seek is directly contrary to the assumption of this Act.

We now have the ultimate absurdity and destructiveness of retrospective legislation in that it creates contrary legal obligations on the same people for the same actions at the same time. That, essentially, is the heinousness of retrospective legislation. A person cannot fulfil two directly contrary legal obligations. Directors could have been prosecuted if they had followed the assumptions of this Bill. Indeed, if they had not sought to minimise their tax they could have been prosecuted. Accountants could have been prosecuted it they had failed to give that advice as we found out in May this year. Yet, now the Government is assuming for the purposes of this Act, that a person would have done otherwise.

I reiterate-I do so only briefly as I want to cut down on the amount of time that we will spend on this legislation; we had a very lengthy debate on this matter earlier this year-that companies rarely distribute more than the prescribed sufficient distribution in order to maximise retained earnings. The Government, in running for office this year, as part of its small business policy-Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has already alluded to this-put up a policy of 100 per cent retention allowance for small business, which the Australian Democrats supported wholeheartedly. Perhaps somebody should tell the Treasurer (Mr Keating) what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been promising so that we do not have people branded as crooks who are currently retaining 70 per cent of the allowance when the Government has promised that they could retain 100 per cent. If we are going to get into the business of making retrospective assumptions let us, at the very least make reasonable and logical ones and not assume that business followed absurd and improvident courses of action.

There are a number of other anomalies in the Act, one of which, rather interestingly, was the subject of an amendment which I moved unsuccessfully to the Liberal-National Party Government legislation on evidence. The Government has now found that it should have accepted that amendment and the Opposition should have supported it in the first place. I refer to one other item in conclusion. The Commissioner of Taxation does not have discretion in applying the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill. Companies which did not enter into any scheme at all may be caught up under this legislation. I quote the case which relates to the issue of an amended assessment during the years covered by this legislation. Amended assessments can be given for many reasons. I take for the purposes of an example an investment allowance on something which was sold within 12 months of acquisition. That is a fairly normal case in business where a person may buy machinery which he finds is inappropriate and therefore would need an amended assessment because he had claimed. So I take that as an example and I take, for ease, a rounded figure. For example, if 100 per cent of an investment allowance were disallowed, that would result in $46 of primary tax which would become due in that year. If, in the company we are talking about, there are retained profits of $100,000 the tax liability created by this Bill would be $67,000 instead of $46. I would be very interested to hear the Government's--

TALK.START.PARA: —Instead of $46,000.

—No, $46, because of the way that the Act is structured. It catches up all companies which have an amended assessment during that period. No discretion is allowed to the Commissioner in applying the provisions of the Bill . It actually refers to amended assessments which are not to do with any scheme whatsoever. The order of the difference is absolutely staggering. I presume that is why the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) questioned me whether the figure was $46,000. No, it is not under those circumstances that I have given. That is an anomaly which could be cleaned up by the Government amending its Bill. I believe that, if the Bill passes the second reading, the Government certainly needs to do so because there would be, I imagine, thousands of cases of people who would need to have amended assessments for legitimate reasons in the companies which are still continuing under the same shareholders who have not entered into any scheme. The only essence, of course, is that the company may have been sold.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe then that this Bill reiterates the problem of retrospective legislation. I believe that the amendments that will be proposed by Senator Mason and Senator Jack Evans while certainly improving the Bill do not add sufficient weight to warrant my voting for this Bill on the basis that the Bill introduces anomalies. I, therefore, see it as inappropriate to establish a body to deal with anomalies that are being introduced by the very Bill for which one is voting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this occasion to talk about my difficulty with retrospective taxation. I am on record in this Parliament as criticising governments from the Whitlam era through to the present Government on the basis that we have not exploited the taxation legislation effectively, we have not exploited the companies legislation effectively and we have not exploited crimes legislation effectively to deal with these sorts of measures. My attention was drawn to a paper which is probably the only independent assessment that I have looked at from the Department of the Parliamentary Library dealing with this legislation. I am grateful for the fact that Senator Harradine called my attention to it. I draw the Senate's attention to these matters. Page 7 of the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The amendment assumes that retained earnings are distributed 100 per cent to shareholders. In reality, companies rarely distribute more than a sufficient distribution in order to maximise retained earnings to fund working capital, stocks, debtors, etc. Under existing taxation law a large portion of current year trading profits can be retained within the company tax free.
YEAR ENDED 30 JUNE 1980 Where a sufficient distribution is not made, additional tax (undistributed profits tax) is incurred.

This Bill seeks to tax these retained profits and hence results in an additional tax liability over and above that which would have been incurred by vendor-shareholders had the company not been sold. The additional tax liability can be illustrated as follows.
I do not want to read out all of that. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate that table and the rest of the document in Hansard so that I will not delay the Senate unduly.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Normal Position

$ $ Trading Income 100 100 Company Tax A46 46 Income after tax 54 54 Retention allowance 70% 38 . . Dividend 16 54 Income Tax in hands of shareholders on:
(i) normal dividend (60%) B10 (ii) deemed dividend (61.07%) 33
Total Tax A + B 56 79

Increase in tax 41 per cent. In practice, shareholders in private companies may decide not to make a sufficient distribution and simply pay undistributed profits tax at 50 per cent which is considerably lower than the maximum personal rate of tax. Thus under the circumstances the tax increase in the above example would be 46 per cent. The 'Principal Act' is effective in recouping the undistributed profits tax and hence all the tax that was payable by companies sold in ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' schemes.

Further, because the Bill deems a dividend to be paid at the time of sale of the shares, personal tax at a higher rate will be imposed on the 'deemed dividend' than if the dividend had been paid in the normal manner, usually by 30 April of the following year. This is due to the gradual reduction in the maximum personal marginal rate of tax (69.62 cents to 60 cents in the dollar) during the period covered by the legislation.

(2) Directed at companies sold with current year profit component (Wet Slutzkins). Companies sold to the same promoters with only retained earnings from past years (Dry Slutzkins) escape the new tax as do companies which paid their company tax but avoided their Division 7 undistributed profits tax. However, when the current year profit companies have paid their company tax and Division 7 tax under the 'Principal Act' they are no different to the Dry Slutzkin companies which have been excluded.

(3) Retained profits of earlier years. Another implication of the Bill is that retained profits of earlier years can be caught by the proposed legislation and deemed to be paid as a dividend to vendor shareholders even where there was not an intended avoidance of company tax. This could arise where a company was sold with only the company tax liability of the year of sale outstanding but subsequently, for any reason, an amended assessment is issued in relation to an earlier year resulting in an increase in the company's ordinary tax liability for that year.

(4) The Bill treats all companies in the same manner as if they had all been sent to the ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' given that the innocence clause contained in sub-section 3 (12) of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982 is to be abolished. Not all companies sold under these schemes were dumped. Some companies met all the requirements under existing tax and company law and it is the shareholders related to these companies who will be unduly penalised by the abolition of the innocence clause.

(5) Investor confidence in the share market will be affected by the proposed legislation simply because of the potential liability which some companies might face. The proposed legislation also threatens the concept of limited liability.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I have three letters that I have shown to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). I think they demonstrate the problem that exists in the community and the questions that arise as a result of the-
—It demonstrates that there are a lot of shonky accountants in the country.

—I object to that statement from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) because I think it is an incredible indictment of the accounting profession that he should say that. At least he has agreed-
—I did not say the whole profession was shonky. I just said there were a lot of shonks in it, most of whom have a close association with the Liberal Party.
—I think that is an incredible statement to make.
—It is incredibly accurate.
—I think that what the Minister is saying is an indictment on the accounting profession and I object to it. I think that he should reconsider the interjections he has made.
—You should be more concerned with your own profession, senator; it is a very honourable one.
—My profession is all right. I am not sure whether the legal profession is totally-
—Optometrist heal thyself.

—I am long sighted; you are short sighted. The legislation deals with the matter of retrospective tax. I have always demonstrated my opposition to that because it means that if we introduce these measures a lot of innocent people will be affected. I said that when we were in government. I criticised the Fraser Government for introducing retrospective tax. I criticised it for not utilising the Taxation Act-there are two or three sections of the Act that ought to have been tested-the Companies Act and the Crimes Act. I suggest that it is quite unfair that people who go into arrangements as a result of the advice of their lawyers and their accountants should be penalised in a retrospective sense , and I have always opposed that. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard four letters dealing with the subject.

Dear Senator,
TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983
DIVIDEND RECOUPMENT TAX BILL 1983
The existing legislation embodied in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982 seeks to recover from vendor shareholders:
(i) The company tax applicable to profits earned by the company in the year its shares were sold; and
(ii) The undistributed profits tax applicable to the after tax profits for the year or the tax applicable to the dividend which would have flowed to the vendor shareholders.

These measures to collect tax which the present and the former Government considred to be a proper recovery of tax which was regarded as having been previously avoided have in the main where assessments have been raised been paid or are in the process of being paid.

The proposed amendments introduced by the Treasuer at the August 1983 Budget seek to impose an additional retrospective levy upon the relevant shareholders which would not have been payable if the relevant companies had continued to operate as going concerns. The Treasuer in his second reading speech stated on page 3:

''Rather, those persons should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners, they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of after-tax profits that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands.''

What the Treasurer states is covered by the existing legislation. The proposed Bills introduce an additional liability which would not have otherwise existed if the companies were not sold and hence displays the misleading nature of the Treasurer's statement. The following simple illustration exemplifies the position. (Assuming company sold in 1977 financial year):
Existing
recoupment Proposed
legislation bills
$ $ Company taxable income in year of sale 100 100 Company tax (A) 46 46

54 54 Retention allowance (60%) 33 33 Undistributed profits 21 21 Undistributed profits tax (B) 10 nil Additionl retrospective tax (C) . . 35 ( 65% of $54) Total tax-if company continued operating as a going concern (A) + (B ) 56 . . Total tax-under proposed Bills (A) + (C) . . 81

As evident from above the avoided tax which would have been payable by the vendor shareholders had the company not been sold is 56% of the company's profits. The proposed bills seek to impose an additional retrospective liability at a rate approximating 25% thereby making the overall rate of tax a flat 81% on the company's taxable income.
Other aspects of the proposed bill which are completely unjust and inequitable are:

No allowance is made to provide a tax credit for dividends received by vendor shareholders where the bill applies to income years prior to the year of sale. In these cases taxes would have been paid by the shareholders on the dividends and the profit from which those dividends derived will be subject to he further 'dividend recoupment tax' thereby resulting in 'double-taxing' of the dividend component of those profits over and above the normal company tax paid.
The removal of section 3 (12) which provides that the recoupment legislation would be limited to those instances where illegal and fraudulent avoidance of tax is involved.
The inclusion of a section requiring the Commissioner to disclose the identities of persons who may justifiably resist any improper assessment of vendors recoupment tax.

Removal of the clause whereby vendor shareholders may require the Commissioner to provide details of the stripping arrangements utilised by promoters and which are in the Commissioner's possession or knowledge.

The Government while espousing that the tax sought to be recovered is that which would have been payable had the company continued as a 'going concern' has in the drafting of the bill ignored the fact that the company would have been entitled to a 'retention allowance' if it continued as a going concern and that in the case of just about all private companies this retention allowance is not distributed to shareholders and hence not subject to tax.
The proposed bills:
1. Have been presented to Parliament by the Government on misleading, unconscionable and reprehensible bases, which is borne out on an analysis of the complex verbiage of bills.
2. Retrospectively impose on vendor shareholders a punitive additional tax liability which would not have been payable had the companies not been sold.
3. In some instances impose a higher and harsher liability to tax than that of similar improper legislation defeated in the Senate in May 1983.
4. Seek to tax vendor shareholders on dividends never received.
5. Continue a dangerous precedence of restrospective taxation going back a decade and hence causing considerable harm to future commercial trade.
For the foregoing reasons these bills must not be permitted to pass through the Senate.
Should any further clarification or explanation be required on the matters raised the writer may be contacted at the address on this letterhead or by telephone.
Yours faithfully, Borough and Partners

Dear Mr Keating
We refer to reply from your Assisting Minister to correspondence last May regarding the former Retrospective Penal Tax Bill. This reply was dated 23rd September and received on the 4th October.

To some degree one can understand, that with the pressures of new Government it could take over four months to reply to this matter. It is inconceivable however that with all the advice available to your department neither your Assisting Minister, nor your Department, and therefore presumably the Government, understands the ramifications of the modified Bill.
The reply states that the modified Bill will be:
'confined to such tax avoided in respect of the liberated after-tax profits'.

Let there be no misunderstanding-there were no 'liberated after-tax profits'. The only cash 'liberated' was the promoters fee and the Bill does not even try to tax the promoter. Innocent vendor shareholders who are taxed under the Bill received no distribution of 'liberated after-tax profits', and in fact did not even receive any benefit, other than the benefit accruing to the Company for tax it would have paid, which is currently being paid under the previous Governments retrospective legislation. All other monies were reinvested in the same business and thereby in the continuing employment of Australians for the betterment of Australia.

If there were cases where businesses ceased completely, then perhaps in those cases there could be 'liberated after-tax profits' but the Bill is not confined to such cases. Perhaps you might enquire from your colleague The Honourable Mr Dawkins as to the date and the amounts of distributions he received from ' liberated after-tax profits' from his involvement in such matters in order to justify the assertion, that the tax 'would be confined to such tax avoided in respect of liberated after-tax profits'. Incidentally this apparent misleading statement was also made in the second reading speech and is contained on page 3 of the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill.
The last paragraph clearly demonstrates how out of touch your Department is with respect to this matter. It states-
''the Government believes that, with these changes, the legislation is now in a form which responds adequately to all reasonable criticisms of the original measures''.

If this is so, why all the controversy in the press? and the current consideration by the Government of proposed amendments by Senators Colin Mason and Jack Evans?, to say nothing of the fact that even with such amendments the Bill faces defeat in the Senate.

The Government will lose absolute credibility if it agrees to amendments which will exclude from the operation of the Bill a Government Minister but not others who did not receive any ''liberated after-tax profits''.

In any case any amendment which excludes from the operation of the Bill Public Company shareholders who have sold their shares (and thus had a distribution in cash) but includes shareholders who received no cash or benefit but fully reinvested in their business and thereby the future of Australia and the employment of fellow Australians would be a travesty of justice and a blight on the Australian Parliament.
Because of the apparent lack of understanding, the matter should be reconsidered by all members of Parliament. To do this properly a little history is needed.

We suggest that it is too easy for the Parliament to seek to judge in accordance with 1983 community attitudes, actions which took place mainly in the period from 1972 to 1980. It should be remembered that the attitudes within the community, and apparently also within the Government at that time in relation to tax avoidance were somewhat different. By way of illustration of the attitudes of the Parliament, which were we believe a fair reflection of the attitudes of the community at the time, the decision of the High Court in Curran v FC of T ( 74 ATC4296) was handed down on 4th November 1974. The decision in effect '' approved'' an arrangement which could only be called a blatant tax avoidance arrangement. No law was introduced to overcome this situation by successive Labor and Liberal/Country Party Governments until 1978 when law was introduced affected from 16th August 1977.

Through the same period tax avoidance arrangements, known as Section 36A and Section 36 schemes were well known in the business community for about two years before amending legislation was introduced to prevent them. It appears that both the Government and the Tax Office were aware of these schemes but it took two to three years from the time they became well known, to the time they were effectively outlawed.

It was in this context that vendors sold their shares. Competitive pressures on industry were such that if a business persons competitor ''sold'' his Company and so avoided the payment of income tax for one year, the money so freed was used to gain a competitive advantage by increasing stocks and debtors, and possible by employing more people to increase production and thus lower selling prices. In these situations, and in the competitive business world, competitors were required by economic pressures to follow the same course of action in order to compete. The free enterprise system has survived as long as it has because of such reactions. These reactions are a normal and natural part of business survival and should not, we suggest, be punished harshly in accordance with different standards long after the event.

Not only did the Government of the day and the community appear to condone these practices, but arguably the Australian Taxation Office did also. It has been suggested publicly by prominent Lawyers that the Taxation Office could have used several sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act to collect much of the income tax that the existing recoupment tax legislation now seeks to collect. To our knowledge the Australian Taxation Office did not take any of these steps. And in fact at one taxation seminar attended by the writer the Commissioner stated that a policy decision had been made within the department not to pursue such matters.
We mention these matters not as recrimination but merely to remind you of the prevailing attitudes and the apparent reasons for them at the times that companies were sold.

All taxes previously avoided are currently being collected from innocent vendor shareholders by existing retrospective legislation. If you have any doubt whatsoever about this statement seek the advice of any of the leading firms of Accountants and/or Lawyers or better still seek the advice of the various Professional Accounting and Legal bodies.
The new Bill is penal as it seeks to increase the tax payable from that avoided , namely 54.1 per cent to an average of 81.1 per cent.

It is too easy we suggest to say 'it serves them right', in view of the prevailing attitudes of the Government, the Tax Office, and the community, and commercial pressures of the times. The vendors acted within normal community attitudes and the fact that most of them have now paid their share of tax, or made arrangements to do so, should we suggest be sufficient. To go beyond that point appears to us to be extreme and likely to lead to severe financial hardship, possible more unemployment, as effective rates of tax will be in excess of 81 per cent remembering also that there has been a percentage of revenue paid to a promoter.

We further suggest that the proposed removal of the so called 'innocence clauses' is inequitable and unjust. Normal prudent business people who sought proper advice in relation to these transactions were aware of possible Crimes Act and Companies Act problems as well as the Income Tax Assessment Act problems . Persons who sought proper advice in these matters received advice that they should sell their shares to a reputable purchaser who in the terms of those times, and in the context outlined earlier in this letter, sought out a suitable and apparently effective scheme (in most cases sanctioned by eminent Q.C.'s and even in some cases sanctioned by the High Court) to remove the profits from the company without incurring any income tax liability.

We suggest that such vendors were acting to protect their businesses, and the jobs that those businesses provided, and that as they had taken proper advice and at all times, both before and after the sale, the companies were correctly maintained in relation to all statutory requirements and that moreover no offence was committed by any party against the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 even if that Act had been in force at the relevant time, that they should not be penalised by this Bill.

In any case whatever happened to your Governments policy of consensus and accord. Is it consensus and accord to impose retrospectively a new penal tax on one section of the community (whose innocence can no longer be doubted from Mr Dawkins' own experience) for economic or other reasons?
Finally we would like to conclude with a quotation from the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights-

'No one should be held guilty of an offence on account of any act or omission which did not constitute an offence at the time it was committed. Nor shall a heavier penalty be imposed than the one that was applicable at the time the offence was commited'.

Perhaps Members of Parliament can satisfy their conscience in acting contrary to the United Nations Universal Declatation of Human Rights on the basis of fair shares of taxation. There are no conceivable circumstances to justify the imposition of a severe penal tax up to ten years after the happening of a perfectly legal transaction. In the name of justice the Bill should be withdrawn and not even debated.

Surely it is time to forget about the past and any form of retrospective penal taxation which will only serve to divide the community and distract the Government from providing good and positive government to ensure that present and future generations of Australians enjoy all the benefits which this great country is capable of providing.
With Compliments McNally & Partners R. F. McNally

Letter from McNally and Partners to Senator Mason
McNALLY & PARTNERS CHARTERED ACCOUNTANTS
Robert McNally, A.C.A.; John D. Green, A.C.A.; Richard W. Deveson, A.C.A.; Richard T. Arnold, A.C.A.; Leon R. Rosengren, A.C.A.; Dennis J. Klein, A.C.A.; Frank Lord, A.C.A.
McNally House, 367 Kent Street, Sydney 2000. Australia

17th October 1983
Senator Colin Mason
The Senate
Parliament House
Canberra 2600
Dear Senator
Re: Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983; Dividend Recoupment Tax Act 1983

We understand that both yourself and Senator Evans have suggested certain changes to the above Bills primarily aimed at protecting vendor shareholders who were not aware of the circumstances surrounding the sale of their company.
Whilst this proposed amendment is to be applauded we would respectfully draw your attention to possible inequitities which it could create.

For example if a Public Company shareholder sold his shares on the market ( after the sale of a subsidiary of the public company to a promoter) being comletely unaware of the sale to the promoter, he would presumably receive the benefit of a better price for his shares brought about by the sale of the subsidiary at a price exceeding its true net worth (that is excluding its liability for tax). In such a case the shareholder may have received a real distribution of ''liberated after-tax profits'', such distribution being reflected in the sale price of his shares. Our understanding is that your proposed amendment would exclude such a shareholder from the operation of the Bill.

On the other hand if a Private Company shareholder reinvests all monies in the same business (and thereby investing in the continuing employment of Australians for the betterment of Australia), and accordingly receives no distribution whatsoever of ''liberated after-tax profits'', he would nevertheless be caught by the imposition of additional penal tax under the Bill even after your proposed amendment.
Surely such a situation would be a travesty of justice.
This is not to suggest that either shareholder should be subject to the Bill as they are both Innocent Vendor Shareholders.

If there has to be a retrospective Bill to tax ''liberated after-tax profits'' (Note ''liberated after-tax profits'' is the term used by the Minister in his second reading speech and on page 3 of the explanatory memorandum to define the income that the Bill taxes) surely an essential element should be that a '' benefit'' has been received and anyone whether a Public or Private Company shareholder, whether with or without knowledge of the sale to a promoter, who can demonstrate that he or she did not receive any ''liberated after-tax profits '' and/or any benefit, and in fact the business continued in an indentical fashion, must be excluded from the operation of the Bill.
The Bill tabled in the Senate makes the completely unrealistic assumption that 100 per cent of retained earnings were ''liberated'' to shareholders.

Let there be no misunderstanding-where the same businesses continued, there were no ''liberated after-tax profits'' and accordingly innocent vendor shareholders are being saddled with a penal tax not only never previously avoided, but based on income never received. The Bill is so immoral and unjust it should be withdrawn and not even debated.

Enclosed is a copy of a letter written to the Treasurer (which is provided with the Treasurer's knowledge) which will assist with your consideration of the matter. We are conscious of the time restraints on you, but would very much appriate your consideration of the attached letter prior to the debate.
With Compliments McNally & Partners R. F. McNally
