TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I oppose the principle of what we are dealing with. I think retrospectivity is bad and should not be allowed to persist in Australia. I suggest that-
—There should be a constitutional amendment. While we are running referendums there should be a referendum about this whole matter.
—That is right. I think Senator Townley has a private member's Bill dealing with this subject. I think he should introduce it as soon as possible, and I will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also take the opportunity to speak on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill. I shall make my comments brief. The Bill entails measures which the Government has promised to implement. It received a mandate from the Australian electorate so to do when it went to the election at the start of this year. The proposals are also those that were put forward very clearly and explicitly by the Australian Labor Party when in opposition last year. They attempt to redress a situation which has been developing over recent years. We recognise the inequalities and the injustices in the tax system, and we recognise those who are paying tax and those who are evading tax. These measures are an attempt to work towards redressing that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The need is one which has been highlighted all the more so in reports tabled in this Parliament last year emanating from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The extent of the industry, the degree to which it was affecting Australian life, was highlighted in the interim report when the Commissioner said:

The industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last 5 years, at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian goldrush . . . the impact on the community has been very serious.

All Costigan did then was to highlight the complaints that the Commissioner of Taxation had been highlighting in his annual reports from approximately 1978 onwards. He highlighted a massive increase in tax evasion. He identified tax participants and the degree to which they had increased in the industry. He had in fact highlighted that in the last five full years of the Fraser Government there had been an increase of 2,500 per cent in the number of identified participants in tax avoidance. Costigan also did no more than to highlight the effect of the industry on the Australian taxpayer, as had been mentioned previously by Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association. In numerous instances he mentioned that the tax avoidance industry was costing Australian taxpayers over $7 billion.

In fact the more recent Costigan report, which was tabled last week, indicated the magnitude of the loss to revenue as a result of the tax avoidance industry. The industry has led to one of the most noted commentators on taxation and federalism in Australia, Professor Mathews, claiming in 1980 that personal income tax was now voluntary for the rich non-salary earner. That comment highlights the particular problem that any government had faced. Of course the scandals of last year highlighted the inactivity by, and inadequacy of the response of, the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia in relation to the problem.

Report after report highlighted the fact that over five years or so there was dithering between the Australian Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's department, with lost files and inactivity-4 1/2 years of culpable negligence. In a report the Commissioner of Taxation advised the then Treasurer as early as 1978 or 1979:
. . . the problem of straw companies and straw trust evasion is already very serious and growing. It is my considered advice that the situation needs to be remedied urgently and with stern measures.

So what we had during the duration of the Fraser Government and at the end thereof was inequality in massive magnitudes. We had wage and salary earners whose share of the income tax cake had increased by at least twice the amount of the increase in the company tax sector. Professor Mathews said in his speech that the:
. . . taxation system has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes and wealth in favour of the rich.

What has been highlighted by the Costigan reports and others is that it is very much the company structure that is at the heart of tax avoidance. It is very much that sort of company structure that has been attacked by this legislation. In Australia we have a situation in which it costs $2 or slightly more to set up a company from which massive profits can be made. No one has highlighted that better than the notorious Peter Clyne. It led of course to Mr Costigan saying that the effect of the company law was such that we had a situation where:
. . . blue collar thuggery married to white collar crime by seemingly respectable celebrants.

The McCabe-Lafranchi report highlighted the existence of 3,000 companies which were subject to investigation. The New South Wales Government's Corporate Affairs Commission in fact highlighted 4,000 companies involved in these activities in New South Wales-shonky companies and shonky activities leading to massive rip-offs of the taxpayer. As I said earlier, we had a mandate to bring this Bill before the Parliament and to pursue it. All these Bills do, and I go to the principle of them, is demand that those who benefited from the sale of shares in companies that were stripped of pre-tax profits should not be limited in their obligation only to tax that ought to have been paid by the companies concerned. Under this legislation they should also pay that tax that the shareholders or other former owners escaped through receipt in a non-taxable form of after-tax profits that, if those companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable dividends in their hands. There is nothing novel in this approach. In fact, it is an extension of what the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, did last year in including Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

I need not go to any other authority to highlight the hypocrisy of the current Opposition than the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, who in a speech in Adelaide on 30 August last year, in his attempt to retain the seat of Kingston said that the Government would pursue the promoters. He went on:

special legislation will be introduced to recover the funds that would otherwise have been paid as tax over past years. That is not creating a new liability, it is collecting the funds that should have been paid in any case.
He went on to say:
In a real sense, the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds , whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth of stolen from other taxpayers it doesn't matter very much.
The former Prime Minister went on to say:

I was delighted when the Federal Executive of the Liberal Party last Friday, unanimously issued a statement which supported what the Federal Government is doing in relation to these particular matters. In the light of some of the publicity out of Western Australia, that particular press statement ought to be noted and ought to be given maximum publicity.

Of course, it has been forgotten now, but what has not been forgotten is the hypocrisy of the Opposition. Now not in government, now in opposition, it pursues a direction which is contrary to that of the former Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not changed.

—The trouble with the honourable senator's side is that some of them never change. I go on to the Bills and to tackle the complaint that has been mentioned by some members of the Opposition. I will conclude on this point. The point has been made that retrospectivity in legislation is something that is anathema to Liberal Party philosophy, that it is something that members of the Opposition cannot and would not contemplate. One only has to look at the history of the Liberal Party to see how selective and hypocritical it is when it comes to this sort of thing. It will attack the weak with retrospective legislation but it will not attack the vested interests that support it. We saw that this morning in its approach to the social security legislation. We also, however, see it from the start of the Liberal Party and from the founding father of the Liberal Party, Sir Robert Menzies. Let me remind the Senate of the Communist Party Dissolution Bill 1950 and let me quote, for the benefit of some honourable senators opposite, what Mr Menzies had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Not one of us in this House has any love for retrospective legislation. But quite clearly, as a matter of plain horse sense, if this bill dealt only with those who could be shown to be Communist party members on the date on which this bill becomes an act obviously there would then be no party members or officers to be affected by it and the legislation would be a complete futility. We are not prepared to facilitate a farce of that kind.

He then went on to defend a Bill with retrospective application, a Bill which in fact intended to impart into the law of this country criminal sanctions. That was Sir Robert Menzies. Let me also quote a more recent figure of the Liberal Party-in fact, the recent leader of the Liberal Party in the Upper House of Victoria, Mr Hunt, who was quoted in the Melbourne Age of 22 November last year, less than 12 months ago, in an editorial which stated:
. . . that in 21 years in Parliament he had supported more than 150 pieces of retrospective legislation with a clear conscience.
It went on:
'If anyone tells me that it is not Liberal, or contrary to principle, I say we don't belong to the same party-
It went on:

'There is no such principle that all retrospective legislation is contrary to the principles of the party. What has happened this time is that someone who didn't like bottom-of-the-harbour legislation has sought to raise a principle and use it to criticise the Government by innuendo.'
We also have instances where the courts of Australia have sanctioned the use of retrospective legislation. In the case of D'oro v. Victorian Railways Commissioner in 1960, Mr Justice Adam said:

The strength of the presumption against retrospectivity in any particular case, and accordingly the ease or difficulty with which it may be overcome, must, I would think, depend on the nature and degree of the injustice which would result from giving the statute a retrospective operation.
He later said:

On the other hand, where to give retrospective operation to a statute might be considered to work some injustice to one party, but is clearly required to rectify a manifest injustice to others, there would, on principle, seem little reason for giving much weight to the presumption.

I think I have displayed very clearly that the magnitude of the problem is one that ought to be addressed by government. It is, in fact, a major national scandal. I have not claimed that by bland assertions. I have done it by quoting from official reports and statistics. In closing on this particular point, let me refer to the editorial in the Melbourne Age of only two years ago relating to a 1915 case. That editorial stated:
. . . The High Court unambiguously determined the right of the Parliament to make actions criminal which were perfectly legal at the time they were done.
It continued:
In the 1980s, tax avoidance poses a threat to Australia, as did the somewhat more distant Kaiser Wilhelm in 1915.

I can go on and quote all sorts of authorities in respect of retrospective taxation but I will not. The point I wish to make is that this measure, this Bill, is one that attempts to address a totally unjust situation. It is one that attempts to reallocate the burden on those who, over the years, have been able to escape that burden. It does so in a fair way and with safeguards. In fact, this Government has bent over backwards to placate the demands and the interests of those who have particular criticisms to make of this legislation. In doing so , it has decreased the expected revenue from these measures from $570m to $270m and it has incorporated four major safeguards which would protect individuals. These safeguards can be listed but I believe that Senator Walsh will go into them at a later time.

The point that the Senate has to address itself to is whether it will attack the problem of tax evasion with any degree of equity and fairness at all. Will it continue to allow this sort of ripping-off, using the shell of company structures, using the tax evasion procedures that have been highlighted by commissioners such as Costigan or will it allow the intolerable taxation burden to continue to be met by the wage and salary earners of this community? My answer to that, of course, is that I would not tolerate that, and that is why I am supporting this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill seeks ultimately to recoup $270m in unpaid income tax resulting from the notorious bottom of the harbour tax evasion schemes. I am in favour of that general objective and I shall, accordingly, vote for the Bill. The bottom of the harbour schemes were simple, even crude, in their basic approach to tax evasion. As I understand them, a company with a tax liability was sold, often to persons who could not be traced, criminals and the like who assumed false names, at a figure greater than the company was really worth when its tax liability was taken into account. Then the new owners simply disappeared , having sent the company records, to use that phrase which has now, I gather, become part of the language of this country, to the bottom of the harbour, thereby allowing the old owners to avoid paying tax on the accumulated profits of the company so disposed of. There are those who say that this is justifiable, good clean fun and that probably many people used such schemes not knowing or believing that they were doing anything wrong. That may well be so, although I find it difficult to believe that people who used such a scheme did not, on the whole, know what they were doing I think they must have been fairly aware that they were depriving the state of revenue which would have to be replaced by higher taxation of their fellow citizens or, alternatively, not replaced at all, thereby placing a great burden on the poor and vulnerable in the society, who, heaven knows, are numerous enough and becoming more numerous and who need every cent and dollar of government assistance that this country can afford to give them. Those problems are not improving with the passing of time.

SPEECH.PARA: This year the country faces a huge deficit, the largest it has ever had in its history, and the general tightness of government funds is extreme. It is not possible to deal with and solve the problems of the poor and disadvantaged in the way they should be dealt with. I take the old fashioned view that those who share the protection and assets of the state, as we all do, have the strongest possible moral obligation to contribute to the cost of those things. It seems to me that a basic community morality is being abused in this case. It is being done in the name of legality. Many sins and crimes have been committed throughout history in the name of mere legality, as if legality in itself had any value in contrast with the sufferings and disadvantage of large sections of the community. That seems to me what this is about and what it always has been about.

While I can see that desperately poor and disadvantaged people would have the incentives to escape their proverty and deprivation by avoiding that obligation, I cannot see that those who can well afford to pay should feel morally that they are entitled not to pay. I do not believe that people who take that view should come to this place and seek any kind of sympathy from us or from the community on the basis that they have been hardly done by. If they do that, it seems to me to be a symptom of a serious and very dangerous national moral disease. One would have thought, as was once the case in decent societies and democracies, that the successful and enterprising people-the leaders of the community in many respects-should also take a lead in supporting reasonable public morality, especially in public affairs. There was a time when that morality was regarded as very close to a person's honour in terms of financial dealings. If one went back far enough through history one would find, for instance, that Sir Walter Scott wrote himself into the grave rather than allow himself to become bankrupt because he knew that it was honourable to pay his debts. That no longer, of course, seems to be a view of society. Bottom of the harbour schemes merely seem to be an extension of that kind of situation. If we lose that morality I think we lose a great deal.

Of course, if enough people who can afford to pay instead elect to find means to take and not to give, the national structure must become weakened. I am one of those who believe that tax evasion and tax dodging schemes generally have weakened this country substantially. That is one of the reasons why I believe those citizens of good intent-I think the majority of citizens in this country are of good intent-want this legislation to go ahead. They see it perhaps as difficult and dangerous medicine which, at times, is perhaps unfair to some citizens. What law, after all, is not unfair to some citizens? If we go back and look through the law we will find that there is very little law that has not, at some time or another, impinged unfairly or unjustly on some people. But that national malady has to be corrected.

That brings me to what I consider is the vital principle at stake in this debate. There is a conflict between the two important principles of retrospectivity and tax equity. What use is any society, democracy or, if it comes to that, any government, which cannot guarantee its citizens reasonable equity in the way the tax burden is imposed. I do not think we should tolerate a situation in which we look at the poor and the people who cannot afford to employ lawyers and accountants and say that they are to be disadvantaged to the benefit of the people who can afford those things. I think that is battering of the community. From the feedback I have had from the community, it is regarded as such by the majority of Australians and, I think, rightly so. To me the gross injustice of this situation is of much greater weight than a tax of a so-called retrospective nature as in this legislation.

How often in political affairs can one afford the luxury of unqualified support of a single principle, especially if it is in clear conflict with another principle as is certainly, I think, acknowledged in this matter. These things are matters of judgment and degree. Whilst I am not canvassing that aspect, I merely make the point that there are dangers in espousing, as the Liberal Party appears to have done, opposition to this legislation simply on the ground that it is retrospective and, therefore, bad. I think it is nonsense also to say that because a single piece of retrospective legislation might be passed for good reason the principle is thereby created and a great flood of retrospective legislation will follow. That is absolute nonsense. Matters are decided in this place and in the other place reasonably on the basis of the merits of the legislation. I would be the first to oppose punitive retrospective legislation which tried to introduce criminal penalties on a matter retrospectively. That would be completely different from this situation.

It is evident that a number of people-perhaps not a very large number of people -are now being called on to pay tax resulting from the Fraser Government's 1982 legislation to recoup company tax. These people can reasonably claim that they did not know about the bottom of the harbour schemes. From the feedback I have been getting, it involves mostly small shareholders in public companies who might have held perhaps $1,000 worth of shares or less and who made little or no profit when they sold those shares. They had no way of knowing that the directors of the companies involved had been indulging in bottom of the harbour schemes nor did these people benefit. Now, of course, are they being assessed for large sums of money in taxation under that 1982 Fraser legislation dealing with company tax. I stress the point that this involves the earlier Act which is now law.

I have received letters from people who have been hit by this legislation. That is what led Senator Jack Evans and me to conduct a series of very long and protracted negotiations with the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) assisting the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and senior officials of the Australian Taxation Office. The most recent meeting extended fairly late into last night. We brought forward the amendments which Senator Evans has circulated and which, I have no doubt, he will be discussing in more detail because I know he is following me in this debate. The amendments will provide for new functions for existing review boards to take on new guidelines and to provide, in effect, temporary anomalies commissions specifically to listen to and remedy the complaints of those people who are being unfairly taxed now! I wish to stress at this point, Mr Deputy President, that support for these amendments is contingent , I understand, on the Government's point of view-I must say that it has been very evasive on this matter-and on whether the Bill is passed at the second reading stage. Amendments can then be moved in Committee. I think it is important that these amendments are moved. They should be on the record. The Government's attitude towards the amendments should be tested at that stage. At later stages of the Bill honourable senators can take whatever steps they see fit to dispose of the Bill. I do not think it is unreasonable that these amendments should be considered because they are important. They are important to a large number of people, from whom honourable senators would have had representations just as Senator Jack Evans and I have.

At this stage the Government does not seem to know what to do about these amendments. I gather that this is due to the illness of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the fact that Cabinet will not meet until tomorrow. I find it extraordinary that a relatively small matter like this, and one which is so obviously just, cannot be dealt with by his colleagues, especially those such as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who are responsible for these matters in this area. I find it quite extraordinary that we are told that this is the situation. I would like the Government to make a plain statement on how it feels about these amendments for the benefit of all honourable senators and for those people who are being afflicted now by these assessments. Even if this Bill is defeated at the second reading stage-that, of course, would make it impossible for Senator Jack Evans to move our amendments-I hope that the Government will decide to adopt the idea of establishing the temporary anomalies commissions we have put forward to deal with those people who are being treated unjustly under the 1982 legislation. I am sure there are many honourable senators who would at least support that proposition. Regardless of the fate of this Bill, I think that the Government ought to take our view on board and consider it seriously simply because it is the right and just thing to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anybody listening to this debate tonight out there in the real world must be wondering just what has happened in this chamber between 1982 and 1983. The same noises are coming from the same sides of the House but the people who last year supported retrospective tax tonight are opposing retrospective tax. I think that the public is entitled to ask the question: What is different in principle between a Liberal-National parties retrospective tax and an Australian Labor Party retrospective tax? I think that the only genuine group in this House which has been consistent right the way through is the Australian Democrats. I pay a tribute to my four Australian Democrat colleagues who--
—What about me?

—I said that the only consistent group was the Australian Democrats. There are individuals who have been consistent. The Australian Democrats have maintained their consistency right the way through. The present Government has also maintained that stand. Later I shall explain why both of these retrospective tax Bills may be justified but also why both the 1982 Act and the 1983 Bill have been grossly unfair to some people.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to thank the many apparently innocent people who have written to me and demonstrated that democracy can work in this country and that people are willing and keen to air their views. I appreciate their advice and counsel and the expert advice that I have had from lawyers, accountants and tax experts. Most of the letters that I have received have been written to complain about the 1982 Fraser Government legislation, which indicates that both that legislation and the current legislation are undoubtedly scheduled, if this Bill is passed, to bump into some very heavy weather and to cause chaos in the community. The chaos has already commenced to become evident in Western Australia, my own State.

When the 1982 Fraser Government retrospective tax legislation was introduced, it had my support. I agreed with tax evaders being taxed, even retrospectively, on the condition that they had benefited from the exercise and that the company had been sent to the bottom of the harbour. I think that those two conditions gave sufficient evidence to all of us that these people were tax evaders, even though they may have been wearing a tax avoidance label when they carried out that act. I was not a senator at the time, so I did not have the opportunity to vote on the 1982 Fraser legislation, but I felt that there should not be an innocence provision because that would provide loopholes for some guilty parties . However, I am now very conscious of the fact that there are genuinely innocent people-perhaps hundreds of them; perhaps even thousands-who have been caught up in the net of the 1982 legislation.

I have had letters from pensioners, widows, low income earners, and even from unemployed people, who cannot afford even the few hundreds of dollars that they are being assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation and will have to pay as a result of that legislation. In most cases, these have been public company shareholders who had absolutely no knowledge of the action being taken by their company directors. As I understand it, there were even some private company shareholders who, for odd reasons, for unusual reasons, all also had no knowledge; for instance, employee shareholders who may have had no knowledge of the actions of the directors of their company. There were public and private company shareholders also whose tax assessments exceed any real or deed benefits . That is a gross injustice which needs to be remedied.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should look at the ruling that the Deputy Commissioner gave on 17 October.

—Yes, indeed. It needs to be recognised that a number of people, not the least being Senator Mason and myself, have been endeavouring to persuade Senator Walsh who is the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Commissioner of Taxation that these injustices need urgent rectification, not just in the months or the years ahead when we get down the track but to try to help people who are now suffering because they believe that they are just about to be put into court, in some cases, as a result of that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the 1983 Bill for which the Government claims to have a mandate. There may be a case for claiming further taxes from blatant tax cheats, even retrospectively. I am persuaded to the view that there is an argument that should allow the Government to carry out its mandate and to squeeze every last drop of illegally obtained money from tax evaders, even though that be retrospectively done. But it should be recognised that there is an argument that governments have been negligent down the years and that they have no right to redeem their negligence by claiming taxes which were at the time legally avoided by companies from people who held limited liaiblity shares in those companies. The Government should take heed of its decision to introduce this Bill, and the Government must bear the loss of confidence in Australian investments if this legislation is passed, because that will be an inevitable result of its passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not do it, will it?

—We are all trying to advise the Government. I guess that we are trying to advise each other on this one, because it is not a simple piece of legislation. My concern is that not even one person should be unjustly caught in this net, either by the 1982 legislation or by the 1983 legislation. Surely the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats agree with that statement. It is a simple proposition. I suggest that there should not be one person unjustly caught in this retrospective tax net. I believe that all Australians would agree with that , even those who believe that we should really hit hard those people who illegally and deliberately evaded their tax at the time. That is the purpose of the endeavours that Senator Mason and I have engaged in over the last few weeks and which we shall put in the Committee stage tonight in the form of amendments to the Bill to endeavour to ensure that no one is unjustly caught in this net of either the 1982 legislation or the 1983 legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason referred to the lengthy discussions that we have had with the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) and with the Commissioner of Taxation. I pay great tribute to the people concerned in those discussions for the honest, earnest and genuine endeavours to find ways of ensuring that people were not unjustly caught by the 1982 Act or the 1983 Bill. My tribute goes to them not just for their wisdom and advice but also for their compassion and their understanding of the objectives that Senator Mason and I were endeavouring to achieve to protect innocent people who were not involved in making hundreds of thousands of dollars, or millions of dollars, in this matter but perhaps were being penalised by only a few hundred dollars-those people to whom those few hundred dollars will mean a tremendous amount, particularly in retirement; irretrievable money once spent on this, gone forever.

The purpose of our amendments is to give the right of appeal to an independent anomalies tribunal to all innocent shareholders who have received an unjust tax assessment under either the 1982 or the 1983 tax recoupment legislation. I cannot for the life of me believe that any senator would oppose those amendments . The Commissioner would have the ability to grant partial relief as well as total relief under our amendments. At present only total relief can be granted by the commissioners. Under our amendments it is not only the Commissioner who would have that ability; that flows on to the special anomalies tribunal, for which the amendments provide. It is an independant tribunal, not comprised of tax commissioners or tax department employees; it is a totally independent tribunal which hears the case. Incidentally, the Senate will be interested to know that it is to be made up of an ex-Taxation Office employee, who is no longer linked with the department, but also a nominee of the accounting profession and a nominee of the legal profession. So it is an independent tribunal.

I ask a very pointed question. I request the speakers who follow in the debate to indicate to the chamber how they intend to vote on those amendments, because my position will be determined by the response to our proposed amendments. I wish to know the position of the Government and the Opposition on these proposed amendments. I intend to spell out my position. I will support this new legislation only if it includes the amendments being put forward by Senator Mason and by me tonight. I will vote for the Bill at the second reading stage to enable these amendments to be moved in the Committee stage. I believe that if the Bill passes it will enable justice to be meted out to everybody and the 1982 and 1983 legislation will be embraced by amendment. If the Bill fails to be passed it is my fervent hope that the Government will have compassion for the innocent people who have suffered serious injustice under the 1982 legislation and will provide appeal rights for those people to those in the amendments which we will be moving tonight, if we are given the opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to read something to the Senate. It is a letter which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Harradine,
Ours is not some shady operation which the media and some politicians would have the world believe the retrospective tax Bill is aimed at.

Instead we run a long established manufacturing business in this regional centre employing 43 people at our factory including metal workers, crane driver, iron workers, storemen, electricians, transport workers and clerks. Plus 26 supporting subcontractors and suppliers.
Our company has become involved in this mess because of shareholding problems involving a shareholder who eventually wanted us to buy his share out early in 1980.
On the advice of our accountant, our solicitor and our bank manager, we sold the company and formed a restructured company to carry on the business as usual.
We need not have done it that way, nor did we do it to avoid taxes.
We did not receive any cash, or dividends or personal benefits from the transaction.
What we did was perfectly legal and approved of by the High Court.
Two years later we were shocked to hear that the purchaser of our company had rendered it unable to pay the current year tax and sent it to the 'bottom of the harbour'.
This Bill does not go after this purchaser but rather penalises innocent vendor shareholders.
Having conscientiously paid all our taxes every year, we were demoralised and embarrassed to receive a recoupment assessment for $38,000 under legislation you passed in Parliament last year.
Despite the current difficult economic climate, we have willingly paid this to the Taxation Department.
This is about the only aspect of the letter that I cannot believe. The letter continues:
Although we never broke the law, we can understand the argument that we should pay the tax we should have paid had our original company not been sold.
This new Retrospective Tax Bill is quite a different matter.

It deems a dividend distribution to have taken place of our company's accumulated reserves. This is ridiculous as no such distribution took place, nor could it have because our continuing business relies for its working capital and very existence on these reserves.

The new Retrospective Tax legislation would impose a massive penalty tax on the accumulated reserves of our company which have already been subject to tax and which would not have been subjected to further taxes in the normal course of events.
The new tax will be levied at 60c in the dollar on our accumulated reserves represented by our factory, plant, goodwill, stock and debtors at 1980 values.
We will have to pay $887, which represents almost the entire net assets of our company at 1983 values.

As a result of a double dipping taxation approach, the Government now intends to strip the entire company assets built up over 26 years and already taxed once thus ending the company's life and the jobs of our employees.

Even then the Government will not get what it demands because of losses on the forced sale of the factory at a price well below 1980 values assuming you could get a buyer, on stock rendered unusable, on debtors refusing to pay and on contract breaches and liquidators fees. Perhaps Senator the loss of our small family company will not be noticed except in this town.

But our company is in the same situation as thousands of others and that must surely be economic dynamite for Australia's business community and the tens of thousands of wage earners which were hitherto employed by these companies.
The situation we have described above is stark reality and not tinged with any element of flamboyant extravagant predictions.

Mr Acting Deputy President, this is representative of the points made in the hundreds of letters that I have received in respect of the previous tax recoupment legislation which came before this chamber. I received others from aged people who had arranged their affairs or whose affairs were arranged for them sometimes by husbands or other people to prepare for retirement in a perfectly legal way at the time. These people would have been caught by the previous legislation and would have faced ruin. Senator Tate queried the aspect of loss of employment. I challenge him to question the people in Devonport and Burnie who would have been affected by the previous legislation and will be affected by this proposed legislation. I challenge him to ask them what their situation will be, because he will have a few unemployed people on his doorstep if this legislation is carried, as will Senator Grimes in Launceston.

Honourable senators will remember that on the last occasion when this legislation was discussed the Federal Government refused to have the effects of retrospective tax legislation examined by a Senate standing committee. As I recall it, Senator Macklin moved that the Bill be referred to a Senate standing committee. Had that been successful, the previous measure would still be alive. The Minister was not prepared to let even one Government member vote for that proposition. The proposition for an investigation into the effects of the previous legislation was lost on a tied vote, 30 all. So much for open government! So great was the fear of the Government that what I and others were saying as to the effect of the legislation was correct, that it refused even to have an inquiry. Rather than have an inquiry, it preferred to engage in the tactics of bucket-tipping throughout Australia. That bucket-tipping and vilification were, by and large, directed at me. They were directed at me and at my State of Tasmania by the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, and by Senator Walsh.

I know that my speaking time tonight is limited and that the time for the debate is limited, but I have a number of quotes from both Ministers in the media. Those quotes amounted to economic blackmail of me and the State of Tasmania. Indeed, Senator Walsh suggested that because I had voted the way I had , the Federal Government might not be able to compensate Tasmania for the action that the Federal Government took to stop the work on the Gordon below Franklin Dam. This is all a matter of public record. Similar attempts at blackmail of me were used at the time the earlier Bill came before this chamber. Of course, I was aware of that situation. I will refer to it in a moment. I refused to be blackmailed. I voted against the measure because it was unfair and would have ruined thousands of innocent people, involved mainly in small family concerns.

During the debate let us not forget that Senator Walsh was so afraid that the truth of these injustices would be exposed that he blocked moves to have the effects of the Bill examined by a Senate committee empowered to do so. I challenge him on this occasion to allow this Bill to go to a Senate select committee to investigate its effects. Instead, on the previous occasion he and some others prefered to reap in the fields of ignorance and prejudice. What a fertile field that was. I understand how people feel about this matter. When I voted against the previous retrospective tax legislation I did so contrary to my own ingrained prejudices.

When this matter was first mooted by the Government I immediately thought, as one does when one hears of legislation: 'Beauty! We will be into that'. That was my initial reaction. As with other legislation that comes before us, we attempt to understand what it is all about. After many days of examination of what was foreign territory heretofore for me-that is, company taxation and company legislation-I formed the view, which I still have, that that legislation and this legislation were contrary not only to the principle of certainty before the law but also to the principle of fair taxation shares. My decision was, of course, unpopular with many people because they share my prejudices. They, like me, have an aversion to tax avoidance and tax evasion. Unlike some, I could not indulge my prejudices.

In the key situation in which I found myself on the last occasion, I had to put aside these prejudices and study the facts and the principles to be applied, and the Bill's consequences. On the basis of principle I made my decision. No matter how unpopular, how misunderstood or how misrepresented I am, I intend to come to the same decision now because nothing that has been said to me during this debate or outside this chamber has convinced me otherwise. The previous legislation was justifiably described as immoral and unjust, even by elements within the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who? What elements?
—The lecturer in taxation law-
—That was because there was a capital component in the last Bill. That does not apply to this one.
—The Victorian lecturer in taxation law described the legislation as immoral and unjust.
—Because it had a capital component in it.
—So the Minister regards that as immoral and unjust. This is very interesting. The Minister now admits-
—No, you are misrepresenting his position if you are applying it to this Bill.

—No, I am not misrepresenting his position at all. He described the previous legislation as immoral and unjust. By the interjection that the Minister now makes he understands that the previous legislation, on the basis that it included the capital component, was immoral and unjust.
—No, that was the view of the member of the Labor Party to whom you are referring. This legislation does not contain a capital component.

—Exactly. Indeed, the Minister for Finance at the time regarded it as immoral and unjust. I can say now about the Minister for Finance something I have been wanting to say for a fair while. I entered into discussions with the Minister for Finance on the previous occasion in a bona fide fashion. Now I have been betrayed by the Minister for Finance. He has chosen to go throughout the country bucketing me because of my decision. Yet it was the Minister for Finance who, on the last occasion the legislation was debated in this place, presented me with an amendment which would have taken out the capital component. It was his amendment and not mine. I told him that if he wanted the amendment he should move it; I was not going to move it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said on that occasion-this is something that has not been picked up with respect to this matter-the majority of the shareholders who would have been affected by the earlier legislation and who will be affected by this legislation have not received anything personally. There has simply been a rollover situation in which those moneys are now the working capital of the ongoing enterprise. That certainly has not been picked up at all in this legislation. Ironically, this legislation does nothing to track down bottom-of-the-harbour promoters. Instead, it seeks to levy upon law abiding citizens confiscatory taxes which were never owing and therefore never lost to revenue. Let the Press understand that. It talks about the loss to revenue of $270m. How can an amount be lost to revenue when it was never owing?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just confiscation.

—Exactly, it is just confiscatory. Senator Walsh ought to know that the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford), when Acting Treasurer, sought to have discussions with me about this Bill. I am happy to sit down in a bona fide fashion to have discussions with anybody, but I made it perfectly plain that I believed that discussions could not be bona fide when on the one hand a Minister, whom I regard with a great deal of respect, attempts to speak to me but his ministerial colleagues bucket me throughout the length and breadth of the country. I include in that Senator Walsh and his remarks to the Tangney electorate council on 12 June 1983. I think it would have been appropriate and in good faith for the Government to recognise that its previous legislation was unjust and immoral and to have the Ministers retract some of the statements that they had made about those of us who felt likewise and voted accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: The current Bill is basically the same as the previous Bill except that it has been modified to reflect changes in the recovery of personal income tax. Personal income tax is now to be assessed on the after-tax revenue, not capital profits, of those years of income in which primary company tax was avoided. What does that mean and how is that applied? Before I go to that, let me say this: The previous legislation and this legislation in fact impose a new tax retrospectively in a penal fashion. My view of the word 'penal' is not the limited litigant-type view adopted by Senator Tate. That litigant-type view enabled Hitler to start off his anti-Semitic purge in Germany prior to the war. In fact, if one reads from Keesing's Contemporary Archives of 1932, one finds:

A Bill to confiscate the entire property of all East European Jews who entered Prusia since Aug. 1, 1914, has been passed by the Prussian Diet, after a session in which the Communists sided with the Hitlerites. The measure demands that within three weeks the confiscated property be converted into means for aiding the unemployed.

That was not penal in the sense that Senator Tate was talking about but it was penal in the sense that I am talking about. The same explanation of 'penal' can be applied to the retrospective nature of this legislation. So this legislation is not basically different from the previous legislation. Furthermore, as has been pointed out, this legislation deems a 100 per cent dividend to have been declared when in fact it was never declared and would never, under any reasonable circumstances, be declared unless of course the accountant or the directors of the company were psychiatric cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were out of their tiny minds.

—Yes, indeed. So the Government is saying that money that was lost to the revenue should be recouped on the basis of what it says would have happened had the company continued to operate. Of course, had the company continued to operate there would have been, as has been said, a retention allowance. Yet this legislation is attacking even that. That is discriminatory and does not fit with even the Government's definition of what ought to be recouped.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that the time is passing us and I believe that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) will want to reply to the debate, so I simply state that this Bill, as did its predecessor, fails on the application of the principles of certainty before the law and fair taxation shares, and I intend to vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first comment relates to the letter which Senator Harradine read in its entirety . Even if-I stress 'if'-all the financial details set out in that letter were correct, the underlying assertion which has been accepted by Senator Harradine is that there would be catastrophic employment consequences if the shareholders of that company were to become insolvent and the business had to be sold. Even if it were so that the shareholders were insolvent and the company had to be sold, it would not necessarily follow that the business would be closed down. The business could be purchased by somebody else, particularly at this time when the country is awash with money.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make one other comment on Senator Harradine's speech. He claimed that this legislation was opposed by sections of the Australian Labor Party. When I asked him by way of interjection to name those sections, he referred to Mr Tim Margetts, who I understand was, and probably still is, a member of the Australian Labor Party. I have a copy of Tim Margetts's letter which was read into Hansard by Senator Harradine on 2 June. In that letter Mr Margetts says- remember that this is in reference to the legislation which was introduced in the autumn session of the Parliament:

. . . it ignores the reality that undistributed profits over past years and the current year may have both an income and capital character. So as the Bill imposes a tax on 'total assets' of the company, it might therefore also tax capital profits of the company.

That was a reasonable assessment of the Bill that was presented in the autumn session of Parliament; it is not an accurate or reasonable assessment of the Bill which is currently before the Senate. There is no capital component. Senator Harradine has claimed that this Bill is opposed by sections of the Australian Labor Party. The only evidence he was able to produce to support that claim was to quote a letter from Mr Margetts which referred to a different Bill.

Senator Missen invited us to examine his 1982 speech on the previous Government 's unpaid company tax or tax recoupment legislation. I have done that. I am happy to quote back to Senator Missen some of the things he said on that occasion. They include:
The question of retrospectivity which has dominated this debate is one which I think should be faced. It is one by which non-lawyers are mesmerised.
He went on to say:

Therefore we heard the honourable Alan Hunt, for many years the leader of the Upper House in Victoria and a consciencious Liberal at that, saying that he had supported more than 150 pieces of retrospective legislation with a clear conscience.
Senator Missen quoted Mr Hunt as saying:
If anyone tells me it is not Liberal, or contrary to principle, I say we don't belong to the same party. It's nonsense to create an overall principle where none exists.
Senator Missen continued:
That was very well said by Alan Hunt and it is very true.
Senator Missen went on to say:
But where crooked people have got away with money for years and where we can deal with them only by using this sort of method, it must be used.
Senator Missen said:
Reference probably has been made already in this debate to Lord Greene, who in dealing with this matter said, among other things:
And here Senator Missen is quoting Lord Greene-

It would not shock us in the least to find that the legislature has determined to put an end to the struggle by imposing the severest of penalties. It scarcely lies in the mouths of the taxpayer who plays with fire to complain of burnt fingers.
Senator Missen, in his remarks on 24 November 1982, also said:

It is time the Western Australian Liberals and other Liberals in this country who hold the same view got down to putting the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party back into the hands of people who supported the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer, the ordinary decent citizens of Australia.
I add that I entirely concur with Senator Missen in those sentiments. I regret that it has not happened.

Senator Jessop incorporated a number of letters in Hansard. I agreed to permit that incorporation. There are dozens, if not hundreds, of similar letters floating around, mostly from accountants who, it is apparent, have been involved in advising clients to indulge in bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all of them.

—Not all, perhaps, but certainly in many cases-in most cases-they have done so. One of the letters which Senator Jessop incorporated from, I think , a Mr Woods, quotes my colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) as guaranteeing exemption for dry Slutzkin schemes from the ambit of the previous legislation introduced in the autumn session. He went on to imply that the guarantee of exemption for dry Slutzkins has not been maintained. That is completely false. Neither this legislation nor the legislation introduced in the autumn session had any effect on what is known as dry Slutzkins. Nor does this legislation have any effect on the dry component of wet Slutzkin schemes. This legislation applies only to the wet components of wet Slutzkin schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be illuminating for members of the Liberal Party to hear again what their former Prime Minister and their former Treasurer and current Deputy Leader said just over a year ago about wet Slutzkin schemes and the people who engineer and partake in wet Slutzkin shemes. On 30 August last year the former Liberal Party Prime Minister said:
In a real sense, the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds , whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers, it doesn't matter very much.
On 12 September the former Prime Minister said:
I do not believe anyone could have taken part without knowing they were wrong.

By taking part, of course, he clearly refers to those who were actively and actually involved in the sale of companies under those fraudulent circumstances. Less than a year ago-on 21 October last year-the former Treasurer said:
the only tax to be recovered under the legislation is tax that was legally payable and the payment of which has been illegally evaded.

The former Treasurer and present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party said that that tax was illegally evaded. Granted, that was in reference to company tax. But the former Treasurer and present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party described the actions of those who took part in wet Slutzkins as illegal actions . What the legislation passed by the Parliament last year with the unanimous support of the Australian Labor Party, the partial support of the Australian Democrats, if I recall correctly even of Senator Harradine and the partial support of the Liberal and National parties, did was to recover company tax evaded by wet Slutzkin schemes. Perhaps I should define what a wet Slutzkin scheme is. A wet Slutzkin, as the term is generally accepted, is a scheme under which an actual or contingent liability to pay company tax is evaded. It was evaded through the sale of companies by the directors who controlled them to other directors who ultimately passed on those companies to bogus directors who either did not exist at all or who did not have the assets to pay the company tax which was due either on the current year or, in some years, on a previous year or on previous years and sold those companies at a price clearly in excess of the market value of the companies if the contingent and/or actual tax liability had been provided for.

What the May legislation introduced in the autumn session sought to recover was the personal taxation which would have been payable on all accumulated profits which may have been accumulated over 10 years or over a longer period on the capital profits. That legislation was rejected. The Government took on board the stated arguments and the stated reasons of a number of honourable senators for the rejection of that legislation-that is, that it was unfair and unjust that accumulated profits to the shareholders of the companies from years in which company tax had been paid and capital profits accumulated should not be taxed. That was a point of view. It was a point of view put forward by a number of honourable senators as the rationale for rejecting the legislation in the autumn session. What the present legislation seeks to recover is the personal tax evaded on the wet component of wet Slutzkin schemes or, in more common language, the personal tax evaded on the after-tax revenue income of companies in those years, and in those years only, in which company tax was evaded by the disposal of the companies in the way in which they were disposed.

The spurious principal argument raised by opponents of this Bill is that the personal tax would not have been paid if the companies had continued in operation. There are two possible responses to that spurious argument. One is that they did, in fact, continue in operation, which seems to have been the point which Senator Harradine was making when he read out the letter. If that interpretation is accepted, it emphasises the essentially fraudulent nature of the transactions which took place where a purely nominal change of ownership was engineered for a business that continued in operation for the purpose of evading contingent and/or actual company tax liability. If that interpretation is accepted, it emphasises and acknowledges the essentially fraudulent nature of the transactions.

The second possible interpretation is that the businesses did not continue, that the funds were paid out to shareholders in cash and were, therefore, a distribution of profits and ought quite properly to be taxable as personal income in the hands of the recipients of those profits. The argument put, principally by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, and reinforced by others, was that that did not happen. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and the others are quite wrong.

The fact of the matter is that the after-tax profits of the companies concerned were actually liberated to the shareholders in the form of the sale consideration, in other words, the price paid for the companies in excess of the assets of the companies, if allowance had been made for the company tax which was due. Even if the profits were lent or invested in the new entity, they were converted from revenue profits to capital and the existing tax law subjects to income tax the conversion of revenue to capital-for example, if bonus shares are paid out of revenue reserves or a dividend is credited as a loan in the books of the new company.

Under the 1982 legislation, the legislation rejected by the Senate in the autumn session and the legislation which is currently before the Senate, if the shareholders did not receive a benefit in the form of an excess price-excess, that is, to the after-tax value of the assets of the company so disposed of-the Commissioner of Taxation had a discretion not to impose the tax. I understand that that discretion has been utilised.

Another provision in the Bill to which no speaker in Opposition has addressed himself or herself is the repeal of sub-clause 12 of clause 3 of last year's legislation. Perhaps Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who is trying to interject , addressed herself to it very early in her speech because I did not hear the beginning of it. That is a very curious clause. It was not included in the original legislation which was put up by the Fraser Government last year. Its effect is to exempt vendor-shareholders' liability to pay tax and shareholders who sold shares in companies which were later put into tax avoidance schemes which were disallowed by the Commissioner. In other words, that clause established the principle that the liability to pay or not to pay was determined by the actions of other people after the event of the sale and actions of which, according to those who put up that clause, necessarily the original vendor- shareholders had no knowledge. In other words, that clause sought to define or to impose liability or exempt from liability in a most capricious way. The possible effects of such a clause were set out in a letter dated 21 October 1982 from the Commissioner of Taxation to the then Treasurer in which he said, inter alia:
The Bill has been changed, as you have requested-
That request refers to the insertion of sub-clause (12) of clause 3. The letter continued:
to exclude from its scope cases where there was-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who gave you that letter?
—Wilson Tuckey. The letter continued:

SPEECH.PARA: a post-sale avoidance scheme which, though ultimately unsuccessful, was reasonably expected at the time to be effective.
The Commissioner went on to say:

I hope that I am wrong, but observe that this change must open up the possibility that some promoters will, even through backdating of documents and the like, now seek to establish that after their purchase of the shares they did in fact put the company into one of the ''reasonably expected to be successful'' avoidance schemes. It may not matter that in execution they botch it up, what will be important is that they can show that they tried.

The previous Government was in receipt of that letter. In spite of that advice of the Commissioner, it proceeded to insert clause 3 (12) into the legislation which it had originally proposed. Nobody in opposition to this Bill has addressed the question of clause 3 (12) which this Bill seeks to remove from last year's legislation. The estimated cost last year to revenue of the insertion of clause 3 (12) was $40m. If the opponents of this Bill genuinely object to the other provisions, they will approve the motion for the second reading and then amend the Bill at the most extreme level to remove everything but the repeal of clause 3 (12). But, if they deny the second reading of the Bill, they are endorsing the fundamental absurdity and capricious injustice of the liability or non-liability to pay which is imposed by the insertion of clause 3 (12) in last year's Bill, subsequent to its original introduction.

Mr President, I am sorry that I will not be able to conclude my remarks before 11 p.m. It is important to put these facts on the record. The Australian Democrats have proposed amendments to this Bill, the substance of which is that before the amendments proposed by the Democrats become operative there must be in some way a linkage between the vendor-shareholders and a public company. The linkage can be forward or it can be backward, but there must be a linkage with a public company. The amendments proposed by the Democrats also provide the potential for a refund, effectively a restrospectively operative refund, on assesments which may have been paid pursuant to the 1982 Act.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., in accordance with the sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats provide for the possibility of a refund of assessments paid pursuant to the 1982 legislation . They extend the existing discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation to exempt entirely from liability shareholders who derived no financial benefit from the sale of the company, so that the Commissioner may exempt or make an assessment of the shareholder's liability commensurate with the financial benefit derived by the shareholder from the sale of the company at a price which clearly failed to take account of the contingent or actual tax liability of the company.

INTERJECT.PARA: The 1982 Act allowed the Commissioner discretion to provide time for payment without interest provided that no objection had been lodged by the taxpayer receiving the assessment. The 1983 Bill retains that provision but imposes a 12- month limit on it. In talking about the 1983 Bill I am talking about the Bill that is now before the Senate. The 1983 Bill, if it is passed, has the same provisions for accrual of personal income tax liability to be deferred or to have the payment spread over 12 months at the discretion of the Commisioner, again provided that no objection had been lodged.
Senator Jack Evans-Have you said whether you will be supporting those amendments?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —I was about to come to that. The Government takes the view that the amendments are reasonable and will support them. The estimated cost to revenue of passing such amendments-I think it should be emphasised that such estimates must be regarded as very approximate-is around $20m which, if accurate , still leaves the amount to come to revenue at around $250m instead of the $ 270m which was originally proposed. The Government also believes that the proposed amendments are reasonable. Therefore, we will accept them. If the Bill is denied a second reading the loss to revenue will not be $20m, as it is estimated to be if the Democrats' amendments are accepted, but $27m. It follows inevitably that if there is a loss of revenue of any magnitude at all, let alone of $270m, there is a mixture of three possible ways in which that can be accomodated. It must be recovered from other taxpayers who have not indulged in or benefited from activities which are, by definition, essentially fraudulent and which were described by the previous Treasurer and present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party as illegal. It must be recovered, if it is not recovered through the passage of this Bill with the Democrats' amendments, from other taxpayers who have not engaged in activities which Senator Harradine, by implication, described as essentially fraudulent and which the former Treasurer and present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party described as illegal. There would have to be an extension of the deficit or there would have to be reduced payments to the unemployed, to pensioners, to the States or to whatever other recipient of government revenue one cares to name.

INTERJECT.PARA: In closing, there is one important point which should also be stressed. There has been a great deal of Press publicity recently regarding the Westwools company and a scare campaign stirred up by the representative clients of Westwools. I think they are five in number. They were approached by the Australian Taxation Office. They then, apparently, circulated everybody who held shares in Westwools at the time in a way which substantially misrepresented the facts concerning this legislation. I have in front of me a letter from a person. I will not name the person concerned but--

TALK.START.PARA: —All right, I will. His name is Edward Henry McHugh of 54 William Road, Nedlands. He informed me that he is an age pensioner. He gave his social security number as well. He said that he is faced, so he has been informed, by Westwools with having to pay $87.63 under this legislation if it is passed. That is indicative of the degree to which the representative clients of that company have misled the shareholders of the company because, of course, if there is a liability of less than $100, irrespective of all other circumstances, nobody has to pay. Nobody has to pay a liability of less than $100. Finally, no assessments have been issued to companies which have had a lot of publicity. No assessments have been issued as yet to the shareholders in either Westwools or Metro Industries Ltd. The facts have been, at least in the case of Westwools-I do not know about Metro Industries-quite clearly substantially misrepresented to small shareholders in that company by people who are major shareholders, directors or controllers of that company for reasons which are not too difficult to identify.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. A moment ago the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) indicated that I implied that those who would be affected by this legislation had acted fraudulently. I said no such thing. In fact, I made it perfectly clear that, from the representative nature of the letters that I had received, the advice had been that what had been done was perfectly legal and, in fact, that this advice had been received by a person who is now a member of the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, as the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill is now superfluous and redundant, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be discharged from the Notice Paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.15 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 14 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there (a) long delays in processing claims for repatriation benefits; ( b) a large number of discouraged claimants who have withdrawn, and (c) a considerable backlog of claims awaiting review.

(2) Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs convene a conference of representatives from ex-Service organisations, the purpose of which would be to deal solely with the problems of the repatriation determining system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) There are delays which vary according to the sort of claim. A straightforward claim for one disability will be determined without much delay. More complex claims involving several disabilities, perhaps combined with an appeal and application for increase will take longer to resolve. In some cases, claims and appeals have been delayed for key appeal judgements to be given. There has also been a large increase in the number of claims and appeals lodged.

(1) (b) It is the practice of my Department to register as a claim any letter or enquiry from a veteran which could be interpreted as a claim. In a number of cases, further investigation reveals that the veteran did not intend the enquiry to be treated as a claim and the registration is then deleted. For statistical purposes this case is recorded as 'withdrawn'. No statistical distinction is made between those claims withdrawn by veterans themselves and those withdrawn because of incorrect registration. However, my Department considers the number of claims withdrawn by applicants themselves is minimal.
The large increases in new claims and claims for new disabilities and in applications for increase being lodged suggest that claimants are being encouraged, not discouraged.

(1) (c) Following an increase of 29 per cent in the intake of claims for pension over the last year, there is a backlog of claims awaiting determination. Presently there are 2,051 claims for pension where departmental investigation has been completed and the cases are awaiting determination by repatriation boards.
(2) I have stated publicly on a number of occasions that I am not satisfied with the times taken to decide claims for repatriation benefits.
I have arranged for the appointment of a fifteenth repatriation board to handle claims and the appointment of four additional part time service members of boards.

A 'fast lane' priority system has been introduced whereby claims and appeals likely to cause unreasonable hardship are speedily finalised. Officers with Commission delegations are being located in the processing areas of the branch offices to identify and act on straightforward claims, thus reducing the investigation workload and minimising the need for referral to boards.

I have also authorised the setting up of a special departmental task force to examine ways of reducing the times taken to investigate, process and decide claims and appeals under the repatriation system. That task force has completed a review of the policies and procedures operating in all Branch Offices of my Department and will be providing a final report on suggested changes to the system (including possible new staffing levels) by the end of October 1983.

The task force has held detailed discussions with a number of representatives of ex-service organisations and both I and my Department maintain close contacts with these organisations on matters affecting their members. At this stage I do not see a need to convene a formal conference with representatives of the ex- Service organisations.

The Administrative Review Council, of which the National President of the Returned Services League is a member, has recently completed a long and detailed study of the repatriation determining system. The Attorney-General and I will study the report of the Council with a view to bringing forward recommendations to the Government for reforms to the existing system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Treasurer seen an article in the Melbourne Age on 4 June 1983 by Mr Christo Moll alleging that Federal Investigators are angry that attempts to prosecute have been repeatedly blocked by the Australian Taxation Office which refuses to make available confiscated records.

(2) Is there truth in these allegations; if so, what action will the Minister now take to ensure expedition of proceedings or what action will the Minister now take to investigate the prior action by the Taxation Office in this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Treasurer's attention has been drawn to the article.

(2) No. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the records referred to in the newspaper report were merely copies of original documents seized and retained by the Australian Federal Police in October 1979. Some additional documents that might have some relevance to police inquiries were delivered to the West Australian branch of the Australian Federal Police by the Taxation Office, Perth, on 24 June 1983.
